title: PayPal Introduces New Leader for Global Product Team
content:
May 31
David Marcus, President, PayPal

For just about a month, PayPal has been searching for a new leader of Global Product for PayPal. Product is the heartbeat of PayPal, so it was imperative that we found the best fit to run this team so we can keep innovating at scale.

We looked at both internal and external candidates and I’m thrilled to announce we’ve found the ideal candidate within our own PayPal family. Hill Ferguson, who currently heads up our Mobile team, will now assume leadership of the Global Product team.

I’ve known Hill for a long time, having worked together at Zong and most recently as leaders of the PayPal Mobile team. Hill is obsessed with consumer and merchant experiences, and he’s the kind of guy who loses sleep when we put our customers through bad experiences. Hill has a strong track record of delivering: the ability to develop and drive a global product vision; a deep knowledge and understanding of the customer experience; an entrepreneurial spirit; an innate capability to cut through the clutter and simplify things; and finally an extensive experience in payments and financial services products.

Hill’s career achievements are impressive, having led product teams at Yahoo! around several of their flagship products including Yahoo! Finance. He then served as GM for Yodlee, where he developed a slew of new products that quadrupled the company’s revenue; founded LoanBack, which has processed over $1.5B in “friends and family” loans; co-founded Moneycard Financial, an innovative financial services company serving the underbanked; before joining me at Zong to invent the most frictionless mobile payment experience in over 50 countries. More recently, as the head of PayPal’s Mobile product team, he led our efforts around PayPal Here and, subsequently, the Mobile Check In API.

At PayPal we truly feel that we have an enormous opportunity to change the world and create the future of money, and we can’t wait to deliver the next installments of that vision.

title: Pick Up Some Sunscreen and Help a Great Cause at Outside Lands
content:
Aug 02
Oktay Dogramaci, Director, Cause Products, PayPal
Hi there, my name is Oktay Dogramaci and I’m the head of our cause-related products team here at PayPal. We’re using PayPal innovations to build new ways for everyone to support the causes they care about as part of their daily lives.

As we announced last week, PayPal is proud to be sponsoring the 5th annual Outside Lands Festival in San Francisco’s Golden Gate Park, August 10 – 12. While you’re there you can check out the PayPal Convenience Store, which will be the go-to spot for essentials at the festival: sunscreen, lip balm, a blanket, and more.

And today I’m proud to tell you that 100 percent of everything we sell at the store will benefit two great nonprofits: charity:water, which brings clean water to people of developing countries, and the Berkeley-based Seva Foundation, which provides health services for the underprivileged around the world. And you get to pick which nonprofit your purchases will support. If you rent a PayPal Locker to stash your goodies during the show, 100% of that rental will go to charity:water and the Seva Foundation too.

So whether you pay with a credit or debit card using PayPal Here, or use your mobile phone and pin or PayPal Card to pay with PayPal in-store checkout, you can feel great knowing you helped give clean water or health services to someone who really needs it.

This is just one example of how PayPal is redefining money and the act of giving right now. Come visit us at the PayPal tent to learn more and make your purchases count!

title: Honor our Heroes this Memorial Day
content:
May 25
Clam Lorenz, Director, Nonprofit Engagement, PayPal

Before you head out to enjoy your Memorial Day weekend, please stop a moment to think about those who have served in our armed forces. One way to show gratitude for their sacrifice is by donating to a nonprofit that supports servicemen and women and their families.

PayPal is a great way to donate to any cause that matters to you. To do our part for veterans, we’ve created the Honoring our Heroes campaign and PayPal will waive our fees for donations through the campaign:  100% of your gift will reach the nonprofit.

  • Equip the veterans of Team Rubicon who mobilize when disasters strike.
And if you’re shopping on eBay this weekend, check out their Honoring Our Heroes campaign too: it’s easy to donate when you buy or sell with eBay Giving Works.

These are just a few of the ways you can make a difference and honor those who serve, with PayPal.  Happy Memorial Day!

title: PayPal and ShopKeep Get the Concession Lines Moving at the 2012 Telluride Film Festival
content:
Aug 30
Hill Ferguson, Chief Product Officer, PayPal

Attendees of the 2012 Telluride Film Festival will be sailing through the concession lines this year thanks to a partnership between PayPal and ShopKeep POS, an innovative new cloud-based POS provider.

This is ShopKeep’s second year in a row powering all concessions at the Telluride Film Festival, a feat that involves supporting tens of thousands of transactions for 400 movies over a four-day time period. This year, PayPal’s innovative mobile check-in feature will be integrated into ShopKeep’s point-of-sale solution, enabling movie stars and film buffs alike to check-in and pay for their items right from their PayPal iPhone or Android app!

At checkout, the customer’s name and photo will appear on the ShopKeep POS iPad register where the cashier finalizes the transaction. Once the transaction is complete, the customer is automatically checked out and emailed a receipt of the transaction. No change, no juggling your drinks and popcorn while you fumble to pay. No hassle. Moviegoers can now focus on grabbing the best seat in the house instead of getting held up in line.

We’re thrilled to be able to show what the future of money and payments will look like to all the attendees of this year’s Telluride Film Festival, and we’re proud to partner with ShopKeep POS, a service embraced by thousands of merchants across the country. We announced our relationship with them back in May, along with other innovative point-of-sale software providers, to help us reach the thousands of small businesses across the country looking to bring PayPal functionality and security to their stores.

We look forward to continuing to showcase all of our innovative payment products at events like the Telluride Film Festival as we continue to redefine money and payments for consumers and retailers everywhere.

Until then, see ya at the movies!

title: PayPal Simplifies Credit Offerings for Small Businesses
content:
Oct 16
Peter Karpas, Vice President and General Manager, North American Small & Medium Business

I can’t tell you how excited I am to be sharing the news today around how we’re helping you, our online small and medium business customers, increase your sales just in time for the holiday season.

Here’s the short version: We’re announcing today that you will automatically be able to provide your customers with the flexibility to buy now and pay later, with 6 months financing on purchases of $99 or more when a customer uses PayPal and pays with Bill Me Later (and yes, I do need to tell you that your customers will be subject to consumer credit approval*, and they’ll be able to take advantage of the special financing, no payments, and no interest if paid in full by the due date).

You, the business, will get paid right away. You don’t pay any additional costs. And you don’t assume any credit risk. Plus, we’ve made it incredibly easy to market this throughout your site, in a way where you don’t have to worry about regulatory or legal restrictions – it’s as easy as going here:

Now, here’s the longer version!

As I just stated, today we’re announcing that through PayPal’s Bill Me Later service you will automatically be able to provide your customers with the flexibility to buy now and pay later, with 6 months financing on minimum purchases of $99 or more just in time for the holiday season. As far as I know, never before has anything like this capability been available en masse to small and medium sized businesses like yours.

Even better, we’ve simplified for you the ability to promote this great offer throughout your website where your customers are making the purchase decision in the first place. We know that most of you don’t have the resources to sort through the regulatory and legal restrictions required to market credit, let alone design and host your own ads. So don’t worry about any of that! Check out our special portal right now, where PayPal does all the work for you by building and hosting banner ads you can place directly on your site, so you can focus solely on growing your business.

Holiday season is the busiest time of the year, and we all know consumers are looking for deals and options. And Bill Me Later works. In an independent study, Forrester Research determined that 43% of Bill Me Later sales were incremental to online businesses, and that offering Bill Me Later can increase average order sizes up to 75%!  Increases like that will be critical during this holiday season when cash-strapped shoppers are looking for the best deal.

We’ve been in limited testing with this program for about a month, and the businesses who have been testing it couldn’t be happier with the results:

“As the largest homebrewing and winemaking company in America, we’ve been searching for a way to help our most passionate customers purchase more advanced homebrewing and winemaking equipment.   Brewing systems and wine presses, to name two examples, are large purchases.  We’ve wanted to offer promotional financing to help our customers out for some time, particularly during the holiday season.   Being able to market Bill Me Later and offer a special promotion is a great solution because it’s very simple to set up, gives our customers more options, and we don’t have to manage the payment process – PayPal handles everything and we get paid in full as soon as the sale is made.  Bill Me Later has helped our customers expand their home breweries and wineries  and make more beer and wine.”

— David Kidd, CEO of Midwest Supplies

“I added the new Bill Me Later promotional banners to our site last month, placing one banner on our homepage and another to the shopping cart page right before checkout. It was important to us to build awareness for the financing option while the customer is shopping, not just as they’re checking out. After just two weeks of displaying the banners we saw a lift in PayPal’s share of check out – an impressive 35% to 37.5%!  Can’t wait to see what this promotion can do for our sales during the last part of the year – our busiest season.”

— Nick Capinski, Senior Content & Engagement Marketing Manager, Eastwood

“We have been excited to participate in this promotion, we’ve seen that Bill Me Later purchases are, on average, larger than they are for any of the other payment methods we accept.”
— Wesley McMahon, Director of Marketing, A Main Hobbies

“Helping small businesses succeed is one of the platforms that PayPal was built upon, and something I know our whole team is incredibly passionate about. This is why this effort is so exciting – we can’t wait to see this offer drive success for you this holiday season and beyond. If you are a small and medium business owner or employee reading this, I encourage you to go to go to our portal to get the banners and grow your business.”
— Peter Karpas, Vice President and General Manager, North America Small & Medium Business

*Bill Me Later is subject to consumer credit approval as determined by the lender, WebBank, Salt Lake City, UT.

title: PayPal Sponsors Children’s Miracle Network Hospitals Classic
content:
Nov 09
Clam Lorenz, Director, Nonprofit Engagement, PayPal

We’re excited to announce that this year we are one of the proud sponsors of the annual Children’s Miracle Network Hospitals Classic. Running from November 8 through November 11, 2012, the event brings together 128 world-class golfers from the PGA Tour at the award winning Disney courses in Florida.

During the event, our global mobile payments solution, PayPal Here, will be used to collect donations. People will be asked to make their contribution via PayPal Here and in return they will receive a fun photo of themselves superimposed with the winner’s golf trophy!

It’s not the first time the Children’s Miracle Network has used PayPal Here at a fundraising event. In fact, they were among the first nonprofits to use our innovative mobile payments solution. We’re excited to be able to play a small part in doing so much good. In 2011, more than 200,000 nonprofits received over $3 billion in donations via PayPal.

Every extra dollar CMN Hospitals raises goes to saving the lives of children. Because of that, the organization believes mobile donations are vital. Nick Ward, Senior Director of information Systems for CMN Hospitals says, “With the number of events we put on, being mobile with PayPal Here will allow us to approach donors versus waiting for them to come to us. We can now take a mobile phone or tablet to places where we can engage with people that may not have donated otherwise, generating more donations for kids.”

The 42nd PGA TOUR event at Walt Disney World Resort, the Children’s Miracle Network Hospitals Classic is also the longest-running PGA TOUR event in Central Florida.

Children’s Miracle Network Hospitals is a non-profit organization dedicated to saving and improving the lives of children by raising funds for children’s hospitals across North America. For more information, please visit their website.

title: Help the Millions Affected by Hurricane Sandy – Donate Now!
content:
October 31
Clam Lorenz, Director, Nonprofit Engagement, PayPal

Hurricane Sandy, the largest storm to hit the East Coast in a generation, made landfall in New Jersey on October 29. Its impact was devastating: more than 100 fatalities have been reported across the U.S. Mid-Atlantic and throughout the Caribbean, millions are stranded without power, and flooding and snowstorms are widespread. New York City bore the brunt of the storm, which crippled its transportation systems and flooded parts of Manhattan and Brooklyn.

There are millions of people in need right now, but relief organizations are working quickly. We can help – here’s how:

Anyone can donate now to the American Red Cross, the Salvation Army, Team Rubicon or the Humane Society of the U.S. through our Sandy disaster relief page.  When you give, 100% of your donation will be delivered to the organization you support.

PayPal will credit back transactional fees on donations from October 29, 2012 through November 19, 2012 to any US 501(c)(3) organization involved in the relief and recovery. To request a fee credit for disaster relief donations to your organization, please send an e-mail tononprofit@paypal.com by November 19, 2012 with the account e-mail address for consideration.

EBay Giving Works has also launched a dedicated Hurricane Sandy site, where shoppers can buy products marked with a yellow-and-blue ribbon. The icon indicates that anywhere from 10% to 100% of that item’s final sale price, as designated by the seller, will go to one of a dozen charities or organizations working in the affected areas, such as the American Red Cross.

Our thoughts are with all of the families affected by Hurricane Sandy. Thank you for being part of the generous PayPal community.

title: eBay Inc. Announces Anita Borg Institute Sponsorship
content:
Nov 14
Kirsten Wolberg, Vice President, Technology Business Operations

Having access to a thriving network of supportive women can make a huge difference to a woman seeking to distinguish herself in a technology career. Personally, I’ve benefited from an amazing network of female colleagues (many of whom are now personal friends) that I’ve gained throughout my career.

Today many environmental and social barriers still block women’s participation and progress in science, technology, engineering, and math. eBay Inc. is committed to encouraging women in technology careers, and I am pleased to say that eBay Inc. is now a member of the Anita Borg Institute (ABI).

At eBay, including here at PayPal, we are actively working to increase the number and influence of women in our workforce – and our mission is directly aligned with ABI’s. Given the strong alignment between our goals, I believe that the Anita Borg Institute is one of the best organizations we can affiliate with and leverage to achieve our objectives.

Our sponsorship opens doors to opportunities that will provide significant benefits to our technologists and our global organization.

• Earlier this week, we welcomed Dr. Telle Whitney, president and CEO of the Anita Borg Institute, to speak with team members and future technologists at our eBay Inspire! Scholars Day.

• We are excited to take part in the upcoming Grace Hopper Celebration of Women in Computing – India in Bangalore, the largest gathering of women in computing in India. And we’re thrilled that Raji Arasu, CTO for StubHub, will be the keynote speaker at this important event.

• Finally, we are participating in the Anita Borg Top Company for Technical Women Survey for the first time, a survey that will provide us with industry benchmarks and let us know how we are doing supporting women in technology careers at eBay.

ABI will give the women of eBay access to female mentors, exposure to female-led technology innovation, and avenues to opportunities for learning and development. I am excited about the new opportunities our sponsorship offers. We will take full advantage of the consortiums and forums to recruit top female talent and to more firmly establish Ebay Inc. as a great place for women to work.

title: PayPal Data Shows Holiday 2012 Started September 30th
content:
Nov 19
Anuj Nayar, Senior Director of Global Initiatives, PayPal

Thanksgiving week has started and while the traditional belief is that holiday shopping really kicks into high gear this week, we have compelling data that tells us the official U.S. shopping season actually started on September 30th!!

PayPal processes nearly one-fifth of global ecommerce and our data builds on recent industry findings. The National Retail Federation said 41.4 percent of Americans said they would start shopping before Halloween and more than half have started by now.

This is yet another illustration of what we all see every time we go to the mall or a store. Holiday shopping gets earlier and earlier every year but that’s just part of a much bigger trend. Technology has fundamentally changed the retail shopping calendar. Retailers are now offering “holiday” deals as the fall leaves are just starting to turn. Consumers are still hungry to snap up the best offers available but they’re now shopping from the global marketplace, not just the stores down the street…and they’re doing it in new and different ways.

Last year, we told you about a growing trend called “couch commerce.” We predicted that on Thanksgiving Day 2011, we would see a big spike of people going from the dinner table to the couch to start their shopping from their mobile device – tablet or smartphone. And that’s exactly what we saw. On Thanksgiving Day 2011, we saw a 511 percent increase in mobile purchases over Thanksgiving Day 2010. That’s huge! Let me be clear, this is JUST from mobile devices. It makes sense, while you wouldn’t start shopping from your laptop or PC at the dinner table, you can from a tablet or mobile device as the tryptophan is kicking in and you no longer want to chat with weird relatives who have come over for the day.

A new survey from PayPal and comScore shows 62 percent of people said they’ll use their mobile device for holiday shopping, whether that’s to get price comparisons, product information or actually make a purchase. These are devices that were not around at the last election and now almost two thirds of shoppers are using them to drive their purchase decisions! The infographic below captures this new PayPal data and even more stats that illustrate the incredible impact technology is having on holiday shopping this year.

But whether you are shopping from a mobile device, a computer or in-store, you still want to make sure you are getting the best deal so PayPal is offering price matching for all your holiday purchases. This is very different from the price matching you see from some big box retailers this season. We will match the price whether you see the lower one online or in a store (and we are even price matching for airline tickets). And you get to price match for 30 days after your purchase, not just when you’re in the store at checkout. We’re also offering complimentary return shipping for your online purchases and the ability to buy now and pay up to six months later.

I hope you get a chance to take advantage of these great benefits this holiday season and experience the ability to purchase anytime, anywhere, any way. If you started shopping for the holidays as the fall leaves just started to turn, please tell us why (and what you were shopping for) in the comments!

title: Cards, Cards, and More Cards….How Do I Turn Them Into Value I Can Actually Use?
content:
Dec 07
Carey Kolaja, Vice President, Global Product Solutions, PayPal

In my desk drawer is a plastic bag where I store all of my “non-daily use cards” that I don’t want to throw out. I trust that we all have this collection, but let’s face it, I never use it…So what is the value on them?  As I took all of my cards out the other day (the picture below is my own) I found myself wondering, how do I pool them together to increase the purchasing power for something I actually want, need, care about?

That’s when I decided to use my cards towards my holiday shopping,  I called it my “gift card + card” challenge. With 15 separate cards, I spent hours trying to sort out the amount of funding I had left on each card. However, after spending a good amount of time entering in gift card numbers, I received “error denied” message after message as my cards expired months ago. This experience left me dissatisfied and frustrated over the waste of money I saw sitting before me. I sat there wondering if it is worth it to constantly be aware of when my cards will expire or just abandon the value on them all together.

I figure there has to be an easier way than having physical bits of plastic that I have to keep track of and find a reason to spend at that specific merchant. The reality is with little time to get everything done these days, the value on the cards will most likely expire before I get around to using them. And I know I’m not alone in my frustration on this. In fact, billions of dollars’ worth of cards go unused each year. At any given time, there’s $30 to $40 billion in unused gift card value lying dormant.

At PayPal, we’re all about finding ways to solve customer frustrations with their money and help consumers be smarter with their spending. With partnerships like Plastic Jungle, we can offer our customers more choices when it comes to holiday spending. At the end of the day, turning hidden pools of value into purchasing power is easy. So round up those gift cards, select from hundreds of merchants using Plastic Jungle to cash in cards (need minimum of $25 on them). You can get up 92% of the value delivered directly to your PayPal account to pay for purchases on your favorite sites. (Payout varies. See details on Plastic Jungle website*)

And consumers should have multiple ways to turn abandoned value into useable funds. In the not-so-far-off future, those piles of unused gift cards won’t exist. As we go through our shopping we won’t have to think about tracking loyalty points and making sure our discounts are applied – because our digital wallets will be doing the work for us. And that’s what my team is set on making a reality. Shopping, after all, is meant to be fun.

title: Mobile is Bigger than Ever, Transforming the Holiday Shopping Calendar
content:
Dec 04
Anuj Nayar, Senior Director of Global Initiatives, PayPal

We’ve been sharing with you all throughout this holiday season (and for the last several years) that mobile commerce is rapidly transforming the retail landscape and calendar. Thanks to smart phones, tablets, and other mobile devices, modern holiday shopping has evolved into a buy anytime, anywhere experience and holiday 2012 is the time when mobile really hit the mainstream in the US.

Nowhere is this unprecedented shift in consumer behavior more evident than at eBay Inc.

Our data is undeniable. This past Sunday, December 2, PayPal’s global mobile payment volume hit an all time high for a single day. We had not announced it but the previous all time high was Cyber Monday 2012 just six days earlier. Last Sunday exceeded Cyber Monday by more than one million dollars and we expect that trend to continue throughout the holiday season.

Just as significantly, eBay Marketplaces enjoyed its biggest mobile shopping day on Sunday, Dec. 2. eBay sold more than two million items via eBay mobile apps from Thanksgiving through Cyber Monday, but it also saw its mobile transacted volume more than double from the same period last year.

Mobile is big and only getting bigger.

For more details please visit our sister blog, eBay Ink.

title: PayPal: Free Shipping Day 2012
content:
Dec 14
Claudia Lombana, Shopping Specialist

Buying online and on my mobile device this holiday season has really made my shopping stress free. And with at least 44 percent of retailers offering free shipping this holiday season, having those gifts delivered is a breeze.

For the past few years however, "free shipping day" has been a popular, one-day holiday allowing consumers to shop from hundreds of online retailers with delivery by Christmas Eve! This year free shipping day falls on Monday, December 17th.

Last year, sales from free shipping day topped $1 billion and 2,600 retailers participated. According to comScore, it was the highest earning Friday in retail history and marked the first time more than half (52%) of all transactions included free shipping. With the growth in the number of people making purchases with their smart phones and tablets, we could see another record year for free shipping day.

In 2011, eBay averaged 600,000 daily free shipping transactions between Thanksgiving and Christmas, and this year eBay expects to increase to 900,000 daily free shipping transactions. PayPal saw similar results last year, and expects shoppers to enjoy the same convenience this year.

Year to date trends also indicate the growth in free shipping in 2012 – according to comScore, more than half of e-commerce transactions during each of the past three weeks of this holiday season have included free shipping, with a peak of 57 percent during the week ending Sunday, November 25.

With hundreds of PayPal’s retailers offering free shipping all season long, and more than 50 percent of eBay transactions offering free shipping including daily deals purchases and offers from major retailers on eBay.com such as Toys R Us, this holiday season will be very merry.

Go to PayPal’s shopping site to find out which of our retailers are participating.

Happy shipping and happy shopping!

title: Window Shopping 2.0 in Amsterdam
content:
Nov 14
Eelco van Wijk, Country Manager, the Netherlands & Belgium
Amsterdam is known worldwide for cheese, windmills and our 17th century canals, with the typical step-gabled houses. At the Dutch office of PayPal we believe that the Netherlands will soon be famous for a new shopping experience in the historical heart of Amsterdam.

The popular shopping district, De 9 Straatjes (The Nine Streets), offers a great variety of unique shops, restaurants, hotels, museums, culture and art. And the good news is that you can now shop around the clock in De 9 Straatjes! In fact, it is Europe’s first shopping area where you can shop in 30 exclusive boutiques, 24 hours a day from your mobile phone.

How does it work?

All participating shops have affixed QR codes to their shop window. With the special 9straatjesonline mobile app you can scan the QR code, which will automatically direct you to a mobile website where you’ll see the products displayed in the shopping windows. You can then select the product of your choice, in your desired color or size and buy it with PayPal in just one click. It will be delivered to your home address in a beautiful gift box within two workdays.

QRoute: mobile shopping tour

Over thirty exclusive shops from De 9 Straatjes are taking part in a mobile shopping tour that guides you along shop windows. In this so-called QRoute, you can scan products from all participating shops you are interested in. All of them will be delivered in a great gift box at your home address.

Why is PayPal entering the physical shopping streets in The Netherlands?

At PayPal, we are firm believers that technology will dramatically impact the retail environment in the coming few years. Mobile is fast becoming the navigation system for our lives and smartphone adoption in The Netherlands is currently at 44% (well above the European average of 30%).* We expect, given the mobile phone replacement rate of today, that it is likely to exceed 75% within the next two years. A recent study we conducted amongst Dutch consumers shows that people in the age-bracket 18-34 would rather leave home without their wallet than forget their smart phone.

That light smartphone in your pocket has got more processing power than the big desktop PC you had in your study room eight years ago. So you’ve got this super-computer in pocket format, with additional features such as GPS, a camera and scanner, and it’s being widely used: all the ingredients for a retail revolution.

John Donahoe, eBay, Inc. CEO, has said that the way consumers shop and pay in the next 3 years will change more than it has in the last 20. In The Netherlands, we see that prediction already coming true. The next wave will be a dramatic blurring of the lines between e-Commerce, m-Commerce and high street retail. Physical retailers will use internet technology to make consumers’ lives easier in several different ways: skipping the line, order remote and pick up in store, location based shopping assistance, or opt-in, user profile based service and incentives.

While we are very proud of the QRoute model in De 9 Straatjes zone, this is not an end station. We see this as a first step into that convergent world for PayPal in The Netherlands. 2012 is a test and learn year for all of us at PayPal around the world. We are testing many new ways for customers to shop anywhere they want. With this project we’re learning more about how to maximize the fantastic real estate available in shop windows to help sales 24×7.

And as Amsterdam is the second best city to visit in 2013 by Lonely Planet, I recommend you check out the QRoute if you are visiting any time soon.

“Tot ziens” in Amsterdam!

*Source: Mobile First research by TNS, 2012

title: PayPal Lets You Use Your Cash Anywhere – Even Online
content:
Dec 13
Patrick Gauthier, Head of Emerging Retail Services, PayPal

Using cash anywhere? Now that sounds a little interesting, doesn’t it? Obviously it can’t mean that all you have to do is try to stuff cash into your hard drive when you want to buy something online – particularly this holiday season where consumers are buying in record numbers!

Rather, I’m excited to let you know about our new partnership with InComm, a leading provider of prepaid products. Today we announced the launch of the PayPal My Cash Card. The PayPal My Cash Card is our first fully branded cash loading token that lets people who rely on cash to make secure and convenient purchases at any of PayPal’s online merchants. This is just one more way that we are giving consumers another great way to make purchases, spend money or give gifts – particularly this holiday season.

Many of our 117 million users have told us that they love using their PayPal accounts online, with mobile devices and in store locations, but are looking for additional options to keep it funded. The PayPal My Cash Card is perfect for consumers who prefer to use cash – but want flexibility to spend their money however they want to spend it.

After purchasing a PayPal My Cash card, which are available today at more than 30,000 retail locations across the U.S., a user can simply log into the PayPal My Cash Card website and load the funds directly to their PayPal account using the PIN number on the back of their My Cash Card. If they do not have a PayPal account, they will have the option to simply create one.

The PayPal My Cash Card is now available in more than 30,000 retail locations across the U.S., including Fred’s Super Dollar and more than 10,000 Dollar General stores.

This is one more way that PayPal is making connected commerce a daily reality.

title: Looking Ahead to 2013
content:
Dec 17
David Marcus, President, PayPal

For something that hasn’t changed much over time, in 2013 the payments industry will accelerate the momentum we have seen in 2012 in changing the way people exchange and spend their money.

This last year has been filled with companies launching innovative new solutions to enable digital payments at their favorite shops and stores worldwide. Even in an economic downturn there’s one consumer insight that remains robustly true – people love shopping but hate paying.

At PayPal we have an end-to-end view of the industry that others don’t and I would argue that payments at point of sale alone is not a problem that needs to be solved. The real opportunity for technology is to solve deep customer needs in new ways. That’s what PayPal did 14 years ago when it allowed all of us to purchase items quickly and easily online.

With that in mind, I wanted to share some thought starters, perhaps predictions, for 2013:

1. NFC will fail to gain mass adoption

The NFC payments debate will slowly die in 2013. Is tapping a phone on a terminal any easier than swiping a credit card? I don’t think so – it’s not solving a real consumer problem and its not providing additional value to encourage me (or anyone else for that matter) to change my behavior.


2. The payments, loyalty and coupons businesses will merge

The digital wallet must offer more than another way to pay. It needs to remove complexity from your life, not increase it. For sure, the technology needs to be great, and simple, but then it should get out of your way and let you focus on the things you most want – loyalty points or rewards for example. In 2013 payments will finally merge with loyalty and rewards. These three separate businesses will converge to make it easy for consumers and merchants to automatically leverage appropriate coupons and offers.

3. The cash register will go mobile

In the old retail model, customers browsed in the aisle and paid at the register. This was partly because the registers were hard-wired to phone lines to gain the necessary authorizations. As we move to a world where even the transactions in a shop are transmitted on the back end via the Internet, sales associates will be free to roam the stores and help their customers check out and pay from the aisle or even the changing room… and if they don’t have the right size or color in stock, they’ll order it for you on the spot to be delivered direct to your home.

4. The rise of new experiences beyond check in

To me, new location-based experiences will revolutionize more than just shopping. The power to be fed just what you want, when you want it, was still a science fiction fantasy in 2011. It is only just now coming to light in 2012 in its most basic form with solutions like Apple’s Passbook. I think that location aware, and context-relevant shopping and payments experiences will be one of those technologies that changes much much more for the consumer than even the hard working technologists in Silicon Valley can imagine today.

2013 will be the year that we will truly see disruption in the shopping and payments space, and here at PayPal we are looking forward to playing an integral role by solving real problems for people, merchants, developers and advertisers.

title: The Landscape for Mobile Payments

Anuj Nayar, Senior Director of Global Initiatives, PayPal

We have just wrapped up Monday at NRF 2013.

It’s been a busy day for PayPal with two major announcements:

1. We are now live in 18,000 retail locations and have signed 23 major national retailers in the US to our in-store initiatives.

2. We’re piloting what we believe may be the first order ahead and skip the line capability with a major national US QSR (Quick Service retail) brand — Jamba Juice

But the NRF action actually kicked off on Sunday when Don Kingsborough, PayPal’s VP of retail joined MasterCard U.S. Market Development Group Executive, Craig Vosburg; Isis Chief Sales Officer, Jim Stapleton; and Merchant Customer Exchange (MCX) executive, Dodd Roberts in a panel titled, “The Landscape of Mobile Payments – What Are the Options for Retailers.”

It was a lively discussion, as you can imagine, with four companies with such radically different views for the future of the industry but we did agree on one thing. Modern payments companies need to provide safe, intuitive, and ubiquitous solutions if they want to succeed.

What those solutions will actually look like is a hot topic at the show. Retailers, mobile carriers, technology and new and old school payments companies all appear to have competing views on what the future will look like. It’s going to be an exciting 2013.

PayPal’s Don Kingsborough noted on the panel that, “no one is ever going to ask for a mobile or digital wallet, they don’t care about the technology. Consumers simply want tools that help them save time or money.”

Dodd Roberts from MCX agreed with the sentiment and reaffirmed that solutions need to solve a legitimate problem, and that there was no use creating a solution to a problem that didn’t exist or was misunderstood by consumers.

title: One Year Later and Email Protection Continues to Improve with DMARC
content:
Feb 07
Michael Barrett, Chief Information Security Officer, PayPal

At PayPal, we take customer security very seriously. By contributing our security innovations to the open standards process and collaborating across the industry, we can help make the Internet a safer place for everyone. That’s why PayPal led an industry effort last year along with Google, Facebook and others to launch the Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC) specification – an open Internet technology to better protect consumers from phishing attacks. 

 DMARC helps to significantly reduce the amount of emails, which claim to come from companies like PayPal and eBay, but which aren’t in fact from us. By decreasing the number of spoofed messages that reach customers, DMARC increases the protection against phishing attacks and malware distribution that can lead to account take-overs and identity theft.

We always had high expectations of DMARC, but a year later, it has greatly surpassed those:

  • DMARC protects 60 percent of the world’s email boxes or 1.976 billion of the estimated 3.3 billion email boxes worldwide.
  • The specification has been adopted by many of the world’s largest consumer email providers– AOL, Comcast, Google, Mail.ru, Microsoft, NetEase, Xs4All, and Yahoo!.
  • 50 percent of the top 20 email senders including PayPal, eBay and Facebook, publish a DMARC policy.
  • DMARC has already rejected hundreds of millions of potentially fraudulent messages from domains like @paypal.com who publish a DMARC “reject” policy. As an example, in November and December 2012, more than 325 million messages were rejected as purporting to be “From” domains with a DMARC reject policy. Of those messages, 49 million were from domains highly targeted for phishing attacks*.
The fact that DMARC is now an open standard means that any e-mail service provider can immediately and freely adopt the specification to enable this same anti-phishing protection. We’re thrilled that so many leading mailbox providers and brands across the industry have come together to help keep consumers safer online by combatting phishing.

While the work of protecting our customers is an ongoing process, we are excited to see the success of DMARC thus far and we hope to continue to help accelerate its adoption in 2013.

 *Highly phished domains = Domains with a DMARC reject policy and more than 10 percent of all messages purporting to be from that domain failing authentication checks.

title: Yankee Group and ComScore Confirm PayPal as the Leader in Mobile and Digital Payments

Two major analyst firms issued reports this week that backed up what I have been saying on this blog for ages. PayPal is the mobile and digital payments leader. What I have not said here before, but the analyst data backs up, is that no one else is even close.

The Yankee Group released a study entitled “Google Wallet Is a Top App for Mobile Transactions.” But upon closer review, that title seems like a strange way to interpret the actual results of the survey.

While Google Wallet did finish third in the polling, it was a very distant third to our PayPal mobile payment app and the popular Starbucks app. In fact, the survey says that PayPal is more popular than the next seven mobile payment apps combined.

I hear all the time that Starbucks has cracked mobile payments with their app and that others should follow their lead. I love my Starbuck app and use it every day for my morning latte – because of their myRewards loyalty program that’s built in and gets me a free coffee occasionally. Many of you may know that PayPal is the only built-in payment option within the Starbucks app and the Yankee data indicates that the PayPal app used by three times as many people as the popular Starbucks app for mobile payments.

Meanwhile, ComScore released a new report that notes almost ¾ of Americans equate digital wallets with PayPal and almost half of them have used the PayPal digital wallet. Usage drops from 48 percent to just 8 for the next most popular wallet.

Although we’re on the right track getting the word out about our great products and technology, there is still work to do with the other 50 percent. It’s a topic we talk about every day – how can we bring our customers great products that add real value without bogging them down with technology for technology’s sake.

title: PayPal Leads Industry Effort to Move Beyond Passwords
content:
Feb 13
Michael Barrett, Chief Information Security Officer, PayPal

At PayPal, we are passionate about keeping our customers secure. This week, PayPal, along with Lenovo, Nok Nok Labs, Validity and others, announced the formation of the FIDO Alliance (Fast Identity Online) to revolutionize online authentication for Internet users everywhere.

Why Now?
  • Authentication is unmanageable for users. Users have too many Internet accounts and cannot manage unique passwords for each. The industry statistics show that many people simply reuse the same password everywhere and most of the rest have only three or four passwords that are reused everywhere. This means that users’ security is more vulnerable to malware, phishing and identity theft.

  • Proprietary strong authentication is not scalable. Websites like PayPal and eBay have millions of users worldwide. Most of the strong authentication solutions that are available today are not very easy to use.  At PayPal, we believe that our customers deserve authentication solutions that are both strong, and easy to use.

  • Threats continue to evolve. Traditional phishing, malware, script attacks and other threats exist, but they are becoming more targeted and moving to mobile devices. The defenses are evolving, albeit slowly, and so we want to do what we can to move the adoption of stronger, and easier to use authentication on all platforms, not just the traditional PC.
Why FIDO? 
  • FIDO will give users stronger and easier authentication options – beyond passwords. Users will be able to select the type of authentication that suits them best from a broad range of options – from fingerprinting scanning to USB tokens. In most cases FIDO devices will provide a two-factor authentication or can be used as a strong second factor. By moving beyond passwords, FIDO reduces users’ exposure to phishing and weak security at poorly managed websites.

  • FIDO is an open standard. FIDO supports a wide variety of security devices so you are not locked into a single vendor. Since the FIDO client can run on any platform, there is no need for lengthy and expensive integration for each website.

  • FIDO will scale for large websites and large enterprises. In most cases users will acquire their FIDO device and be responsible for its replacement. This removes the management cost that limits authentication token deployment for large companies.
Although the vision of the FIDO Alliance strong authentication ecosystem will not come to life overnight, we believe it is compelling. We encourage other companies to join us in the FIDO Alliance and to find ways to make online authentication easier and more secure for all our customers.

At PayPal, we’re seeing rapid and exciting growth. More than 5 million people joined PayPal in the last three months of 2012—the most in a quarter in over 8 years. We now serve more than 123 million active PayPal customers around the world.

But we can do more. And grow faster. That’s why I’m thrilled to announce that we just acquired Iron Pearl, a Palo Alto startup that is at the forefront of the science of customer acquisition and engagement. Iron Pearl has developed groundbreaking tools, methodologies and intellectual property, built on a new understanding of the social and cultural factors that drive the viral spread of products, combined with new approaches to data analysis and predictive modeling.

Iron Pearl was founded by Stan Chudnovsky and James Currier. Effective immediately, Stan is assuming the role of Vice President of Growth and James will serve as a Growth Advisor to the company.

Stan is a visionary in the emerging science of growth and he has a remarkable track record of success as an entrepreneur. James and Stan started and ran Tickle, one of the first social media companies and an early explorer of the possibilities of online viral marketing. After Tickle was acquired by Monster in 2004 for more than $100 million, they founded Wonderhill, a developer of family-friendly social online games that was acquired by Kabam in 2011. Stan was also instrumental in designing growth for companies like GoodReads, Path, BranchOut and many others.

The new Growth team at PayPal will focus on growing our customer base and engaging existing customers more actively by leveraging data to develop innovative marketing approaches and product initiatives. There are only a handful of world-renowned “Growth Hackers” with amazing track records and Stan is one of them. He managed to create genuine and sustained viral growth and retention for his own startups, and has advised others to grow at a tremendous pace, leading to hundreds of millions of unique new users. We’re confident that applying this unique, and highly effective skill set to PayPal will lead to making our groundbreaking payments experiences even more ubiquitous for our merchants and consumers.

Here’s to our next 100 million customers!

title: Why Mobile Matters for the Nonprofit Industry
content:
April 15
Tanya Urschel, Nonprofit Engagement Manager


As essential as PayPal's mobile capabilities are for businesses, they're equally powerful for nonprofit organizations. PayPal works closely with nonprofit organizations (over 300,000) and helped them to process more than $4.6 billion in 2012 alone.

Tanya Urschel, Nonprofit Engagement Manager at PayPal and Katya Andresen, COO/CSO of Network for Good, an online giving platform, co-authored "Why Mobile Matters: A Guide to the Mobile Web," a white paper that offers nonprofits research-backed tips and best practices for integrating mobile into their donation platform.

"The for-profit world serves as a key predictor of future tech trends for the nonprofit world," says Urschel. As mobile payments and shopping have revolutionized nearly every industry, PayPal and Network for Good are seeing these changes emerge in the nonprofit world. 2012 was a turn-key time for nonprofits: PayPal Mobile Express Checkout, PayPal's mobile web transaction platform, continued to expand in markets across the US and was an especially popular choice for nonprofits looking to improve donation completions on mobile devices..

Urschel and Andresen found that fundraisers could use PayPal technology at events; staff or volunteers can accept donations without administrative access to organizations' financial accounts. Mobile payment technology facilitates the in-the-moment decisions that define donations.

To take the first step towards integrating mobile donations, nonprofits can implement PayPal's Donate HTML button, which is now optimized for mobile use. Even for nonprofits that can't afford a new responsive design, putting the mobile-optimized button at the top of each page is an easy first step toward mobile success. 

Mobile e-commerce is a powerful, behavioral wave that nonprofits must incorporate to maintain their traffic, and therefore their donations. "2013 will be the big year for nonprofits," says Urschel. Take a look at the white paper to learn best practices and out how to get on board.

title: Magento Imagine 2013: PayPal Provides “In-Aisle Selling” and “Order Ahead” Capabilities for Magento Community
content:
April 10
James Barrese, CTO, PayPal

Have you ever wished that your drink was waiting for you at the store? Or that you could simply purchase that TV in the aisle instead of lugging it to the checkout stand?

By solving real customer pain points like waiting in line or carrying bulky merchandise, merchants can help improve service, attract more customers, and drive more repeat purchases.  PayPal is on a mission around the world to make it easier to enable better experiences.

To open up this promise for more merchants in more markets, we partnered with Magento to deliver two new extensions – “in-aisle selling” and “order ahead”– for Magento’s 150,000 merchants and community of developers in industries such as food, beverage, fashion and music. Through our relationships with Magento and our ecosystem of partners, we are bringing PayPal to more places that consumers shop everyday. The extensions for the Enterprise and Community Editions of Magento are available now throughMagento Connect.

In-Aisle Selling

We’ve created a new “in-aisle selling” extension that gives merchants a way to connect their Magento store to PayPal Here to complete the transaction anywhere in store:

The “in-aisle selling” extension gives merchants capabilities such as:

  • Flexible shopping experiences – Once the transaction is completed, consumers have the flexibility to take the item right then, pick it up at a special counter later, or have it delivered.

  • PayPal Here integration – Since there is direct integration with Magento and PayPal Here, all of the order details (name, email, order details, amount, etc.) are taken from the Magento ordering system, so the salesperson can quickly charge the customer.
Order Ahead

In January, Jamba Juice piloted a way for their customers to order ahead and pay with PayPal on their mobile device.

Working with our ecosystem of partners around the world, we have seen order ahead help drive increased sales and new customers in markets around the world and for all types of businesses – from quick service restaurants to outdoor cinemas.

With the Magento “order ahead” extension, developers and merchants have access to capabilities including:

  • Ordering experience – Consumers can order their favorite items from the business’ menu or catalog and pay directly through PayPal’s mobile app.

  • Simple set-up – We’ve made the “order ahead” extension easy and fast for Magento merchants and developers to integrate. Merchants even have access to customizable mobile templates to create menus and order pages quickly and easily.

  • Easy store management –Merchants can synchronize store locations and hours with PayPal’s app from within Magento.

  • Order pick-up – Customers can pick-up orders by name, by number, by time or even by scanning a QR code on their e-receipt. Merchants can manage order pick-ups either through a simple console available through the PayPal extension that can run on a tablet or computer’s browser; or an integration with their existing POS system using Magento’s APIs.
If you are at Magento’s Imagine conference this week, you can try out the order ahead experience out for yourself. Through the PayPal mobile app, you can order limited edition Magento merchandise and pick it up at the swag shop on-site – no waiting in line, no fumbling around for cash or cards.

We are looking forward to seeing the innovation that the vibrant Magento community will help drive by bringing order ahead and in-aisle selling experiences to even more markets around the world, and many more industries.

title: John Lunn’s Top Mobile Development Trends of 2013
content:
April 15
John Lunn, Global Director, PayPal Developer Network, PayPal

Only months into 2013, the marketplace has witnessed an influx of technologies that include data-enabled virtual reality glasses to pocket-sized cameras that correct focus after a picture is snapped. Likewise, mobile tech marches relentlessly into the future for developers around the globe.

According to the Economist, the number of mobile devices connected to the Internet will exceed the number of online desktop and laptop computers in 2013. For developers, this trend moves beyond just consumer behavior to a democratization of the mobile development space.

John Lunn, global director of PayPal’s Developer Network, shares why there’s never been a more urgent time to pay attention to mobile development.

HTML5 Takes Over

Until recently, native apps drove the development community on mobile. Developer teams would assemble resources, choose an initial platform, such as iOS or Android, on which to develop a product or app and ship it at high cost both in funding and in time. But 2013 is HTML5’s year. According to Lunn, the mobile industry is coming to “a stage where a less skilled developer can write apps very fast with compatibility across multiple devices.” This “democratization” of web-based mobile development will speed the rate of mobile innovation in nearly every industry.

Mobile Device Price Wars

Mobile device makers across all platforms have begun to price their devices down, allowing more consumers and developers to gain access to products, payments and information. Speculation abounds that even Apple is set to announce a more affordable iPhone this year. Combined with widespread HTML5 development, mobile apps will become exponentially more affordable to develop and ship and they’ll reach more consumers than ever before.

Cloud Service Becomes the Norm

For industries to fully tap into the mobile market, cloud-based services must become ubiquitous across multiple platforms. Developers focusing on shipping robust, secure mobile products based in the cloud will enable the multi-screen experiences and cheap devices that rely on it, something consumers crave.

“It's going to come down to the companies that make your life easier on mobile, rather than just accommodate it,” says Lunn.

These trends are all interconnected and compound on each another.

title: Mobile Focus: Top Features of PayPal Here
content:
April 16
Scott Henshaw, PayPal Ambassador and co-owner of Nanette Store and Motor Del Sol

Since its release last fall, merchants around the world have used PayPal Here to change they way they do local business. Just ask Scott Henshaw, PayPal Ambassador and co-owner of Nanette Store and Motor Del Sol. As a merchant with a presence both in-person at Seattle’s famous Pike Place Market and online, Henshaw uses PayPal Here to maintain brand consistency and quality.

“PayPal Here allows me to stay engaged with the buyers, instead of just saying ‘Thanks, have a nice day,’” Henshaw says.  His four favorite features?

#1. Increased Vendor Security

Before he set up PayPal Here, Henshaw’s iPad transactions took up to five minutes to complete—keeping his eyes off his merchandise and the busy crowds eyeing it. PayPal Here “put the technology in my pocket and changed transactions from five minute operations to 45 seconds,” Henshaw says.

#2. Increased Transaction Volume

Another benefit of decreased transaction time is the ability to keep up with the pace of sales in a fast moving market like Pike Place. While other sellers are forced to reject credit cards or enter transactions manually, Henshaw is able to “keep up with credit card transactions at a cash pace,” allowing him to make more sales than his competitors.

#3. Diffuses Cash Carry Disagreements

Customers not carrying much cash are a common problem in the local market environment. Sellers might have a great product, but potential customers aren’t carrying enough cash, forcing sellers to negotiate. PayPal Here allows sellers to diffuse this issue by allowing customers to access their bank accounts and pay for products in whatever manner they prefer.

#4. Brands the In-Person Transaction

Many sellers meticulously maintain their brands online. Why not bring that to the local transaction as well? According to Henshaw, PayPal Here allows sellers to combine the traditional local transaction and “combine it with modern tech and branding to stay engaged” with modern customers.

For example, when Henshaw sells chairs to a real estate agent, he will brand the receipt with his website, social media accounts and photos of the product. It allows buyers to “remember the experience and my brand,” increasing the likelihood of repeat customers. PayPal Here allows customers “to not just take sellers’ money, but also remember the experience,” says Henshaw.

title: Looking Back at the Last Quarter
content:
April 18
David Marcus, President, PayPal


We had another good quarter here at PayPal. Payment volume reached $41 billion, up 22%* year over year, and revenue of $1.5 billion, up 20%* year over year.  For the second quarter in a row we’ve also welcomed 5 million new customers. To all of you, I want to extend a personal welcome and thank you. 

Everyone at PayPal is excited about how many people we are welcoming each day. Today, PayPal has almost 128 million active accounts all over the world.

We are also happy to see so many developers coming back to PayPal. We were the first company to open our secure payment APIs back in 2009, in some ways our tools didn’t keep up with the level of innovation our developers deserved. We listened when they said they wanted better capabilities from us, and now we’re doubling down on our resources, APIs, and SDKs to deliver the best tools in the industry.

We are delighted that all our efforts are paying off by bringing consumers, merchants and developers to PayPal at one of the fastest rates in years. Our mission is to make everyone love PayPal and provide exciting new ways to use us everyday.

We are already driving exciting change for our customers by launching new ways to turn the change in your sofa cushions into money in your PayPal account or donate to a worthy cause while you are commuting into work (provided you’re not driving of course…). We even announced new ways to buy using your remote control, right from your TV.

We continue to make great strides. Recent studies have shown that we are the number one digital wallet in the United States, with almost 75 percent of Americans equating digital wallets with PayPal and almost half of them using us. Usage drops to only 8% for the next most popular wallet. 

Creating more and better ways for you to use PayPal is the next frontier for us.

PayPal is already in almost 20,000 retail stores in the U.S. and that number will rise considerably when our relationship with Discover goes live next quarter. We want to be everywhere people want to pay – online, on mobile devices, in-store and on every screen, and device.

I so am proud of the progress everyone here at PayPal made towards that goal this quarter.

Despite the title of this post, I’m not really a person who takes much time to look back. I’m much more interested in what’s to come. For PayPal the future is very bright and full of new products and experiences I know you’ll love. So stay tuned for more exciting news!

* Numbers calculated on an FX neutral basis.

title: PayPal Makes It Easier to Shop on Mobile Devices with Log In with PayPal
content:
April 30
Damon Hougland, Senior Director of Identity, PayPal

Today at the 2013 Future Insights conference in Las Vegas we're unveiling yet another PayPal innovation that helps solve real customer pain points - in this case making it easier to shop online.

My colleague John Lunn will present the latest version of our commerce identity system, Log In with PayPal (formerly known as PayPal Access) in a session at the show. Unlike other identity solutions, Log In with PayPal, provides everything consumers and merchants need to create an account and complete a purchase - including user identification, shipping information, payment details and checkout. More than 128 million account holders around the world trust PayPal with their commerce identities today.

As more consumers shop on mobile devices, retailers must make it even easier and faster for consumers to shop and pay. That's why we've tailored the latest version of Log In with PayPal for mobile devices and fully integrated PayPal's checkout experience for the first time. Studies show that nearly one out of four consumers abandoned their shopping carts when asked to create an account and nearly half left a site when they couldn't remember their password.

For merchants, Log In with PayPal can help increase conversion, limit checkout abandonment and establish customer accounts to deliver more personalized shopping experiences. Feedback has been terrific from our partners:

"Log In with PayPal adds tremendous value to Gigya clients by streamlining registration and providing merchants with a great way to reduce shopping cart abandonment," said Patrick Salyer, CEO of Gigya. "We're looking forward to offering our merchants the next version of Log In with PayPal and helping them see great results."

"Creating a rewarding shopping experience is a mandate for online retailers, and that includes making the checkout process as quick and easy as possible," said Larry Drebes, CEO of Janrain. "Janrain is proud to offer Log In with PayPal to enable consumers to easily register and checkout on eCommerce sites using their trusted PayPal identity."

And for consumers, it means they only need to remember one username and password - or mobile number and pin - for the thousands of merchants using Log In with PayPal today. Consumers also no longer have to fill out lengthy forms for every purchase. In a couple of clicks, they can securely sign-up or sign-in without having to enter credit card or shipping address information for every merchant.

Log In with PayPal is available globally and uses open-based technologies such as Oauth and JSON. It is also built on the same RESTful technology as the new PayPal APIs, so that it's simpler and easier for developers and merchants to integrate. Any merchant interested in bringing it to their site can get more details here.

- Damon Hougland, Senior Director of Identity, PayPal

Today was a big day for us. We were honored that Ireland’s Prime Minister, An Taoiseach Enda Kenny T.D., officially opened eBay Inc.’s new European operations center in Dundalk. The new center provides support for millions of PayPal and eBay customers across Europe, the Middle East and Africa.   We're creating jobs in customer service, telesales, risk and financial operations and account management so it truly is a site which will support all areas of PayPal's business. 
 
Ireland has been a great partner to PayPal. We’ve already hired 385 people in Dundalk, and expect to employ 1,450 by 2015. This is on top of over 2,000 people working for PayPal and eBay at our existing sites in Dublin.  Ireland is rich with talented individuals and we're expecting our workforce to include graduates, school leavers and people joining us later in their careers.  Our customer service team will speak multiple languages ranging from French to Russian to Polish – and we are hiring.  We are looking forward to partnering with the local community in Dundalk, and beyond, to find and train our new employees.

That amazing expansion reflects how quickly PayPal and eBay have grown in Europe and beyond.  That shows the success of our mission to create new opportunities for consumers and businesses through connected commerce. 
 
Dundalk is a special place for me. My grandfather was born there, moving to America at the age of 14. I was thinking of him today when Taoiseach Enda Kenny opened our new center just down the road from his boyhood home.  He was a man that enjoyed serving customers and his community his entire adult life and I know how proud he would be of his Dundalk family as they serve the PayPal customers and that community.

title: Looking Back to See Ahead: A conversation with John Muller
content:
May 08
John Muller, General Counsel, PayPal

Looking Back to See Ahead: A conversation with John Muller


Featuring John Muller, General Counsel, PayPal

As PayPal's general counsel, John Muller has seen many changes in the payments industry in the 12 years since he first joined the company in its early days. Since then, the payment industry has gone global and mobile payments have virtually exploded. With this growth, the complexity of keeping up with regulations, industry challenges and the competition has meant his team has gone from one person 12 years ago to about 80 today.

Still, from John's perspective, the more things change, the more they can stay the same. Recently, he sat down with us to chat about his story, how he sees the industry and his favorite purchase made with PayPal.

Q: Both PayPal and the industry has changed quite a bit since you came on board, correct?

A: That's true. The company was basically a year old when I joined and definitely a lot smaller than today. But even then it was growing pretty fast. As for the industry, a lot of the same issues that were important 12 years ago are still important today. For example, debit and credit cards are still vital to our business model, and issues around innovation and helping merchants succeed still take center stage.

Q: What are some of the key industry changes you're seeing? 

A: Increased globalization, for one. Mobile payments, of course, and different ways to accept payments beyond the traditional check out terminal. Regulations have changed in both complexity and scope. For example, while anti-money laundering (AML) regulations existed in 2000, there have been new requirements that have come in over the years, such as specific disclosures/requirements for international remittances.

Q: You and your team have a lot of responsibility when it comes to navigating the regulatory landscape, both here and abroad. Can you offer a quick overview of how you see the kinds of challenges PayPal is facing today?

A:  Complexity, certainly. That's what takes an 80 person team to deal with today. Even within the U.S., uniformity doesn't exist across states in regulation of payment companies. That's even more so outside of the country. Regulations in the EU are different than Australia or Japan or Singapore. And now, we're about to get a license in Russia, which is different yet again. So that creates a lot of complexity, both on the legal side and on the product side, having to build in the different elements to make our service compliant.

Q: Is PayPal helping to lead the way in helping shape the regulatory landscape in any way? Is it a role the company should have?

A: I think it is a role we have and want to do more of. There are limited resources and only so much time in the day, of course. Essentially, it's true for most businesses - you have a point of view on how your business should be regulated, and within whatever resources you do have, you want your voice to be heard. The challenge in the payment world is there is no industry association, at least not yet, that really speaks to the voice of the internet- and mobile-focused payment business.

At PayPal, we take a responsibility to lead. We want to promote international trade, lower trade barriers and increase opportunities for businesses around the world. We want to be a voice for these and advocacy for policy is one way to do that. So we look to be active in the technology industry trade associations, and we want to be commenting on proposed regulations, meeting with regulators and attending industry conferences as much as we can.

Q: Since you joined, what's your favorite item you've purchased with PayPal?

A: My wife is a big Boston Celtics fan, and in 2003 the home of the Celtics-formerly the Boston Garden-ran a charity auction to rename the building after anyone you wanted. I won the auction, and had the marquee read "Linda Walton Garden" for a day. So that was her Valentines Day gift for that year.

title: Entering New Markets: Complying With the Local Ecosystem is Key
content:
March 15
Laurent Le Moal , General Manager – Continental Europe, Middle East and Africa

Did you know that the highest skyscraper in the world is in Dubaï? That the richest man on earth is Mexican? That the biggest plane is manufactured in Russia? That Macao is now the #1 gaming place before Las Vegas? That the average age in Canada is 40, when it is 26 in India? That in 2020, 61% of the world’s wealth will come from emerging markets?

At PayPal, we know that the future growth of the global economy will come from these new international markets. We have been expanding our global footprint and deepening our service offering internationally. It is a key driver for our business.  We already operate in more than 190 markets, and it is a reality for the last four quarters now, that our international business represents more than 50% of our revenue, with a YoY growth of 26% in Q4 2012.

Therefore, we are in a unique position in the industry to see how fast these new markets are growing. We are also in a unique position to work with the local ecosystem to bring safe and convenient payments to local users – both consumers and merchants.

In this global environment, Russia is definitely one of the biggest growth opportunities for PayPal (along with Brazil, India and China), with 40 million online shoppers and already more than $13 billion spent online in 2012. As is our experience everywhere else in the world, expanding our domestic business in a new market requires a lot of preparation, attention and investment. We need to learn from the local ecosystem (consumers, merchants, banks, etc) and also work closely with local regulators. This is particularly relevant in the field of payment services and PayPal processed more than $118 billion globally in 2012. Russia is no exception.

As required by the National Payment System Law, we officially applied for a Non-Banking Credit Institution license (NBCI) in Russia. The Central Bank of Russia has been a key stakeholder and enabler from the outset, actively helping us to fulfill all requirements. We’re excited that they approved our application, which is a major step in this process but we are still just at the beginning of our journey in Russia.

Entering a new country with a relevant business offer, a strong consumer value proposition and close relations with regulators is key for success. This has been our experience for over 14 years.

We’re confident that the local regulators will continue to be our highly valued partners as we develop our payment services for the Russian market.

More to come in Russia. We will keep you posted.

title: Comic Relief and the Rise of Mobile Giving
content:
March 21
Clam Lorenz, Director, Nonprofit Engagement, PayPal

PayPal is proud to play a part in making it easier to give to the causes that matter, and to be trusted by more than 300,000 North American non-profits to process $4.6 billion in essential funds last year.

One of the things I love about my job is that chance to take everything we’re learning in the commerce environment, and to apply those lessons to the nonprofit sector.  As my colleague Sean Milliken declared in Forbes.com last month, one trend to watch in 2013 will be the explosive rise of mobile donations.

Case in point: Last weekend’s Red Nose Day in the UK.

Every two years, our friends across the Pond do something funny for money inspired by the charity Comic Relief and a BBC telethon, featuring famous names like Simon Cowell and One Direction. Last Friday marked the 25th anniversary of Red Nose Day, and participants raised more than 113 million dollars in 24 hours to help people in need across the UK and Africa.

What’s remarkable about Red Nose Day 2013 is that for the first time over half of the donations they received via PayPal were made from smartphones and tablets rather than computers. During the busiest time for PayPal donations – 9pm and 10pm – 62% of those payments came from a mobile device.

As exciting as this is, we’re only at the front of the mobile trend: in the U.S., mobile is about 10% of all PayPal payments, but only 3% of all digital giving. But by integrating with PayPal, Comic Relief offered their donors the ease of giving in a few clicks: reinforcing our belief that the easier we make mobile giving, the more people will use it.

You can read more about the rise of mobile in our recent mobile giving whitepaper here, and expect more updates about how we’re making it even easier to give on the go in 2013.
