title: PayPal Wins CSO40 Security Innovation Award!
content:
April 03
Michael Barrett, Chief Information Security Officer, PayPal

I am pleased to tell you that yesterday, CSO Magazine honored PayPal’s Information Risk Management team with a CSO40 award for our customer security innovation, known internally as our QuickPass Project: a method for deriving PINs for our customers based on their password. This award program recognizes 40 security projects and initiatives that have “delivered groundbreaking business value through the innovative application of risk and security concepts and technologies”.

A little more than a year ago, I challenged my team to develop a solution that would allow our customers to easily and securely authorize cash deposits and withdrawals to and from their PayPal account through a public kiosk such as CoinStar. My team implemented this simple, secure, device agnostic solution for accessing funds in a PayPal account via a PIN that we create for them in advance and without ever having to tell them what their new PIN is. But how does that work?

PINs are attractive for public shared devices such as ATMs and CoinStar machines for two main reasons: they are familiar and easy to use, and they don’t require the customer’s full password used to protect sensitive personal and financial information. But, the challenge with PINs is that a good PIN is hard to remember, which leads to re-use across multiple services and poor PIN selection such as 1111, 1234, year-of-birth, etc.

Our innovation addresses these problems by deriving PINs from passwords using an algorithm that creates a numerical PIN based on the first four digits of a PayPal user’s password. By doing so, we limit the number of credentials our customers have to remember. If you know your password, you know your PIN, which makes the user experience simpler, and incidentally, more secure.

Here’s what Mike Skinner, President of Coin for Coinstar, had to say about this solution:

“Coinstar coin-counting kiosks allow people to securely add coins and paper currency to a PayPal account from the convenience of select grocery store locations where the PayPal functionality is available.  Customers can quickly use those funds anywhere PayPal is accepted or withdraw cash from their PayPal account. QuickPass is an easy and effective way to authenticate a PayPal account holder who wants to securely add or withdraw funds at the Coinstar kiosk.”

I want to thank my team for their passion to enable our customers to use PayPal safely and securely anytime, anywhere, any way.  I also want to thank CSO for recognizing all of the CSO40 winners for their security innovations.

title: eBay Inc. Analyst Day – The PayPal Update
content:
April 01
David Marcus, President, PayPal

Last week I, along with several members of my team, represented the PayPal business at eBay Inc.’s Analyst Day. Gary Marino, Don Kingsborough and Hill Ferguson helped me tell the PayPal story – where we’ve been and where we’re going in the next three years.

Analyst Day is an important opportunity to communicate to the investment community what’s going on at PayPal and why we’re so excited about what we’ve accomplished and where we are headed.  At the event the team spoke about how PayPal is reinventing our company, and our belief about the unique competitive advantages that we have and the significant opportunity ahead.

I also articulated our company’s vision of being essential to our customer’s lives.

We want you to rely on PayPal, everyday. We want make your life simpler and easier and to give you more control over your money.

We are reinventing PayPal

To accomplish our vision, we are reinventing PayPal according to a principle that guided me as I built my earlier companies – Simple. Customer. Focus.

These words each carry meaning individually, and can be applied to anything — how we work and how we build products.

It is a philosophy that everyone at PayPal now uses to frame the way we work every day.

It is helping us to center ourselves on the most important thing: you, our customers.

We have unique competitive advantages

We shared with analysts that we think we are unique.

PayPal is a technology company, but PayPal is also a financial services company.

We sit between these two worlds and bring them together.

We believe that we’re also the only company at that scale that controls the full experience across the entirety of the ecosystem we power.

This puts us in a unique position to innovate at scale on behalf of our customers.

Endless opportunity ahead

And, I was proud to share that PayPal has significant opportunity ahead for our business.

We’ve proven we can deliver on big goals. Did you know that we doubled our business in the past three years?

A few years ago, PayPal was mostly about facilitating payments on eBay.

Since then we have scaled in merchant services and we’ve expanded into 190 markets around the world.

We believe we are the leaders by a long way in mobile payments, which has jumped from 1% in 2010 to 10% of our payment volume in the fourth quarter of 2012.

Gary, our SVP of Global Financial Services and the Americas, spoke about how we’re expanding our credit business by introducing innovative credit products designed to give consumers more reasons to choose us, and merchants more benefit from offering us as a payment option. Our approach to credit is to embed it within PayPal’s digital wallet, simply making it another funding source. But that’s not what’s exciting – PayPal credit removes friction at sign-up, drives higher conversion rates at checkout for merchants and increases engagement with our consumers.

Consumers who use PayPal credit are our highest value customers. Over the last three years we have seen on average that they spend 39% more and our transaction margin is 73% higher than our average customer who does not use PayPal credit.

All of these are now clearly part of our core and even bigger than our initial Marketplaces business.

And we are confident that this core business has miles of runway. As I mentioned, in the past three years we doubled our business and we plan to double it again in the next three years.

Don, VP of Retail and Prepaid Products, talked about the promise of omnichannel commerce – allowing people to shop and buy seamlessly online, on mobile and in a physical store — is next for PayPal and we are confident that just like in the past, what is now a seed, will with time become part of our core business.

And finally, Hill, VP of Global Product, showed off some of our upcoming products, clearly demonstrating the strength of our core business and product set, showcasing improved experiences for merchants and consumers.  More to come there!

We sincerely believe that we will be successful in delivering on PayPal’s vision of becoming an everyday essential brand for our customers and in achieving the goal we’ve set out for doubling our 2010 revenue by the end of this year. But the true way we are going to measure success – is tied to my philosophy of Simple. Customer. Focus.

We will only be satisfied if we satisfy you. If you, our customers, love us and love using our products, everyday.

And if you do, we are confident that we can make amazing gains for the business again and reach new heights in enabling global commerce and participate in eBay Inc.’s goal of reaching $300B in commerce volume in 2015.

title: PayPal Invests In Chile With Multicaja
content:

Mario Mello, General Manager, PayPal Latin America

For over two years now, we’ve been growing our footprint in Latin America by opening up local offices in Mexico and Brazil, and by entering into innovative partnerships in countries like Costa Rica. It’s a dynamic region where we see significant opportunity to work with partners who can help grow the eCommerce industry locally as well as foster the region’s participation in eCommerce on a global scale.

With 10 million Internet users, an eCommerce sector approaching 2 billion, and a strong culture of innovation, Chile is an important Latin American market for PayPal. Working alongside a company like Multicaja affords us the opportunity to empower

Chilean SMBs to take an active role in global commerce by using PayPal’s secure, fast and trusted payments platform.

We’re confident that this important relationship will help Chilean merchants connect with more buyers around the globe – to build and grow a loyal customer base with access to PayPal’s 123 million active accounts.

This new service is just the latest example of how we are innovating to help emerging markets participate in global commerce, and we don’t plan to stop here. We’ll continue to work with Multicaja to expand opportunities not only for merchants, but also for consumers in Chile.

title: What Happens When Your Credit Card Expires Online or in Your App?
content:
April 06
Anuj Nayar, Senior Director of Global Initiatives, PayPal

It turned March 1st on Friday and my email exploded. It turns out that one of the credit cards that I use on a regular basis is set to expire on the last day of March and I was inundated with notices from online locations, as well as apps on my phone,  where this soon to be outdated info is stored.

At least I was given notice. Last year, I lost and cancelled a credit card. For months afterwards, I was finding out new places that had that card info stored and would not process my transaction. My gym membership lapsed; I was late getting a prescription fulfilled etc etc etc.

Now I work at PayPal so it’s no surprise that I think the answer is to use us everywhere. But the fact is, I just spent two hours over the weekend going through old credit card bills and then logging on to sites to update my credit card information, when if they all took PayPal, I would have just updated my card once in my account and be done. I could have spent the time wasted this weekend on more productive – or at least more fun – endeavors.

In fact, even if I had not updated that one credit card in my PayPal account. It’s just one of the ways to pay in my PayPal digital wallet, so my transaction would have gone through anyway.

We’ll be at SXSW this week so I hope that some of the developers in Austin will stop by our developer lounge and check the new tools out because I know that I can’t be the only person who has not been able to use my taxi app at the last minute or order a pizza online because my financial info was out of date.  My gym now takes PayPal so it looks like I’ll have to find another excuse to let that membership lapse.

title: SXSW 2013: PayPal Launches Next Generation Developer Tools and Support for Mobile Payments Technology
content:
March 08
James Barrese, CTO, PayPal


Back in 2009, PayPal was the first financial company to open up its payments APIs for developers around the world. However, our tools haven’t kept up with the bleeding edge of innovation that the industry expects of us. As our President David Marcus remarked a few months ago, there is a “massive culture change” happening at PayPal, and we are at SXSW this week to ask our developers to take another look at the tools we can offer them.

Developers should have the freedom to focus on innovating for their customers, not spending time worrying about handling the complex task of payments. As one of the largest, most trusted online payments service around the globe, nobody can grow with a developer’s business the way that PayPal can. We connect 123 million account holders across more than 50 financial networks in 190 markets and in 25 currencies around the world. And, we do it securely so that developers don’t need to worry about managing complex issues like fraud or all of the compliance requirements.

But we listened when our developers said they wanted better capabilities from us, and now we’re doubling down on our developer programs to deliver the best tools in the industry:

  • Mobile SDK – Everyone knows that mobile is changing the way consumers shop and pay, and no one more than developers who must have a mobile presence to compete in today’s environment. We’re launching a mobile SDK so that developers can deliver great experiences for their customers by reducing friction when it comes to payments. Customers never leave the developer’s app experience to pay and they have more choice in the way they want to pay – simply click a PayPal button or scan a credit card using our card.io technology. We’re making it available for iOS developers first, but we’ll expand to other platforms soon.
  • JavaScript PayPal Buttons – Developers can now integrate PayPal in seconds by simply copying and pasting five lines of code into their website, shopping cart or a QR code. We’re making it easy to accept payments on a website, whether it’s a mobile device, tablet, or PC.
  • New REST APIs – In addition to our existing APIs, U.S. developers will now have access to new APIs built on modern, standards-based technologies such as REST, OAuth, and JSON.  We are beta-launching these modernized versions of our most popular APIs –payments processing and immediate settlement – to make it easier and faster for developers to integrate PayPal into their experiences.
    • Tokenization – A key feature of our new APIs is that we now tokenize credit cards for developers so that we significantly reduce their PCI compliance responsibilities.
    • Developer Website – We are launching a simple, integrated website –https://developer.paypal.com – that gives developers a single location for our sandbox, tools, documentation, and resources they need to build innovative applications.
     
This is just the beginning. We will be releasing new APIs and capabilities throughout 2013, while continuing to support our existing developer tools through this evolution. We will continue to listen to the developer community and rapidly respond to their feedback.

As the SXSW Interactive Festival kicks off this week in Austin, we’ll be on the ground showcasing our new set of developer tools and engaging attendees at the PayPal Exchange, where our Developer Lounge is located on the third floor of the Austin Convention Center. If you’re attending the show, please swing by!

title: PayPal Expert Testimony Today on Payments Industry Regulations
content:
March 11
John Muller, PayPal General Counsel


I’ve been at PayPal since before the eBay acquisition. As our business has grown and adapted over the years, I’ve seen us grow from a startup that helped friends send money to each other over Palm Pilots and email to an online payments company that now operates in 190 markets and 25 currencies. Today we continue to innovate at the rapid pace demanded by our customers as PayPal moves from online to main street, breaking into the $10 trillion dollar offline retail industry opportunity.

One thing that has been clear as we have adapted and grown is that running a successful payments business takes much more than just technology. It takes relationships with both merchants and consumers; back end processing at scale; risk and security management; 24×7 customer support and many other skills.

One of the most important skills – because it deals with the heart of our business; our customers’ money – is ensuring that we remain compliant with government regulations in every market in which we operate. We are, of course, licensed in the US by state laws but as legislators try to ensure that legislation keeps up with the pace of innovation the government is turning to leaders in the space to help them understand best practices in technology and payments.

As a leader in online payments, PayPal spends a lot of time working with governments around the world to help them understand our industry and how to regulate it. We were delighted when Assembly member Roger Dickinson, the chair of the California Assembly Committee on Banking and Finance, invited me to participate as an expert in a hearing titled, “Emerging Technology and the Money Transmission Act” to determine what reforms are necessary for the CA Money Transmission Act.

California is leading the way in helping define how the future of this industry is regulated in the US. If you are interested in listening in you can catch the hearing here. It starts at 2pm Pacific Time today.

title: Welcome to PayPal | Forward

title: One Year Later: PayPal Here Catching Fire with Small Business Owners Worldwide, iPad Version of App Makes U.S. Debut
content:
March 13
Hill Ferguson, Chief Product Officer, PayPal


What a difference a year makes. Last year at this time we launchedPayPal Here in the U.S., Hong Kong, Australia and Canada. Small business owners of all kinds, from non-profits to hair stylists, to roofers, landscapers and more, immediately embraced this new payments solution to help them get paid no matter where or how they were doing business. Now a year in and we’re seeing fantastic momentum worldwide as small businesses everywhere adopt PayPal Here.  

This isn’t surprising since a survey by Bank of America last year found that 45% of 1,000 small business owners cited “not getting paid on time by clients and customers” as the biggest challenge they faced when managing their cash flow. PayPal Here helps businesses get paid fast, easily and securely from a name they can trust.

So as we wish PayPal Here a Happy Birthday, we’re thrilled and pretty proud that it’s becoming such a world traveler:

PayPal Here in Japan

Just last week we announced the full-scale retail expansion of PayPal Here in Japan through our joint venture with SoftBank, a leading telecom and mobile Internet company in Japan. It is now available in more than 2,700 SoftBank retail locations and business sales networks across the country and available for both iOS and Android mobile OS platforms. 

SoftBank and PayPal are first-to-market in Japan with a mobile payment technology like PayPal Here to help more than 4.2 million small businesses, which account for 99% of all businesses in Japan and of which 80% still do not accept credit card transactions.

Since PayPal Here started selling in SoftBank Mobile stores last fall, thousands of Japanese small business owners have used it to grow their sales and have provided valuable feedback to help us enhance the total customer experience. With SoftBank’s countrywide store network and thousands of sales staff, we’re going to bring PayPal Here to the vast majority of small businesses in Japan.

Launch of Chip and PIN version of PayPal Here

On February 21st we announced that PayPal Here will be available in the U.K. this summer and eventually available in those countries that use Chip and PIN debit and credit cards. Aside from the product being tailored to this specific market, this version offers all the same ease and functionality of PayPal Here in the U.S. and elsewhere and demonstrates our commitment to our customers to listen to them and respond with products that meet their specific needs. 

We showcased the Chip and PIN version of PayPal Here at the vibrant Mobile World Congress in Barcelona to an overwhelmingly positive reception. And British small business owners have reacted with enthusiasm. Within days of the announcement, we saw more than 11,000 people registering their interest in the device.

PayPal Here iPad Version Now Available in U.S.!

And finally, we’re thrilled to announce that today the PayPal Here app optimized for the iPad is now available in the United States.

In order to create innovative technology like PayPal Here that makes small business owners’ lives easier, we collaborate with them to understand their pain points so we can solve real problems. In listening to our customers we learned that while all love the convenience, security and functionality of PayPal Here, some prefer the larger screen of the iPad.

So with that in mind we went about designing a new version of the PayPal Here app that would work seamlessly and beautifully with the iPad. Some of the new features include:

  • App designed specifically for the iPad
  • Ability to scan an item’s barcode for faster checkout
  • Wirelessly connect to a cash drawer and printer
  • Track sales activity in “Daily Summary” reporting
Leveraging eBay inc. technology (Red Laser), the bar code scanning feature lets merchants easily scan in items they sell to their Item List, and also provides a fast checkout experience for customers. 

PayPal Here for iPad is designed for small retail storefronts, sole proprietors, offices, or businesses who want to accept payments more simply with an easy to set up, scalable mobile payment solution that grows with their business. It’s perfect for those small businesses that don’t already have an existing solution, but we are also working with dozens of existing vendors that supply retail POS solutions – from large ones like NCR to mid-market providers like Shopkeep, Leapset, Vend, Kounta and Erply – so that we can offer businesses new ways to connect with their customers without ripping out their existing solutions.

All of these initiatives in the U.S. and worldwide demonstrate our commitment to helping small business owners take and make payments in a simple and secure way no matter how or where they do business. And, most importantly, PayPal Here helps them ensure they never miss a sales opportunity again so they can sell more.

Now that’s something everyone can understand, no matter what language they speak.

title: PayPal Launches Android SDK for Developers
content:

title: Let’s Lose Our Wallets
content:
May 13
David Marcus, President, PayPal


Every day the noise about "mobile wallets" gets louder in this industry. It's certainly a great catch phrase and makes for an easy headline, but what are we really talking about? A mobile wallet … a digital wallet … a cloud wallet …. or whatever you want to call it … is really just another way to store your money and pay for the things you want. And we're constraining ourselves by looking back towards a physical item when technology is taking us so much further forward.

Paying for things is something PayPal transformed nearly 15 years ago, and we have seen an amazing runway of new developments since then. We do more mobile payment volume than anyone else -- $14 Billion last year, a 250 percent increase in a single year. We also released exciting updates for the iPad and, just this week, the Android platform. And top industry groups have recognized PayPal's market leadership, with 75 percent of all American consumers equating digital wallets with PayPal.

However, as the ecosystem buzzes about the latest catch phrase, it's important to point out that wallets (in any form) are only a sliver in the story of how PayPal is transforming commerce, and more importantly, the lives of our 128 million customers. Mobile plays a key part, but it's not just about paying for a smoothie or coffee with your phone (or anything else), or just adding and holding your financial information on your phone. The opportunity is more than that - it's about solving real customer problems that make shopping experiences more seamless, connected, friction free and almost intuitive.

PayPal can help your favorite burger joint start that plate of sweet potato fries the second you check-in and order ahead. At the coffee shop, you shouldn't have to wait in line, order and pay for coffee. By knowing who you are before you walk in, the barista can have your favorite drink ready. It's a clothing store thinking ahead for you and delivering highly personalized offers based on who you are, where you are and what you've done in the past (and might do in the future). It's about relevant and real time coupons and offers that are tailored specifically to each user.

Enabling these elegant experiences and connections for consumers and retailers is what we're working on everyday at PayPal. We're finding new ways that both simplify our daily lives and make exciting things possible to deepen our connections to merchants and each other. We're turning all those 1s and 0s into something far more personal and meaningful than simply exchanging currency.   That isn't a catch phrase.

I don't know about you, but I'm looking forward to the day where I can lose my wallet altogether - both the word and the physical object.  There's so much more we can do with technology, there's so much more we can do to make life easier for our customers everyday, and I don't want words, a catch phrase or misconceptions to hold us back.

We're just PayPal. Onwards!

- David Marcus, President of PayPal

title: Survey Says: People Worldwide Really Do Want to Leave Their Wallets at Home
content:
May 21
David Marcus, President, PayPal

Last week, I posted about "losing our wallets" and the enormous opportunity in front of us to use technology to bring a new and better experience to consumers with regards to shopping and paying for things. But we wanted to go a step further. We wanted to know what people really thought about the prospect of ditching their wallets altogether. Today we released the proof that the majority of consumers worldwide really would like to do just that.

We conducted a global study in five large markets: the United States, United Kingdom, Australia, Canada and Germany.  The results are in and strengthen the notion that carrying around your financial information, credit cards, and cash in a wallet is simply just a pain. At PayPal, we want to remove friction from the financial equation. So we asked 5000 consumers around the world where and when that happens.   

Some of the anecdotal data was entertaining, such as… apparently no one wants sand in their wallets. In every market, the beach is the number one place people don't want their wallets. Maybe you'd expect that in Australia, but in Germany or Northern Canada?

Overall, the data that came back showed that what people want most of all is to lose their wallets. In every country we surveyed, at least 3 of 4 respondents said they wished they didn't have to carry their wallets around with them.  A vast majority (83%) of respondents across five countries said they wished they didn't have to carry a wallet. Additionally, nearly one in three Americans (29%) would choose a smartphone over a wallet if they could only bring one item when going out.  

While American consumers are keen to move to a digital payment future, the businesses that serve them may be lagging behind. More than two-thirds of Americans (68%) reported they have been unable to pay for something because they didn't have cash with them; for nearly one in three Americans (30%), this has happened frequently.

So, what people are saying is that they lose their spare change, they wish they weren't tied to their wallets, and they often aren't able to buy something because they don't have cash. Conclusion? We have a real opportunity to make people's lives easier … an opportunity to make shopping experiences more seamless, connected, friction-free and intuitive.

As we expand offline and into more and more stores, like Radio Shack,Toys "R" Us, American Eagle Outfitters and Jamba Juice and our other retail partners, we can help free more and more consumers from the shackles of the wallet. Jamba Juice, in fact, has been testing our Order Ahead program - where consumers can order and pay for their smoothies before they even get to the store. 

The consumer sentiment this new survey shows is more proof that we're truly on the cusp of a transformational moment with regards to how consumers will make every day financial transactions. People are ready for the day when the notion of carrying around a bulky wallet to pay for things will seem as antiquated as Gordon Gekko's enormous mobile phone in the movie Wall Street seems to us today.

Think of PayPal as the network that connects everyone, consumers, merchants, developers alike, and enables their money to flow seamlessly.

PayPal assists in all things related to payments.  For us, it's the beginning of a great adventure to help usher this transformation into consumers' lives, and to use the power of technology to bring them an experience that is not only secure, simple and extremely useful but, yes, a lot more fun.

Tell us in the comments below if you're ready to ditch your wallet, too!

David Marcus

President, PayPal

title: 100+ eBay Employees Participate in Bike to Work Day 2013
content:
May 20
J.D. Norton, Global Manager, Employee Engagement/Social Innovation, eBay Inc.

Every year, on one particular day, usually during the first week or two of May, thousands of cyclists, and the cycling curious, take over the streets of the Bay Area. May itself is National Bike Month, but this one day marks Bike to Work Day, and companies nationwide encourage their employees to ditch the car and put their pedals to the metal for their commute to and from work. This year, May 9th marked Bike to Work Day here in the Bay Area. 

eBay Inc. has been a strong supporter of Bike to Work Day here in the Bay Area for several years, as well as in many of our offices around the country.  We also have very strong cycling groups in our Omaha, NE and Salt Lake City, UT offices.  We see Bike to Work Day not only as a chance to participate in a fun event, but to also support a group dedicated solely to promoting a two-wheeled commute every day of the year -  the Silicon Valley Bicycle Coalition. We see this as a great opportunity to continue to spread a strong environmental message to our employees and our community as well.  It's also a chance to encourage a healthier lifestyle and it cuts back on employee stress for the day from having to find a parking spot in the morning (you should see our parking lots!).  There's nothing quite like a little fresh air and exercise first thing in the morning to get your day started off on the right foot. 

This year, over 100 eBay Inc. employees from both our San Jose, CA campuses participated in Bike to Work Day. They were all treated to breakfast upon arrival and were given an opportunity to enter a Bike to Work Day raffle, featuring all kinds of great bike commuter-related prizes.  Our local cycling group also volunteered to staff a Cycling Coalition table along a major morning commuting route not far from our South Campus.  Our South Campus also had a mobile bike shop set-up onsite to help with minor repairs and talk bike maintenance with curious employees.  As a side note, we have a bike mechanic on site at each campus once every two weeks for employees who need work done. We figured it'd be a nice perk to encourage cycling if employees are able to have their bikes worked on while at work, rather than having to make appointments with the local bike shop, which would often require them to leave it for a few days (usually on weekends) to get work done. 

Overall, it was another impressive turnout.  Happily, our headcount continues to increase with each passing year. We hope to one day have a completely empty parking lot on Bike to Work Day (we can dream, right?!). Now go dust off your own bike, grab that helmet and do something for yourself and the planet this weekend by going for a nice long bike ride (then do it more and more often until it becomes a habit).

Shopping is now a highly customized experience. Want to order from a food truck and pay by swiping a credit card and “signing” with your finger? Done. title: Research: Faster Mobile Check-outs Mean Bigger Payouts
content:
June 19
Todd Martin, Senior Director Branded Checkout, PayPal

In 2012, PayPal enabled $14 billion worth of global mobile payment volume and in 2013 we expect to exceed $20 billion. In addition to our leadership in this space, recent research from eMarketer found that people in the U.S. spent $25 billion on purchases made from phones and tablets in 2012, an increase of 81 percent from the year before, which compiles data from 120 sources that track commerce. They also predict that by 2016, mobile will be $87 billion, or a quarter of all e-commerce.

PayPal is the leader in mobile payments. In order for PayPal to stay ahead within this fast moving industry, and remain a leader in this space, we must continue to understand merchant and customer behaviors to create better experiences on mobile devices. As part of this, PayPal andBranding Brand developed a mobile study, which included four large merchants across consumer packaged goods, electronics, and the footwear/apparel verticals and measured approximately 400,000 visitors between December 2012 and March 2013.

The results were fascinating and demonstrated that simply adding a PayPal button on a product page – versus only at checkout – could help mobile shoppers check out faster and lead to a significant increase in sales for merchants.

  • Even adding a standard mobile optimized checkout experience, such as the one that is part of PayPal’s express checkout product, increased sales by 26% and 44%.
  • Adding a PayPal checkout button on the product page adds at least another 10% sales lift on top of a standard integration.
In one case, the sales lift for adding PayPal to the product page even went up to 32%. This sales lift includes all payment methods and has been calculated based on “per-visitor-value”. For example, each visitor to the merchants’ mobile site was worth $0.2 with their existing payment integrations, which included PayPal on the payment and cart page. Adding a third placement of PayPal on the product page would increase the “per-visitor-value” to $0.22.

The methodology was running concurrent live tests measured with Google analytics, and analyzed by both Branding Brand and PayPal to determine the sales lift.

You can go here for more information on PayPal Mobile Express Checkout. Also, feel free to leave comments below and we will be back in touch with soon.

June 25
Dr. Markus Jakobsson, Principal Security Scientist, PayPal

We all know how to log in on a computer or a smart phone, and how to enter a PIN in an ATM. But, how do you log in on a device that has no keyboard, that does not have strong support for biometric authentication, and where you have to be concerned that every move you make is observed -- and may be recorded -- by somebody who wants to know your login?

For example, how do you log in with a wearable device such as an exercise band or digital glasses? In many situations, you probably do not want to speak your PIN, password or mother’s maiden name, out of concern that somebody would learn what it is.

Say that you are on a train. You are reading an advertisement, and decide that you would like to buy that product or service. You look towards the bar code displayed in the corner of the advertisement, and you say “Ok, buy.” You see the price on the small screen of your wearable device, and you are asked for your PIN to confirm the purchase -- that is how the vendor knows that it is you, and not just anyone with access to your wearable device. What’s next?

You do not want to speak your PIN. Or gesture it. But here is what you can do, using patented technology developed by PayPal researchers.

First, the payment service provider displays a random PIN to you on your screen. Say, 1394. With a small cursor box around the first digit. Nobody but you can see this.

But wait, you say, my PIN is 1024. How can 1394 help me get to the right PIN? Well, let’s explore that!

Is the first digit correct? Yes it is. So you move the cursor to the right -- whether by saying “next” or by sliding the touch sensor on the frame of your device.

Now the cursor is over the digit 3.

Is that digit correct? Nope. You say “less”, “less”, “less”, or slide your finger three times backwards on your frame. And the 3 changes to a 0. So now you say “next” or slide upwards to move the cursor to the next digit, and follow the same process.

You could say “less” seven times, or “more” three times, or slide your finger backwards or forwards that same number of times. For each voice command or each touch, the digit on the screen changes, and you see what the current PIN is.

When you are done -- the PIN on the screen should say 1024. You say “Done” or double-tap on the frame, and your PIN is encrypted and submitted to the financial service provider.

And here is the charm: nobody, but you knows your PIN because nobody knows the random PIN shown originally.

This is only an example of the advanced authentication technologies PayPal is developing. Tomorrow, June 27, I will be speaking about security advances in wearable security at the CSF conference at Tulane University in New Orleans. If you’re at the conference, feel free to stop by!

title: PayPal Galactic Initiative to Tackle Payments in Space
content:
Jun 26
David Marcus, President, PayPal

Almost fifteen years ago, PayPal set out to be a global currency – to build the first money transfer and payment system fit to serve the entire world. Today we are there; PayPal is the boundary and currency agnostic platform, regularly used by 128 million people around the globe. We almost single-handedly created the online payment category and can truly say we have helped change the way the world uses money.

The time has now come for us to start planning for the future; a future where we aren’t just talking about global payments. Today, we are expanding our vision off Earth into space.

What we once deemed to be science fiction has become a reality. The enabling infrastructure pieces are starting to come together, and as we start planning to inhabit other planets, the practical realities of life still need to be addressed. 

We will still need a way to pay for life’s necessities, back here and out there, though exactly how we’ll do that isn’t currently clear. This is why, today we are announcing our intention to make PayPal the leading resource to address the challenges that these new and exciting times present. We are the only company currently poised to deliver payments outside of our planet. We want to be not only the world’s most loved way to pay but also the preferred money transfer system off earth – in space and between space and Earth.

Our PayPal Galactic initiative is launching on Thursday, live from the SETI Institute, supported by key organizations in the scientific community. This visionary program, spearheaded by PayPal and working with the SETI Institute, aims to bring together leaders in the space industry to work on the big questions around the commercialization of space. These include:

  • What will our standard currency look like in a truly cash-free interplanetary society?
  • How will the banking systems have to adapt?
  • How will risk and fraud management systems need to evolve?
  • What regulations will we have to conform with?
  • How will our customer support need to develop?
To mark this occasion, I’m proud to introduce the initiative alongside space experts including Frank Drake, Chairman Emeritus and Margaret Race, senior research scientist at the SETI Institute; John Spencer, the Founder and President of the Space Tourism Society; and former astronaut, and second man on the moon, Buzz Aldrin.

You can watch the announcement live at 9am PDT Thursday at www.paypal-galactic.com. Video of the announcement will be available after the event at the same location.

Already the need for a payment system off Earth exists. Astronauts inhabiting space stations today still need to pay for life’s necessities—from their bills back on Earth to their entertainment, like music and e-books, while in space.

The functionality is already in place for us to facilitate transactions across the globe – internet connectivity, a bank account, and an e-mail address or mobile phone number are all you need to use PayPal. Our robust and proven systems that help us to transact safely and securely in 25 currencies across multiple banking systems, are built to be scalable – out into the solar system and beyond.

Creating a secure and functional commerce system that can operate in space at scale will not be easy, but with the support of the scientific community, other technology companies and the public at large, we hope to find the solutions to address these challenges. This is just the beginning. Specific details still need to be addressed, and we look forward to keeping you updated with our progress and to the day when we are truly able to make space a commercial reality.

title: French Customers Able to Reload Minutes on Friends/Family Mobile Phones
content:
July 03
Marc Jaugey, Director of Communications + Social Media, PayPal EMEA

PayPal has taken ‘Act Mobile’ to a new level by launching a service in France that enables airtime transfer globally.

Did you know that of the 6 billion mobile users worldwide, the vast majority are prepaid and that these users make $50 billion in top-up purchases per year? “Top-up” or airtime (as it is called in the payment industry) is prepaid minutes that are added to mobile phones. A unique feature of top-up is that some mobile operators offer their prepaid customers mobile-to-mobile minute sharing. This airtime sharing monetization is a new form of Mobile Money and a widely used practice around the world, representing an estimated $20 billion market!

Prepaid mobile phones have dramatically improved the life of all its users and have become a tool of economic empowerment allowing information to move more freely and unleashing entrepreneurship. This is why we are so excited to share with you PayPal Mobile Reload, an innovative PayPal service that enables consumers to use their PayPal account to instantly reload the mobile phones of friends and family in more than 60 countries through 200 mobile network operators! As always, PayPal helps the consumer do this in a simple and secure way.

Developed in partnership with TransferTo, the global airtime leader owned by payment provider company Ingenico, PayPal Mobile Reload, gives French users [currently only available to send minutes from a French account] an easy way to reload mobile devices! Users simply have to go to PayPal Mobile Reload, and select the recipient’s country, enter the recipient’s mobile phone number, the amount they want to send to their mobile phone, and finally, pay with PayPal. The mobile phone is reloaded instantly. Once the reload has been completed, the sender will receive an email from PayPal confirming the transaction and the recipient will receive a text message.

PayPal Mobile Reload is a first step to connect 200 million people worldwide working and living in a country other than their own with their friends and family and to tap into the $300 billion that is sent cross-border every year.

PayPal is committed to innovating and simplifying payments however large or small for people in a convenient, user-friendly and safe manner.

title: Order Ahead Your ‘Flat White’ with PayPal at Your Favorite Sydney, Australia Cafés
content:

Jeff Clementz, Managing Director, PayPal Australia

Aussies love their coffee. They’re deeply passionate about their ‘flat whites’ (a fancy word for a latte), with a thriving café culture present across the nation.

To give you an idea of what I am talking about, here are some coffee-related numbers – Australia has a population of 23 million and of those 10 million are coffee drinkers. These drinkers purchase 2.2 billion cups of coffee each year from 15,300 cafes located across Australia.

It’s been just over six months since we launched our offline payments in Australia. Sonoma Bakery was one of the first locations to enable PayPal payments in-store and since then we have been working with a number of other strategic partners and cafes to integrate PayPal at the point-of-sale. Today there are 170 cafes across Australia that accept PayPal payments.

With one of the highest smartphone penetrations in the world, Australians have been quick to adopt mobile commerce, using their smartphones to search, browse and shop easily and conveniently on the go.

To make buying your morning coffee even simpler, PayPal has integrated ‘Order Ahead’ functionality within the PayPal consumer app, powered by a local start-up called Beat The Q. Now, when Australians look for ‘local’ cafes using the PayPal app, they can check-in, browse the café menu, place an order and pay via PayPal – all through the PayPal app.

Another great advantage is that within the PayPal App you can save your favorite order to make it even quicker to place your order in a few clicks. Loyalty is also built into the app so you can see how many coffees you have purchased from a café and automatically get a free coffee when you are entitled to it without having to remember a physical loyalty card.

The customer’s order then appears on the café’s point of sale terminal screen so they can get the order ready in time for the customer’s arrival – allowing PayPal customers to feel like a rock star as they zip past the queue and pick up their order as soon as they walk in. title: Building Opportunities Around the World with Habitat for Humanity
content:
May 30
Prashanthi Ravanavarapu, eBay Inc.

For the past two years, eBay Inc’s holiday donation as a company was made to Habitat for Humanity, and a select group of employees applied to be chosen for the opportunity to build a home for a family in need.

The first Habitat for Humanity donation last year sent teams of employees to build homes in the poorest regions of China, India and Brazil. Stories from the employees who went were moving and their lives were transformed by the experience.

This year, eBay Inc increased the opportunities to participate. In addition to returning to last year’s countries, they expanded the program to build sites in the United States as well, where there also is tremendous need.

Prashanthi Ravanavarapu, an eBay Inc employee, participated in the build that took place in Sichuan, China. Here is a brief overview of her experience:

The Habitat For Humanity (HFH) trip to Sichuan, China was amazing! It was everything and more than I expected. While I am extremely overwhelmed and saddened by some of the realities in this remote part of the world, I am inspired by other aspects.

It felt great to know that we made a direct impact and were part of making somebody's dream a reality. In some of these cases, we were helping an individual who had never even dreamed of ever having a humble home. HFH scouts these families and helps them. There is no application process. Mr. Zhou, the homeowner we helped in Sichuan, couldn't even believe that it was happening. Even on the day we started to build the house, he was in disbelief. Now, he and his 94-year old mom are thrilled to have a home they can be proud of. eBay Inc helped fund 3 such homes in Sichuan this year and the entire team was touched by the stories of these families. In total, eBay Inc funded 30 homes around the world and sent teams to 5 different sites.

We had an amazing team in Sichuan, which consisted of 16 people from across the company and from different locations in the world. Despite the earthquake that hit very close to our build site, the whole team showed up to work.

The goal was to build at least one wall up to 1m. We built the side walls up to 2.5m and all the other walls to 1.5m. HFH partners said we were the most goal oriented team they had ever seen. We almost always shortened our 90-minute lunch to 30 minutes so we could get back to work. We moved 10,000 bricks, dug foundations, mixed mortar, moved mud, laid bricks and had fun doing it. We all walked away with immense gratitude for this opportunity.

Here are a few of our leadership learnings and observations:
Shared Purpose: When a team of people have a common goal (shared purpose), they will go above and beyond any physical, emotional or other issues to ensure that the goal is achieved. In our case, we beat all of our goals in less time and with a smile on our faces. There is no room for ego or politics.

  • Direct Impact Inspires: When an individual feels like he/she is making a positive impact directly to another life, the energy they bring to work is intense.

  • Keeping Up the Team Spirit: It is up to the leader to ensure that they provide the right tools and resources for their teams. If not, the teams might begin to feel like they are not delivering well. In our case, we kept running out of brick, mortar and tools so some of the team members felt like they were not be utilized completely. The leaders of the team worked hard to keep the morale of all team members high.
After the HFH Trip

While I am overwhelmed with the needs in this world and sad that we can only do so much, I am committed to keep growing so that I can have more impact. I am committed to plant more seeds of little bits of good so that those around me might be inspired to take it forward

title: PayPal Here in Japan: One year, 2,700 stores and thousands of happy merchants
content:
May 22
Rohan Mahadevan, VP of Asia Pacific


It's been a year since PayPal announced a strategic alliance with Japan's leading Internet company, Softbank, to be the first to bring a mobile payment system to small businesses in Japan.

More than 2,700 Softbank stores now prominently display the PayPal Here reader and thousands of small businesses have embraced it.

Via SoftBank retail shops and through SoftBank's business sales network across Japan, we can now reach 80% of the Japanese small businesses that still do not accept credit card transactions today. 

It would be hard for even a globally recognized brand such as PayPal to succeed going it alone in the Japanese market.

Our experience in the last year has shown us that partnering with a well established brand such as Softbank was the right approach to getting Japanese small businesses to embrace new ways to get paid.

So who in Japan is using it? The answer is anyone who wants to grow their business fast, but we are seeing a lot of traction in coffee shops and restaurants in particular, as well as beauty service providers such as nail salons.

These market segments have embraced PayPal Here because they've been cash-based businesses until now and have been losing sales because they can't accept credit cards. A lot of small businesses are seeing their customers spend more when they are not limited to the cash they have on hand in their stores. But don't just take our word for it. Here's what several Japanese small business owners had to say about how PayPal Here is helping their business thrive. 

"After we started using PayPal Here at exhibitions and showrooms, 90% of our sales came through credit card transactions via PayPal Here. When customers find out that they can use their credit card, they feel more comfortable when choosing and purchasing products. As a result, both unit sales price and total sales volume have increased," commented Mr. Hiroyuki Miyazaki, CEO of Aquarylis, a jewelry shop that sells high-quality, hand-crafted stone jewelry at exhibitions in Tokyo and Osaka, as well as through face-to-face sales opportunities.

 “PayPal Here has no monthly charge and an easy transaction process, so we are happy to recommend our customers to pay via credit card. Also, our sales team comments that PayPal Here enables credit card payments at sales visits to yoyo competitions and exhibition events. Moreover, sales from our online and physical stores can be completed through PayPal, an easier way to manage overall sales transactions for our business,” commented Mr. Masahiro Noma, CEO of YoYo Company which has a shop called Rewind located in Aichi prefecture, selling a range of popular yoyos including professional models for world competitions.

"After introducing PayPal Here, it is a more convenient way to pay for customers and we are able to grow our sales by offering more payment choices to our customers. Although the transaction fee cost is 5% of sales, the amount of lost business by not offering credit card acceptance is even higher," commented Mr. Daisuke Tanaka, CEO of Uniginal Ltd., managing company of Milton Coffee Roastery, a cafe located in South Yamaguchi prefecture.

"Three weeks after we started, we saw that payments via PayPal Here were already 10%. More importantly, customers would purchase additional products because they can pay by credit cards," said Thomas Bertrand, owner of Bento&Co, which provides stylishly designed Japanese bento boxes and kitchen utilities in a physical shop in Kyoto.

title: Clarity on our Policies: Complying with Government Regulations
content:
July 31
John Muller, PayPal General Counsel

We wanted to let you know that PayPal has recently updated how we handle payments that involve countries, companies and individuals sanctioned by one or more of the countries where we operate. 

As a global payment provider, we make every effort to comply with the laws and regulations around the world. At the same time, we are very careful to balance the need to comply with our desire to offer the best possible customer experience to everyone that uses PayPal, every day.

Before this recent change, payments that PayPal identified as potentially being in violation of government sanctions were automatically declined. We knew this was not a positive experience for our customers and we've been working hard to make this situation better.

Our new approach begins with an automated screening for payments that are possibly in violation of sanctions.  Then for most sellers, instead of automatically declining these payments, we place these transactions in pending status while our team reviews the transaction within 72 hours, less whenever possible. This review determines whether the payment has been inaccurately identified and should be processed. Today, we are trying to reduce the disruption of having payments automatically declined, and to deliver a better experience for both our consumer and merchant customers by working quickly to allow the transaction to proceed, when appropriate.

However, we understand that having a transaction held for 72 hours is still disruptive for affected customers. That is why we are continuously refining our processes and technologies to reduce the number of payments that are delayed but eventually cleared. Today, this process affects only 0.04% of payments flowing through our service, but we aim to make this even lower.

Every transaction for every one of our customers matters to us. Our goal is to deliver a seamless payments experience when our customers use PayPal – no exceptions.

We've had some recent feedback from affected customers, which I’d also like to address.  We want to be very clear - this policy was never intended to apply to informational materials like books, magazines, CDs and DVDs. While we have worked to ensure as much as possible that informational materials are not affected by our compliance with this policy, sometimes transactions involving informational materials are held pending review by mistake. This happens because it is not always easy for our automated systems to understand when a payment involves informational materials, especially when we don’t know if the seller may sell both informational materials and other items. We regret the frustration that this may cause, and are working hard to improve our systems to reduce these errors.

Francesco Rovetta, Chief Mountaineer, Summit Stories, Director of Business Development, PayPal

Kilimanjaro, the highest mountain in Africa, I’m excited to bring you news about Summit Stories, a journey across the seven continents and their highest peaks to help bring educational opportunities to underprivileged youth and local communities. The initiative was launched in 2012 with the fervent support of the eBay/PayPal community and we can’t wait to begin our next expedition.

The second Summit Stories expedition – Kili Tech Trek – is now here and I can you tell the excitement is palpable as we anticipate our climb. Joining me are technophiles from Silicon Valley, Europe and Asia as we climb Mt. Kilimanjaro to raise funds for a local non-profit (Amani Children’s Home) that supports the homeless children of Tanzania. In addition to the charitable cause, KiliTechTrek is also focusing on the use of technology by its participants before and during the trek. We are partnering with tech companies to enable Trekkers to power their devices, transfer media seamlessly, track and report their progress on social media and transfer money on the trail. As an example, we will make a donation via PayPal every day of the climb all the way to the summit!

As Chief Mountaineer at Summit Stories and Director of Business Development at PayPal I’m incredibly blessed to be making this trek with my counterparts as we ascend Africa’s highest mountain for a great charitable cause, and use the latest technologies on the way. This is an impactful story and I hope it is as inspirational for others as it is for me!

title: A Report from Softbank World Japan: New data-only phone package delivers a complete payment system in a box
content:
July 31
Elena Wise, Country Manager, Japan


Since PayPal Here started selling in SoftBank Mobile stores over a year ago, thousands of Japanese small business owners have used it to grow their sales and have provided valuable feedback to help us enhance the total customer experience.

We’ve acted on that merchant feedback.

At SoftBank World in Tokyo last week, Softbank launched a new data-only phone package that’s directly based on feedback we’ve received from our Japanese merchants. Put simply, some of them just don’t want to take payments on their personal mobile phone. No one wants to be caught deciding whether to take a payment or answer a phone call from a loved one.

The package includes an Android phone, free with contract, as well as a PayPal Here card reader, stickers, a guide book and other marketing materials to help businesses let their customers know that they take more than just cash.

The package is data only, no voice calls, and costs just JPY 1750, about $17.50 USD, per month. This is about one-third of a full-service package in Japan and offers a complete mobile POS system in a box.

We also announced that we are making our PayPal Here card reader effectively free in Japan, via a credit into a merchant’s PayPal account after their first transaction. Previously, the reader cost between JPY 1260 and JPY 1440, or $12 to $14 USD.

The combination of this great deal with SoftBank’s data-only phone package is unbeatable. We think it will disrupt the status quo in Japan. This is an industry first between a telecoms and online payment company, globally.

There is now no reason why a small business cannot increase sales by taking digital and credit card payments from their customers today.

Additionally, we announced a new partnership with Yahoo! Japan. Starting this summer, any merchant with PayPal Here will be able to easily register their shop info with Yahoo! Loco, Japan’s most popular location-based service, from within the PayPal Here app. Consumers will be able to easily find merchants that are accepting PayPal digital payments and merchants can expose their shop to millions of Yahoo! users, just when they are in the local area and looking to buy.

Softbank and PayPal are serious about bringing the future of commerce to consumers and businesses in Japan. It’s an exciting time to be at PayPal with innovation happening around the world that is truly changing how people shop and pay.

title: PayPal’s New REST APIs Available Globally
content:
Aug 01
John Lunn, Global Director, PayPal Developer Network, PayPal
Back in March, we released new REST APIs and developer tools for US developers. By building our new APIs on modern, standards-based technologies such as REST, OAuth and JSON, we’ve made it even quicker, easier and more secure for developers to integrate PayPal into their applications. The response has been terrific with more than 50,000 US developers implementing these APIs. Based on our developers’ feedback, we are now making our REST APIs available globally for anyone to integrate PayPal payments in multiple currencies.

For developers in the US, the UK and Canada only, we’ve added the capability of processing credit card transactions using the REST API. We will be spreading this functionality to other countries as soon as possible.

To get started, simply go to http://developer.paypal.com and log in with your PayPal account. You can start coding using our dynamic documentation and simple integration tools. How simple? One of our New York City Battle Hack teams had only five weeks of coding experience, and incorporated it into their application within a few hours.

As we’ve said, we will continue releasing new developer capabilities throughout the year and we encourage developers to give us feedback about these APIs via Twitter @PayPalDev. And, remember if you get stuck on anything, you can ask questions on Stack Overflow, or directly to our team of evangelists at developer@paypal.com.

title: Eelsnot, The Story of a Mobile Small Business that is using Mobile Payments to Grow
content:
July 16
Toby West, Creator of Eelsnot

Sports and payments are both pretty fast and demanding. But, ask any athlete and they’ll tell you the same- the older you get, the less mobile you are. That’s why Toby West, a skimboarder from Hawaii who now resides in Williamsburg, Virginia created Eelsnot. As he got older, he realized he wasn’t as mobile on a board as he used to be and was looking for a way to find more speed while skimboarding. He wrangled together some scientists and surfers to come up with a special, organic compound (no eels were hurt in the making of the product) that water cannot adhere to and that is applied to surf and skim boards and boats for a smoother, quicker ride. Thanks to Eelsnot, Toby who is turning 40 this year remains the East Coat’s undefeated skimboarding champion in his age group.

But being mobile in the water isn’t the only thing important to Toby. He has also taken his payments system mobile with PayPal Here. PayPal Here let’s Toby take his business out of the water and onto the road. In just two months he’s raked in about $5,000 from swiping more than 200 customer credit cards across the country at the beach, trade shows, boat shows, marinas, special events and more (and no, he does not put Eelsnot on the card reader so cards swipe faster)! He’s even started to carry a PayPal Here reader everywhere he goes and is often hailed at traffic lights by water sport enthusiasts to make a sale right out of his truck. Today, Eelsnot is available in 15 different countries and 25 different surf shops.

title: Spotlight on Erin Ozer
content:
Au 06
Erin Ozer, Creator of Knot and Bow
Sparkly cotton twine, confetti and gold stamped pencils are more than just party favors to Erin Ozer. The twenty-something turned her love for handmade products and beautiful packaging into a business that would put even the most perfectly wrapped products on Pinterest to shame. Erin’s philosophy is that modern and nostalgic and uncomplicated details make a package. We couldn’t agree more.

What is this sparkly cotton twine, exactly? It’s 2” x 4” spools of twine that Erin coined “the original Glitter Twine.” The spools are available in gold/natural and silver/natural and truly do add a metallic twist to any package. Baby shower? Wedding reception? Surprise birthday party? This Glitter Twine works on just about every package for every occasion.

Erin has been crafting and making for as long as she can remember. Art class has always been her favorite class in school and growing up, she taught at a craft camp every summer. Fast forward a few years and she is now the creative mastermind and small business owner of Knot and Bow, a Brooklyn-based stationary, packaging and party supply company. If you love confetti, arts and crafts or finding adorable ways to make presents and packages look the best, Knot and Bow is right up your alley.

She started the Knot and Bow business in 2010 and has been making confetti a must-have for any party ever since. Her business started in her own apartment, but recently moved to their own brick and mortar studio location in Gowanus, Brooklyn. She shares that her studio “quite often feels like a candy shop” with the bright colorful products scattered around. Our candy-inspired Knot and Bow favorite is the signature confetti bombs – packaged tightly in a crystal clear tube. The confetti is available in white metallic or the Knot and Bow classic party mix – both perfect for any celebration!

Erin finds inspiration in a lot of places, but mostly through her two children and living in New York. Her son’s artwork reminds Erin to loosen up and have a little fun with her business and living in New York reminds her to always keep her eyes open for new creative opportunities at every corner.

The Knot and Bow products are all available on Etsy, and PayPal is the way many of Erin’s customers purchase products. Given the Knot and Bow business is based online, Erin loves to shop online and PayPal is her go-to way to purchase items. She shares that “PayPal is so much easier than finding my credit card and typing all of those numbers!” We couldn’t agree more.

Follow Knot and Bow’s sparkly adventures on Facebook, Twitter andInstagram and start shopping using PayPal on the online store here:www.knotandbow.etsy.com.

title: One Hot New York Battle Hack
content:
July 23
John Lunn, Global Director, PayPal Developer Network, PayPal


This weekend, New York City experienced record temperatures and electricity consumption both outside and inside PayPal’s sold-out Battle Hack. Throughout 24 hours of intense coding at The Alley NYC, Battle Hack teams pounded their keyboards, feasted on NYC’s signature eats, consumed vats of caffeine, and created more than 20 applications aimed at solving problems for residents of the Big Apple.

Apps from the second of ten Battle Hacks included efforts to streamline the New York public housing repair process and a PayPal-based exchange for free parking spaces to a platform for members of the armed forces and veterans to get emotional and monetary support.

It wasn’t easy. Participants had to win over a few of the most critical judges, including Liz Crawford from Birchbox (@liscrawford), Harrison Weber from The Next Web (@HarrisonWeber), Jason Saltzman of Alley NYC (@saltzmanjason) and Jonathan Gottfried from Twilio (@jonmarkgo).

In the end, Brian Kehrer and Yosun Chang of team DeadDropAR won for their application that puts PayPal payments in both physical and artificial reality locations with virtual dead drops. The application allows a user or a business to leave money (virtually) in any location for someone to find using a mobile phone or Google Glass. The user needs to go to the location and identify the item to which the money is attached in order to pick it up. The app uses cutting edge augmented reality technology as well as PayPal to transfer the money. The judges were impressed by the implementation of so many technologies in just under 24 hours.

Last month in Berlin, Sergiej Rewiakin and Jurre Stender met for the first time, formed a team, and won for their “Clean Berlin” application. The app made finding and paying for a home clean service in Berlin simple. Clean Berlin seamlessly integrated PayPal’s iOS SDK, making it simple and easy to book someone on-demand to clean your house or apartment right from your phone.

These two amazing Berlin and NYC hack teams will be flown to our World Finals on November 16th and 17th in Silicon Valley. If you’d like a shot at representing your city, battling for your country and becoming the World’s Best Hackers--check out www.battlehack.org and sign up for a Battle Hack near you! There’s $100,000 USD and a very coveted Axe trophy waiting for you.

Also, watch our video to get some tips on "How to Survive a Battle Hack".

title: Second Quarter Update
content:
July 18
David Marcus, President, PayPal
As the founder of a number of successful startups before joining PayPal in 2011, I’ve led companies through periods of rapid and sustained growth before. It’s always exciting to rack up big increases in the key metrics you use to gauge success. But achieving impressive gains is one thing when your company is small and you’re starting from relatively small numbers. It’s another thing altogether for a global company like PayPal where we’re building off a much larger base.

So I’m very pleased to share some pretty remarkable second quarter results for PayPal. First of all, we enabled more than 700 million transactions during April, May and June. This an all-time high for the company, topping last year’s very busy holiday season. Our second quarter total payment volume climbed to $43 billion, up 25 percent on an FX neutral basis. Merchant services (off-eBay transactions) reached $30 billion, up 29 percent year-over-year. Revenue rose to $1.6 billion, a year-over-year increase of 21 percent on an FX neutral basis. We welcomed nearly 5 million new customers during the quarter, bringing total active accounts to more than 132 million.

Another number that I’m proud is year-over-year international revenue growth of 21 percent, to more than $827 million. This is a clear sign to me that our ability to deliver great experiences is resonating with customers around the globe.

While I love numbers, they don’t tell the whole story. It’s just as important to note that we’re introducing better experiences and groundbreaking technology advances at an ever-accelerating pace as we strive to continually improve the lives of our customers by delivering better, simpler financial services and products around the world.

Simply put we continue to innovate. In the UK, we introduced our new Chip & PIN PayPal Here reader. It’s already transforming the commercial lives of our first UK PayPal Here customers by making it fast and simple to accept credit card payments. By integrating PayPal with a rapidly-growing number of leading POS systems, we’re eliminating payment friction in places where people shop, dine, and fuel-up. With our brand new Cash For Registers program in the US we’re giving merchants the opportunity to move beyond the traditional cash register by using the PayPal Here and a mobile card reader to accept payments anywhere in a store.

In addition, we unveiled new checkout experiences and business servicing platforms in a number of new markets around the globe. We created a new process that makes it significantly easier for customers to recover a password that they can’t remember. And we introduced Log In with PayPal, an updated version of PayPal Access that it makes it easier, faster, and safer for consumers to log into the merchants web sites they love and complete their transactions quickly.

I’m confident that we’re in a position to sustain this level of innovation and growth for many quarters to come. So stay tuned, there’s a lot more coming as we continue to move forward.

Onward.

title: Opening Up The Digital Wallet in Australia

Jeff Clementz, Managing Director, PayPal Australia


Over the last few days, I’ve had the pleasure of hosting our Global Head of Product, Hill Ferguson, in Australia.

Hill was in Sydney to meet with local merchants, partners and in-house teams. We were pumped to have him in town especially as we have such an exciting story to tell.

Mobile is at the core of the PayPal experience. We’ve had some great early wins in mobile and we’re creating a growing number of in-store payment opportunities via the PayPal app for our five million active account holders.

The Australian team is working with local start-ups, point-of-sale providers and retailers to deliver true mobile payment innovations to what is a sophisticated and advanced mobile user base. We’re addressing real customer pain points and taking steps towards the future where a physical wallet is not required.

Last night we showcased our digital wallet offering at an event for local media.

We announced a collaboration with mobile take-away ordering site EatNow, which brings EatNow’s network of more than 2,000 take away and delivery restaurants into the PayPal app.

No more scrambling around in drawers for out-of-date and illegible paper menus. Simply log-on to the PayPal app, select your favorite local take-away restaurant and order and pay with PayPal.

Continuing with the dining theme, we announced Pay At Table on the PayPal app, which brings PayPal in to the more formal end of the restaurant industry via collaboration with OrderMate, a point-of-sale provider to more than 1,000 restaurants across the country.

Pay At Table puts an end to the back and forth that occurs at the bill payment stage of a restaurant meal. Hill Ferguson provides a great demo in the video below.

With the integration of coffee and food ordering solution, Beat The Q, PayPal customers can ‘Order Ahead’ at cafés and quick service restaurants around Australia, enabling users to order their coffees remotely with their smartphone so that they don’t have to waste time standing in line.

This is the beginning of the journey but as we continue to work in collaboration with other leading entrepreneurs and innovators of all sizes, PayPal’s mobile application will increasingly be seen as a destination for consumers to browse local businesses, order ahead and transact at point of sale.

title: PayPal Unveils Modern Spice Routes: Cross-Border Shopping Creates Economic Opportunity Worldwide
content:
July 20
David Marcus, President, PayPal

I just returned from a trip to Asia last week. Whenever I travel it always strikes me just how global the economy has become. It’s amazing how easy it has become to buy American groceries in Tokyo or this season’s Parisian fashions in Singapore. Cross border trade is nothing new, but what is a relatively new is a major global phenomena that’s growing at a staggering rate and that is people buying and paying directly from businesses half way across the world. Cross-border trade today is about a quarter of PayPal’s total payment volume and new shopping corridors are fast emerging. Our data shows that consumers in Argentina, Russia and Israel were among the top five fastest growing export markets (up to 168% year on year growth) for PayPal merchants in the largest markets worldwide last year.

We commissioned Nielsen to conduct a research study on the cross-border shopper in six key markets around the world – the United States, the United Kingdom, Germany, Australia, main land China and Brazil – to better understand their behavior and concerns. Just as the traditional spice routes created economic opportunity by connecting consumers and merchants across Europe, Africa and Asia, so too do we think these modern spice routes. It’s fascinating to see these new corridors of online trade with consumers shopping directly on overseas websites – which can be a new source of growth for today’s merchants and bring items from far-flung shores to the homes of people wherever they are. PayPal and eBay bring the opportunity to shop around the world to millions of people every day.

Our report "The Modern Spice Routes" has revealed some amazing insights that should serve as a wake-up call for businesses.

  • In the six surveyed markets, cross-border online shopping will be worth $105 billion this year with 94 million consumers regularly buying from overseas websites.

  • By 2018, this will increase nearly 200% to $307 billion with 130 million cross-border online shoppers.

  • Among those surveyed, the US (45%) is the most popular overseas market to buy from, followed by the UK (37%), mainland China (26%), Hong Kong (25%), Canada (18%), Australia (16%) and Germany (14%).

  • Top purchase categories for cross-border shoppers across these six markets in the past 12 months are: clothes, shoes and accessories ($12.5 billion); health and beauty products ($7.6 billion), personal electronics ($6.0 billion); computer hardware ($6.0 billion); jewelry, gems and watches ($5.8 billion); and home electronics ($5.4 billion).
The report also highlights:

  • 5 types of cross-border shoppers that transcend geographic and cultural barriers.

  • Top reasons for cross-border shopping and payments, as well as online safety concerns to overcome.

  • Some of those entrepreneurial merchants that are profiting today through these modern spice routes.

  • And how the future of cross-border shopping is increasingly mobile, secure and global for merchants and consumers alike
You can get a copy of our report at www.paypal.com/spiceroutes and here is a short video that brings the modern spice routes to life for both consumers and merchants all over the world.

The emergence of these "modern spice routes" is great news for businesses the world over. Our message to merchants is if you are looking for new ways to grow your sales, especially in an economic downturn, start selling directly to 94 million cross-border shoppers in these 6 markets and own a piece of this $105 billion market.

For consumers, paying for items in a different currency or country has never been easier and we make it safer with the help of our buyer protection program. Through PayPal’s own internal cross-border trade data and the research insights, we can help to connect consumers and merchants around the world in order to create more economic opportunities together.
