title: PayPal’s Bug Bounty Program: One Year Later
content:
July 25
Gus Anagnos, Director of Information Security, PayPal

As we celebrate the first anniversary of the PayPal Bug Bounty Program, we would like to thank our security research partners for their valuable contributions, which has made our program the success it is today in protecting PayPal’s customers. By flagging potential issues to us first, we can often provide fixes before anyone else is even aware. Since we started the program a year ago, we’ve had participation from hundreds of researchers across 48 countries.

We’re always looking for ways to improve our program and increase transparency with our researchers, so we have updated our Bug Bounty Terms and Conditions to address areas such as participation eligibility, payout schedules and frequently asked questions.

One of the most significant updates we’ve made to the program is that we have now found a way for younger security researchers to take part in our Bug Bounty program. We recognize that it is important to encourage research efforts from the wider security community and find ways to honor and award younger researchers. From now on, we will allow security researchers between the ages of 14 to 18 to participate and receive alternate methods of awards if they are not eligible for a PayPal account.

We’re excited to share that we also added a Wall of Fame to recognize the top 10 researchers that have either submitted the most interesting vulnerabilities, provided a high percentage of valid submissions, or identified a critical bug. We also have an honorable mention page for all the researchers that have provided valid bug submissions. We will update the list once a quarter, so please check back in regularly!

In an effort to increase transparency around our program, we’ve also updated several other areas in our Terms and Conditions. Here are some of the highlights:

  • Eligibility Requirements: We’ve provided more clarity on our traditional PayPal account payout process as well as changed our policy to provide an alternate way for those not eligible for a PayPal account to still receive an award.
  • Bounty Payments: We’ve shared which vulnerabilities are in our program’s scope and disclosing the range of payments by vulnerability types and domains. The payouts are based on a variety of risks both pertaining to the vulnerability and sites where they may be identified.
  • Responsible Disclosure Policy, Bug Submission Requirements and Guidelines: We’ve updated the policies that cover the terms of participation vital to our partnership with the research community.
  • Eligible Domains and Out of Scope Vulnerabilities: We’ve clarified which PayPal subsidiaries and partner sites are eligible for the program, as well as which vulnerabilities are out of our program’s scope.
  • Frequently Asked Questions: We’ve added this section to address many of the common inquiries to the program and we hope it serves as a useful resource when performing research activity.
We look forward to continuing to grow and improve our Bug Bounty program to help keep PayPal a safer place for our customers.

title: TSYS to Support PayPal's Physical POS Systems
content:
Aug 26
Chris Morse, Head of Merchant Communications

Since entering a service provider relationship with Discover, we at PayPal have seen many wonderful things come to fruition. Most recently this includes expansion via Total System Services (TSYS), which today announced the ability to process payment transactions within the contiguous United States.

In other words, many more consumers are now able to take advantage of an enhanced payment experience: a single source to access credit or debit cards, bank accounts, PayPal balances, or Bill Me Later payment methods at a point-of-sale terminal.

“We are extremely pleased to support PayPal’s expansion into more physical merchant locations,” said Mark Pyke, president of TSYS’ Merchant Services segment. “We believe PayPal provides merchants and consumers more choices and helps reach new consumers at the point of sale, relying on our robust payment transaction processing platforms, as well as other value-added products and services. We anticipate the addition of PayPal as an added benefit to both merchants and consumers.”

In addition to augmenting the accessibility of our services, today’s announcement buttresses the goal of becoming much more than just a way to pay online. With the help of our partners we’re bringing the seamlessness of digital experience to the physical world, and enabling our merchants a way to provide a more convenient, personal and, most importantly, more fun way of shopping has been a wholly satisfying experience.

Here’s to many more!

title: Customer First: The PayPal Way
content:
Aug 28
David Marcus, President, PayPal

Last year when I began to lead the team at PayPal, it was clear to me that although we were a strong and thriving company with great promise, our laser-focus on scaling the business, and keeping it compliant in the complex world of payments had taken precedence over our customers’ experiences for too long.

This was brought home to me in the following months as the media were quick in reacting to the mistakes we were making and we heard in real time from our customers about their issues directly through social media channels. It was clear that something was broken, and it needed to get fixed.

Here’s what we’re doing at PayPal to get this stuff fixed:

My leadership team committed to making a difference as soon as possible, in the ways that mattered to our customers.  The only way to do that with any effect, any impact, was to listen. We spent hours on live calls with our customers at our Customer Service Centers, hearing their challenges and frustrations first-hand. We watched and listened to the feedback we were getting and responded when we could. We asked our friends, cousins and babysitters, suppliers and even strangers what we could do to make PayPal great.

And we never ever, ever lost sight of the fact that we look after people’s money – we have a great responsibility to keep funds safe and protected from the bad guys – no one does this at the scale we do, in the number of countries we operate in, dealing with the number of regulators we have.  We know how very, very important and very personal money is to our customers.

It was time to re-focus and commit in a new way, with a fresh perspective. We worked quickly to fix issues we knew of and could solve for, while at the same time:

  • We doubled down on creating beautiful products that leverage our technological leadership
  • We used a true “mobile first” approach that shows off our ability to create cut-through UI design to make payments simple
  • We categorized known “pain points” so we could check them off and make a real difference in the lives of our customers
We call this Customer First.

The essence of this initiative is a combined effort across multiple functions in our business to stay focused more than ever on our core audiences of merchants, consumers, and developers, their needs and desires. We genuinely believe that our end-to-end product experience, from the first time you interact with us, to when you call us with a concern or question is who we are – it’s our community.

Nothing gives us more joy than when a merchant comes online and is able to accept payments and build a business within minutes because of the care we took to make it possible. Nothing gives us more delight than when a busy mom tells us she paid her sitter with PayPal because she didn’t have time to stop at the ATM.  That’s why we do this.

Taking Action

We launched a set of initiatives to tackle known customer issues head on. Our teams in Risk Management, Customer Service, Legal and, of course, our Global Product and Technology teams banded together to help solve pain points no matter where you are in the world.  We put new procedures in place, used every day by everyone at PayPal.

Proudly Use PayPal Every Day:  Employees all over the company – from San Jose to Australia – use our products every day.   We iterate quickly, when our people give us feedback.  We tested new products to get our coffee at the office café, we Order Ahead lunch at our company cafeteria and pay vendors using PayPal. We challenge our employees to be brutal in feedback so we can truly understand what our customer wants and needs. We’ve taken that a step further by transforming the look and feel of our offices, starting at our headquarters in San Jose, so we can collaborate quickly and refine our products at the pace required to keep our customers satisfied. No more high walls or siloed spaces – we’ve literally knocked down the barriers to our workplace to stay nimble and stay connected.

Listening. Hearing. Responding: Our operations teams are tremendous internal advocates for our customers. They identified a set of complex customer pain points in multiple areas based on internal research and direct feedback from our customers, and I’m happy to say that so far we’ve solved more than half of these top issues. As a result so far in 2013, we’ve tracked 40 million fewer issues that customers have experienced than last year.

Be The Customer: Because nothing compares to real conversation, real experiences, and real lives when you’re making decisions for your customers, we ask Directors and above to spend a week on the front lines at our call centers to hear and deal with issues first hand. When someone gets promoted, or joins the company at that level, they receive an invitation to go spend a week in one of our centers, and we’re relentless in ensuring all of them go. It’s a transformational experience that is changing our culture.

Take “Risks”: That might sound a little contradictory. Being the leader in online payments makes us a prime target for all the bad guys around the world. Over the years we had to build our industry-leading Risk Management technologies. We’ve been able to scale a rate that cannot be replicated by anyone else, and sometimes it’s left customers feeling less than satisfied. Of the more than 7.5 million transactions we do every day, the vast majority go through without an issue. We’ve tweaked our models to catch more bad guys and way fewer good guys. Hundreds of thousands of customers who may have experienced holds last year based on our policies are no longer impacted and we’re seeing some recognition of that work - with a notable increase in our Net Promoter Score, an industry measurement of brand loyalty. We’ve also adjusted policies specifically around holds to demonstrate that we trust our customers as much as they trust us. Simply put, we’ve built, and are continuing to build a better net. Fewer dolphins, more sharks!

Be Human: Policies, laws and regulations are black and white. We have to be compliant with government and regulatory agencies, that’s just part of doing business as a leader in global payments. But we’ve made some tweaks to our policies and procedures and introduced some guiderails to better help you when there are issues. For example, when dealing with alleged counterfeit goods, we now give the benefit of the doubt to the seller while making sure the buyer is not penalized, sometimes taking a loss to ensure a smooth customer experience for everyone involved. For small claims we instituted a “no fault construct” when there is a buyer complaint so that we now simply absorb this cost. This program benefits tens of thousands of sellers and buyers each month. PayPal will absorb $2.5 million a year to provide this benefit to our buyers and sellers.

Customer First. The PayPal Way.

We’re making a commitment to making PayPal great, and to make it more customer-centric so that people love our products every single day.  Now and in the future.

When PayPal launched 15 years ago it fundamentally changed the way commerce is conducted. It literally opened the doors of millions businesses all over the world to millions more consumers in every corner of the globe. And today, there are businesses that simply wouldn’t have existed without us. They wouldn’t have been able to accept payments online, wouldn’t have built innovative businesses unique to the Internet we know today, wouldn’t have been able to provide for their families. We take that promise and that legacy very seriously.

We are making huge progress in reinventing the experience for our customers. But we’re not quite there yet. We won’t be satisfied until all of our customers, consumers, businesses, and developers alike, come away from every interaction with their PayPal with the feeling that we’ve helped them in a transparent and valuable way. PayPal should be synonymous with putting the Customer First. That’s the PayPal Way.

I will keep you up to date on our progress. We have so much more to share, so much more to do. I look forward to your feedback and comments.

And please be sure to reach out to us when you encounter a problem – we’re here to fix it! Contact our Customer Service team @AskPayPal on Twitter any time.

Onward.

title: PayPal Beacon: Finally an Easier Way to Pay in Stores Than Swiping a Credit Card
content:
Sep 09
David Marcus, President, PayPal


At PayPal, we’re passionate about opportunities to bring greater convenience, value, and fun to people’s lives by building beautiful products that make the payment part of shopping simpler, faster, and a whole lot richer. The new PayPal app is a great example of how we’re helping to solve everyday problems that consumers and merchants struggle with today, even as we deliver exciting new shopping experiences for tomorrow.

Now, instead of finishing a meal at a restaurant by waiting for the server to run your credit card, and then finally return it for your signature, you can simply pay using your PayPal app and leave when you’re ready. And, instead of waiting in a line to pick up and pay for your takeout order, you can order ahead through our new app to skip the line altogether.

But this is just the beginning.

We challenged ourselves to find a better experience than swiping a credit card. And that’s hard. No one wakes up in the morning and thinks, “I wish someone invented something better than swiping a card to pay. I hate it.” We figured the only better way to pay would be to do nothing. Just walk in a store, and, like magic, when you’re ready to pay, money is transferred securely. We played with geo-location leveraging GPS and WiFi. We played with geo-fences in iOS. But, none of these solutions met our standards.

Traditional geo-location requires phone signal and good data throughput to offer a great experience, the indoor resolution isn’t good enough, and keeping it on at all times significantly reduces battery life. Geo-fencing can only be used with a limited number of locations.

So, we started looking at Bluetooth Low Energy, otherwise known as BLE. BLE is a breakthrough technology that will enable connected devices to communicate with each other seamlessly, while keeping the energy consumption at a very low level. The team started working on designing an integrated solution that would enable a transaction to take place without having to open up an app, without GPS being turned on, and even without a phone signal for those places with thick concrete walls (those of you who live in the UK know what I mean).

Today, I’m very excited to unveil PayPal Beacon. This technology is our most significant contribution to date in reinventing the in-store shopping experience. Beacon is a new add-on technology for merchants that will enable consumers to pay at their favorite stores completely hands-free. Consumers will have full control of stores they will want to check in to, those they will want to get prompted to confirm payment for, and stores they will want to enable a complete hands-free experience for. In the latter case, simply walking in a store will trigger a vibration or sound to confirm a successful check in (this happens in milliseconds), your photo will then appear on the screen of the Point-of-Sale system so you can be greeted by name. Paying only requires a verbal confirmation, and you’re done. No wallet. No card. Nothing to do. Not even touching your phone.

Any store running Point-of-Sale systems compatible with PayPal, including Booker, Erply, Leaf, Leapset, Micros, NCR, PayPal Here, Revel, ShopKeep, TouchBistro and Vend, and many more soon, will simply plug a PayPal Beacon device in a power outlet in their store. Once the Beacon is plugged in, they will be ready to offer the best, most personal shopping experience ever.

We value our customers’ privacy, so PayPal Beacon won’t constantly track your location like other technologies. If you enter a store and decline to check in, or just ignore the prompt entirely, no information is transmitted to PayPal or the merchant.

We’re opening up opportunities for retailers and developers.

With the introduction of PayPal Beacon, I believe we’re opening the door to a fundamentally different way to use technology to make shopping richer and more valuable for consumers and merchants alike. That’s why I’m excited to share the news that we’re giving developers access to the PayPal mobile in-store API to create experiences such as being able to self-checkout on your mobile phone or automatically placing a customer’s usual order as soon as they walk through the door. Take a look at the videos below to see how it works and to get inspired. Developers can submit their ideas at www.paypal.com/beacon for a chance to be chosen as one of the 100 developers that get access to the API and a free developer version of the PayPal Beacon device before we roll this out.

We’ll start piloting Beacon-enabled shopping experiences in Q4, and the full rollout is planned early next year.

I, for one, can’t wait to see what developers do with PayPal Beacon once they get their hands on it. For a chance to be chosen as one of the developers to experiment with PayPal’s mobile in-store API and the PayPal Beacon device, just visit www.paypal.com/beacon to submit your ideas. This is also the place to go for anyone who is interested in learning more about this great new technology, or signing up to receive updates on when it will be available to everyone.

The future of in-store payments is finally here. Now it’s time to start rolling it out and delighting millions of customers around the world.

title: Paying With Your Phone has Never Been So Easy – Or Looked So Good
content:
Sep 05
Hill Ferguson, Chief Product Officer, PayPal

Ugh, I don’t have any cash. Whoops, I left my wallet at home. S#4% my credit card has expired!

Those thoughts used to mean lost time, a trip back home, inconvenience and a raging headache. Not having an ability to pay when out in the world is limiting, to say the least. That’s why more and more of us (nearly 400 million consumers according to Juniper Research) are turning to our mobile phones to make purchases.

Today we’re launching our completely reimagined PayPal app on iPhone and Android, so our customers can leave the raging headache at home and just get what they want, when they want it.

With the new design of the app, we’ve made it easier than ever for our customers to pay when they’re in-store and send money to friends (that reminds me, I owe David $3 for that latte). Of course, because we’re PayPal, paying with your phone doesn’t mean you have to give up choice. We have made it even easier to pay using your bank account in one store and your credit card at the next place. In this release, you can even open a line of credit in the app using Bill Me Later.

We’ve also vastly improved the in-store shopping experience. The PayPal app has a new tab called ‘Shop’, which you can use to find shops or restaurants nearby that accept PayPal payments. You can then 'check in' and open a tab with just a swipe. You can change how you want to pay right on the "check in" screen, meaning you’ve really got access to your entire wallet in the app. After you’ve paid, you’ll see a confirmation alert and our usual PayPal email receipt. Check out this video, which shows how simple it really is:

Thousands of restaurants, cafes, clothing stores and other retail locations in the US, UK, Australia, Japan, Hong Kong and Canada now allow shoppers to pay just using their mobile phones.

The new app is delivering on the promise to help consumers get the most of their money, on their terms, in a way that no one else can.>

Order Ahead

The minutes you spend standing in line can now be spent on chatting with your family or getting back to work on time. By checking in on the PayPal app, you can order ahead (from the full menu!) and bypass the line at local restaurants and cafes. Starting today, you can order ahead at more than a thousand Eat24 locations, with more restaurants and cafes coming soon.

Pay at Table

Forget having to wait for the server to run your card or give you change. You can check-in to view your bill, give a tip and pay your restaurant bill through the PayPal app. You can even order another drink from the app at some locations.

Offers

Instead of thinking about that stack of paper coupons in your desk drawer at home, the new app has the offer waiting in your wallet the second you stepped into the store. Starting today, $100 in offers is available in your PayPal app from local US businesses. You can save the offers to your PayPal wallet and they are automatically redeemed at checkout.

Credit Line Built In

For the first time, you can apply to finance your PayPal purchases from inside the app by selecting the Bill Me Later option. You also have the opportunity to get flexible financing and promotional offers such as "six months to pay on purchases of $99 or more" from participating PayPal retailers.

So give it a try and tell us what you think. Download it on your iPhone or Android smartphone and check it out. It’s available in nearly 125 markets around the world starting today.

Great food and some fun perks kept everyone focused, but when the developers weren't coding, conversations quickly moved to how they believe our society will soon become cardless as part of their effort to create an app to solve a local issue.

Consumers can pick up the cash at a shop, a home, or just about anywhere. The app helps local business by keeping dollars within the community. It charges the consumer $1 per transaction, which is dramatically lower than most ATM fees.

title: Closed Loop Offers Save Money for Consumers and Drive Commerce for Merchants
content:
Sep 06
Patrick Gauthier, Head of Emerging Retail Services, PayPal


When we look at new technology at PayPal we’re interested in one thing: does it actually solve a problem for either a consumer or a business? We’re not interested in technology for technology’s sake, but rather those solutions that drive more sales and customers for merchants and save time and money for consumers.

When we looked at the current state of “offers” we saw a lot of problems. Many consumers equate offers with spam—they’re not easy to redeem, and often people simply just forget to bring them along when they’re actually going to a store. As a consequence, offers perform unevenly for merchants. That’s why we’re so excited to share a fantastic new feature called a Closed Loop Offer (CLO) that will change the way people shop and buy.

Closed Loop Offers by PayPal, are simply smarter offers.

Closed Loop Offers are smarter for merchants accepting PayPal, in how they enable them to put real money into a PayPal user’s account to be spent at their sites and stores. Offers are distributed through digital media placements (online, email, mobile) or placed directly into the user’s PayPal account. Redemption can be omni-channel (e.g. both in-store and online to provide flexibility and choice to the consumer) or designed to drive sales in one particular channel. CLOs can be targeted based on a number of criteria, including PayPal’s proprietary segmentation models, or by channel, geography, and day parts. Better still, the merchant doesn’t need to change anything about their marketing or payment infrastructure. And once a CLO campaign is complete, full funnel metrics from ad impressions to the transaction-enabling measurement of return on investment are provided to the merchant. In short, Closed Loop Offers give merchants and brands a treasure trove of options to reach PayPal’s 55 million US customers.

Closed Loop Offers are also smarter for consumers because they are relevant. These offers, they can actually use. They’re smarter offers because once they’re saved into a PayPal wallet, the consumer can forget about them. They’ll be alerted when the offer is about to expire and the discount is automatically applied at the time of purchase, not as a statement of credit weeks later.

Simply put, CLOs enable consumers to get offers they will care about and merchants to get pre-qualified prospects. When you combine this capability with that of the PayPal Media Network, including geo-fencing and context targeting, the result is connecting consumers and merchants in a personal and effective way that drives engagement, loyalty and sales. This is the power of Connected Commerce.

PayPal has a rich history of solving commerce challenges—beginning with pioneering a secure online payment platform, for example, and more recently, by taking the pain out of settling the bill at a restaurant with view, tip, and pay technology.

An easier and better shopping experience for both customers and merchants is what we’re after. Closed Loop Offers provide retailers with an effective tool to acquire and connect with customers on a whole new level, as well as drive repeat patronage of those same customers. And they’ll give shoppers the savings they want while avoiding offer clutter and wasting valuable time.

For more information on Closed Loop Offers, visit: http://advertising.paypal.com

title: PayPal and Crowdfunding
content:
Sep 11
Tomer Barel, Chief Risk Officer, PayPal

You might have seen some press articles over the last few days about PayPal limiting the accounts of a few crowdfunding campaigns.

Crowdfunding sites are an exciting and innovative new way to directly connect entrepreneurs with the people who want to help them create new products and services. However, there are unique regulatory and risk aspects inherent to this new way to raise money from supporters around the world. To name one, we sometimes hear from campaign contributors that they are confused about what exactly their money is going towards, and assume that they’ll get it back if the venture is not successful.

Because the model is so new, it is potentially open to abuse. PayPal has a responsibility to ensure that the system remains secure, in compliance with Government regulations around the world, and that consumers who contribute to these campaigns understand where their money is going.

Some of PayPal's competitors solve this by simply refusing to allow their payment systems to be used at all for crowdfunding. We don't believe that's the right approach because, when done right, crowdfunding is a powerful catalyst for innovation. However, it's clear that our existing policies and processes aren’t working quite right for this particular fundraising model.

We are now in the midst of overhauling our policies in this space. We're talking to the major crowdfunding players that we work with to put in place a permanent solution that avoids unnecessary account limitations. But making this work for all stakeholders – contributors, entrepreneurs, crowdfunding sites and us -- is pretty complicated. As soon as I have more to share, I promise to update everyone.

In the meantime, we will ensure that each crowdfunding campaign is reviewed by a senior member of my team before any action is taken. It’s a small, but important step.

PayPal's very essence is connecting buyers and sellers. The last thing we want to do is get in the way of the innovative new products coming from entrepreneurs raising money via crowdfunding.

We never forget that we are looking after other people's money. The customer-first approach is the essence of what our president David Marcus wrote in a recent post to this blog, and we have a responsibility to keep funds safe and protected. No one does this at the scale we do, in the number of countries we operate in, and with the number of regulators we have.

We're making changes every day to get this right, but if anyone is having an outstanding issue with PayPal for a crowdfunding effort, here is my direct email: tbarel@paypal.com. 

Thank you, 

Tomer Barel 

VP Risk Management, PayPal

title: Building a Business with PayPal: A Q&A with ‘Suitcase Entrepreneur’ Natalie Sisson
content:
Sep 11
Chelsi Nakano, Content Manager, PayPal

It’s probably safe to say that nobody has a résumé quite like Natalie Sisson. After a life of body sculpting competitions, TV presenting, triathlons and even Moto-x racing, Natalie made a sharp turn towards the world of entrepreneurship and has since built her career with a combination of modern business savvy and a serious sense of adventure.

As a triple citizen with a never-ending case of wanderlust, she operates almost entirely from the road, demonstrating both a brave new world of possibilities and the power of today’s tools. Naturally, we were delighted to learn that she chose PayPal to manage the financial end of her initiatives.

The story of her online business journey can be found in her new book, The Suitcase Entrepreneur, and we were lucky enough to be able to speak with her about why PayPal remains the best option for those looking to follow in her footsteps.

Why did you choose PayPal over other options, such as Google Checkout and Amazon Payments?

When I left New Zealand to travel the world I realized I needed an online payment solution where I could send and receive money in a large number of currencies without having to worry about bank charges or international complexities. PayPal spoke to every concern I had at the time about how to manage my finances, and when I started my online business it seemed like the most obvious solution to be able to charge in one currency for my products and services and receive funds from almost anywhere around the world. I also liked that I could clearly see all transactions online and manage my finances, as well as the level of fees I was accountable for. Plus PayPal was the most widely accepted form of payment solution online.

I became particularly enamoured when I cofounded my first technology company and we built our FundRazr app on Facebook on top of the PayPal app. This is when I started to really get a better understanding of what PayPal offered.

Would all of that still apply if you started your business today rather than years ago?

I think there are a lot more choices nowadays in terms of payment platforms but for me personally I’ve still not found a solution that works in with my personal situation so well. As someone with multiple citizenships and bank accounts I still find PayPal is the most universal payments platform I can use.

Further, merchant accounts can take a ton of work to set up and a lot of paperwork, but my PayPal Pro Flow account gives me the same flexibility as a merchant account. What’s more is that people trust PayPal and it’s far more likely they have a PayPal account to use so I can naturally work with a broader range of international clients and customers.

Most of my vendors these days invoice me via PayPal and I pay my team via PayPal too. It’s my global online bank.

What do you think it is about PayPal that is specifically appealing to entrepreneurs today?

I think it’s the fact that you can access PayPal online, through your mobile device and have so much functionality at your fingertips. I can literally run my entire business with a website and a PayPal button. Or I can turn my phone into a merchant terminal with PayPal Here.

As someone who generally speaks to PayPal’s digital strengths, what do you think of our latest efforts to build a physical presence?

I think it’s a good thing to establish your physical presence and prove to those people who still believe their bricks and mortar bank is more secure than your virtual online payments platform. By being physically present and having people to explain your products and services it makes you real and tangible. It allows people to interact with your solutions in an environment where they can touch, see and feel you first, and then carry on that goodwill and experience to the online environment with a greater understanding of what you do and why that matters.

As an entrepreneur working with a number of inexpensive tools, which PayPal integrations have you found to be most helpful?

For me I saw the added value when I started to notice that PayPal was widely accepted and integrated with many of the online tools and software programs I was using including e-Junkie, WordPress and oDesk.

That felt incredibly liberating as it meant I could run my business seamlessly with my PayPal account and not to have set up a new way to get paid each time.

When I switched to a business account I immediately started using the increased functionality like subscriptions and recurring payments, which expanded my business offerings even further. I use these more than any other functionality within PayPal.

What has surprised you the most about PayPal’s offerings?

I was surprised to find that PayPal offered a merchant account setup when I was investigating how to get one. I guess I always saw PayPal as the easiest way to send and receive money online, not as a fully-fledged solution.

Any last words for entrepreneurs considering their payment options?

At the end of the day you have to choose the payment solution that's going to fit your local and global needs. I'd choose one that's constantly pushing the boundaries to offer more flexibility and ease of options, the highest level of security, online and mobile access, as well as competitive fees.

title: PayPal Goes Live with 13 Merchants in Russia
content:
Sep 17
Laurent Le Moal , General Manager – Continental Europe, Middle East and Africa

Today in Moscow, 13 of Russia’s biggest names in online commerce announced that they would start accepting payments from customers using PayPal.

The list provides a variety of shopping opportunities across all verticals that are important to Russian consumers. From every day purchases to special high ticket items, we’re delighted to have these merchants as our launch partners. Take a look:

  • Online hypermarkets, Ozon.ru and Enter.ru
  • Designer furniture and accessories from Westwing
  • Travel from Tutu.ru and Anywayanyday.ru
  • Russia's largest online store for clothes, shoes and accessories inLaModa.ru
  • Fashion from MyWalit.ru
  • Food delivery from Utkonos.ru
  • Kitchen appliances from Holodilnuik.ru
  • Cellphone and consumer electronics with Svyaznoy
  • Emex.ru sells auto goods and parts
  • Biglion, the leader in coupons, providing discounts for many great services
  • KupiVip provides 90% discounts on online shopping. 
This is a major milestone in our efforts to bring the security and convenience of PayPal to one of the world’s fastest growing ecommerce markets.

According to a study by McKinsey & Company, there were 70 million people online in Russia in 2012, already the largest online community in Europe and growing at 35% each year. They also report people in Russia made $13bn in online purchases in 2011, which is expected to grow to $25bn by 2014.

The Russian people are eager to shop online. The problem so far has been doing so easily and safely. In a society dominated by cash we are excited to solve some of the friction points in paying online for the things you want.

It has been possible to open a PayPal account in Russia for a few years, but only to pay in US dollars. Despite that, three million people in Russia have registered for an account and over one million are using PayPal actively. Our internal data shows Russia is already one of the fastest growing export opportunities for merchants in countries like Brazil, the UK, Germany and China. The more people in Russia that used PayPal, the more we kept hearing they wanted to be able to pay in rubles. We listened and took action!

In May 2013 we were granted a license by the Central Bank of Russia, taking the total number of currencies we support to 26 and opening the doors to safer ecommerce in Russia.

We’ve been enthusiastically received.

Our reputation for successfully handling $145bn in online transactions in 2012, the fact that our payment platform spans 193 markets, and that our world-class fraud detection systems identify many criminals before anyone becomes a victim, provide the reassurance so far missing for Russian online shoppers.

That’s why 13 merchants stood on stage today to talk about how excited they were to be offering PayPal payments to their customers.

And we’re just getting started.  

We’ll be announcing many more merchants in the coming months and toward the end of the year we’ll start bringing smaller merchants on board.

According to the companies on stage in Moscow, the launch of PayPal marks the coming of age of online commerce in Russia. We can’t wait to see how the market develops and we’ll be ready to introduce more innovation when the time is right. For now, Russia is open for business.

title: Causes We Love: Pencils of Promise
content:
Sep 17
Clam Lorenz, Director, Nonprofit Engagement, PayPal

Pencils of Promise is a non-profit organization that works diligently to increase educational opportunities in the developing world. Recently, I sat down with Carlo Dumandan, the org’s Digital Media Manager, to discuss these efforts and how PayPal helps along the way. 

Tell us a little about Pencils of Promise. 

Pencils of Promise started a little under 5 years ago with $25 and a dream. Our CEO & Founder, Adam Braun, started with an initial goal of just building one school to dedicate to his grandmother. Since then, we’ve built over 150 schools in Laos, Nicaragua, Guatemala and Ghana, and are implementing educational programs such student progression scholarships, lessons on sanitation & hygiene and teacher training to provide quality education to our students as well. 

What makes Pencils of Promise unique? 

One thing that is incredibly important to us is dedication from the communities in which we work. We require that they contribute at least 10-20% of the build and it usually comes in the form of labor or materials. We work with communities that truly want a school for their children. In Ghana, for example, PoP school builds have 4x the number of volunteers participating in the construction process than is mandated. 

Our business model is based on for-profit business acumen and non-profit ideals, which is different from most in the space. We’re a nonprofit with a true focus on efficiency and data measurement - we have an entire department and system dedicated to measuring the effectiveness of our work. The quality of our programs we deliver on the ground is a lot more important to us than increasing our school count. 

What are some of your biggest challenges in getting support? 

Since we are working in the developing world, many of our supporters don’t get to experience the impact they helped create first-hand which is why social media is incredibly important to us. Social media helps us bridge this gap and allow us to share photos, videos, and stories of the impact we are collectively creating as a global community.

How does Pencils of Promise currently use PayPal and why did you choose us over other payment platforms? 

We use PayPal as our main payment processor for our donations page on our website PencilsofPromise.org. For any company transacting payments online, security is key. PayPal is a trusted payment processor with relatively low processing fees, which is a major win for any nonprofit. 

How can others get involved in Pencils of Promise’s cause?

We actually just launched our Back to School campaign on August 13th. Through this campaign, we hope to raise $500,000 to fund 5,000 student scholarships, which will allow primary school students to progress to secondary school. In our partner communities, about half of students don’t have what they need to progress forward in their education. A PoP scholarship covers all the basic necessities in order to make a seamless transition to secondary school: school fees, a backpack and supplies, and a uniform.

This initiative is super exciting for us because these scholarships are awarded to students who are working hard in school and truly deserve them.  

You can find out more at http://pencilsofpromise.org/backtoschool

Would you recommend PayPal to another nonprofit? Why? 

Yes, definitely. PayPal has a wonderful customer support team and integrates seamlessly with our CRM, Salesforce. We’ve never had an issue with your service!

title: Introducing PayPal Working Capital: A Faster and Easier Way to Fund Growing Businesses
content:
Sep 24
Darrell Esch, VP and GM, SMB Lending, PayPal
Small businesses across America are constantly under pressure and face intense competition. Many need additional capital to grow or sell more so they can better compete and succeed, but it’s no secret in the small business community that securing capital is difficult. According to a report released in August by The Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, the total value of small business loans in the fourth quarter of 2012 was 78 percent less than in the second quarter in 2007.

Today we are pleased to share PayPal Working Capital, an innovative way for PayPal customers to fund their growing businesses. For the first time, select PayPal businesses will have access to a business loan that allows them to get funding in minutes once they apply, review and agree to terms. And it allows them to repay with a share of their sales and know they’re paying for the loan with one, affordable fixed fee. From September 24 through December 31, 2013 select PayPal businesses in the United States will be offered an exclusive release of PayPal Working Capital, which is issued by the lender, WebBank.

PayPal Working Capital is available to select businesses that already process payments with PayPal. And it’s simple:

  • It’s a business loan that enables PayPal merchants to repay the loan with a share of their PayPal sales, so there are no minimum monthly payments. If you have no sales on a particular day, you owe no payments for that day.

  • Select PayPal merchants can apply online, review and agree to the terms of the business loan and if approved, get funding into their PayPal account in minutes.

  • Pricing is simple and clear. The loan is available for a single, fixed fee that is displayed to a business before signing up. There are no periodic interest charges, late fees, pre-payment fees, or any other fees, so a merchant knows what they’ll pay, down to the penny.

  • Under the PayPal Working Capital program, the lender uses PayPal sales history to extend credit, so no credit check is required and the loan does not affect a business’s credit score.
PayPal’s strategy is focused on providing simple access to funding for small businesses, and we have a strong relationship with our business customers. The lender WebBank will make credit decisions based on our customers’ PayPal sales history. Decision-making and funding loans will be faster than alternative sources would be and, more importantly, the loan offers greater degrees of flexibility and transparency.

We are constantly listening to and engaging with small businesses so we can help them solve problems and sell more. PayPal reached out to the SMB community including a survey of 1,000 PayPal small businesses who conveyed their frustration with the current lending system and the need for more options. This is how PayPal Working Capital was born.

PayPal Working Capital enables small businesses to easily scale to meet seasonal demands, and seize new business opportunities when they arise. For example, PayPal merchants can easily access funds they need to expand inventory and increase their staffs to gear up for busy times such as the fast-approaching holiday season.

PayPal has been committed to small businesses since we pioneered online shopping nearly 15 years ago and helped to open the doors of millions of businesses worldwide. PayPal Working Capital is an extension of this commitment and one we’re extremely proud to introduce.

title: Good Storytelling and Good Food are Keys to Small Business Success
content:
Sep 18
Martha Cass, Global Communications, PayPal

I just came back from a summer cross-country road trip with my family. We are Canadian and it was a great way to show my three boys their amazing country. But, as you probably know – Canada is BIG – which means a lot of time in the car. Did I mention the part about having three boys with us?

We spent a lot of time listening to audio books during the long drives (the Audible app is amazing). The boys were captivated and I was reminded about the power of a great story.

Small Business and Storytelling

If you are a small business owner, you have great stories to share with the world. The story behind why your business exists, who you are as a business owner, how you first came up with your product idea, the lessons you’ve learned along the way and what you do to delight your customers every day are great stories and can be powerful marketing tools. At their heart, great stories are about connecting the writer and the reader emotionally – and small business owners know that creating an emotional connection with their customers can be a great competitive advantage.

Small business owners today have more ways than ever to tell their stories to customers. Social media has given them that perfect podium, which is both affordable and has broad reach.

The Story of Caplansky's Deli

A great example of an entrepreneur who has built his company successfully with storytelling is Zane Caplansky, owner of Caplansky’s Deli in Toronto. Zane’s business started 5 years ago with a craving for a great sandwich and is now an incredibly successful Jewish deli brand including a bustling downtown restaurant, food truck, catering business and a soon-to-launch packaged goods line selling in grocery stores across the country.

“My dream was to bring great Jewish deli food back to Toronto,” he said. I started making the Jewish handmade, homemade food that that my grandmother Thelma made for me.”

Part of the reason that Zane was able to turn his dream into a reality is that he told his story to everyone who would listen and through all the tools at his disposal – Twitter, Facebook and his blog. He even put his personal email address on the restaurant’s menus to start personal conversations with his customers about Jewish food and their experiences in his restaurant. It worked. 

“On social media [platforms] and when I talk to customers I’m always saying that I love food and believe in its power to bring people together and help them celebrate the special moments in their lives. I believe great food builds strong communities. Whether I’m promoting a contest between grandmothers to see who can make the best matzoh ball or hosting a traditional Jewish dinner at the restaurant for people who have never tried Jewish food – I’m telling my story about food and people coming together. This is why people say they feel a connection with my business and why my business has grown. Of course, the food is amazing too.”

Beyond social media, Zane has also been featured in the press on many occasions and appeared in numerous reality television shows about his business and his passion for food. He’s even been the star of a PayPal video about his business. You can check it out below to see a master storyteller at work!

title: My PayPal Moment
content:
Sep 20
Jennifer Hakes , Director, Corporate Communications, PayPal

When I started working at PayPal just about three years ago, I have to admit, I wasn't what they would call a "power user." Sure, I was extremely familiar with the brand, I trusted it as a form of payments online and when I said that I was going to work for PayPal, people were impressed and excited.

But over my time here, I've become a true believer – and not just because they sign my paycheck. Because I had a moment.


Navigating Convenience

One of the challenges my colleagues and I find when trying to communicate the value of PayPal to our consumers is that there are SO many everyday features an average consumer could use: you can split the check with friends from the PayPal mobile app (there's a new one – check it out!), pay your babysitter with a credit card using PayPal Here, or pay back your mom for that group gift for dad. You can do this from your desk, your phone, or on the beach. The possibilities and potential for making your life easier are literally limitless, making tough to pick just one to demonstrate value.

So I started asking my friends and family the same question: “What was your PayPal Moment?” They initially stared back at me blankly, but once I clarified – “What was the moment where you realized that PayPal made your life better, easier and you didn't want to live without it?" – the light bulb turned on and people got excited. And they each had a different answer.

My dad: "I've been eyeing that computer for your mom for too long, so I bit the bullet and used BillMeLater. It was so easy – maybe too easy. Now I'm looking for my next big online purchase!"

My mom: "Oh, honey, you know I use PayPal several times a week to keep up with my eBay addiction. Please call me more often."

My best friend: "I paid most of my wedding vendors with PayPal and it was awesome."


Lonely Carts

My own moment was similar in simplicity and I feel very common, but nonetheless transformative.

I was on the couch after a long day at the office (insert tiny violin here) surfing on my iPad. I’d just discovered a new site for furniture, décor and travel accessories, and was obsessing over a certain clock. As I started to make the purchase, I realized they didn't take PayPal. The couch was so comfortable I didn’t want to get up and get my credit card, so I abandoned the cart.

I still think about that clock, but I've never looked back. Nowadays, comfy couch or no comfy couch, I don’t pay for anything online unless PayPal is accepted.

It will continue to be a challenge to tell consumers why they should use PayPal every day in multiple ways, but to me that's a good problem to have. Every second is a new opportunity to prove that our platform can be what you want when you need it – secure, flexible, easy to use and transformative. Just give yourself a moment to discover why.

However, I just realized that my PayPal Moment just revealed me as a total sloth. I need to hit the gym.

What was your PayPal Moment?

title: Why We've Agreed to Acquire Braintree
content:
Sep 26
David Marcus, President, PayPal
I came to PayPal and eBay Inc. in 2011 via the acquisition of Zong because it offered the best opportunity to achieve the goal I’ve been working toward for more than 15 years: to use the power of digital technology to transform the world of payments. I’ve always believed that if we can make transactions safer and easier, we’ll unlock value and convenience that we can only imagine today.

Over the past year and a half, we’ve worked hard at PayPal to put this idea into practice. We’re delivering beautiful products that make shopping faster, simpler, and more fun. We’re introducing innovative technologies that enable businesses to thrive in an increasingly mobile world. We’re providing tools to help developers create compelling new experiences that connect merchants with their customers in entirely new ways.

A lot of other companies claim they’re doing these things, too. But in the crowded payments space, most have a long way to go before they actually deliver useful solutions at the scale that’s required.

One company delivering these solutions today is Braintree. In a very short time, Braintree has built impressive mobile payment solutions that handle transactions in 130 currencies in more than 40 countries. Mobile developers love Braintree’s tools and the great hands-on service that they offer.

I admire Braintree because they were one of the very first companies to understand the power of real mobile-first experiences. I’m not talking about traditional e-commerce ported to your mobile device. I’m talking about groundbreaking experiences offered by companies like Airbnb, OpenTable, Uber, and TaskRabbit. Light, powerful, massively disruptive, and thoroughly delightful, they are all powered by Braintree.

Today’s news that we have agreed to acquire Braintree is a great move for both companies.

As a separate service offered by PayPal, Braintree will be able to scale its platform at a rate that is just not possible for a startup. PayPal’s already solved many of the regulatory and logistical hurdles that will help to extend Braintree’s reach to more customers in more markets even faster. Our resources will enable them to push the boundaries of innovation with ambition and confidence for consumers, merchants and developers around the world. It’s business as usual for Braintree. Braintree will continue to maintain its best-in-class service for its customers and developers for the foreseeable future.

And with the addition of Braintree, PayPal gets a lot more than a notable list of clients and an impressive technology portfolio. Today’s news means that Braintree’s team of brilliant engineers, innovative mobile strategists, and strong business leaders will soon be joining our ranks. Led by Bill Ready, they’ve built a company culture that emphasizes initiative, ownership, and passion for quality. Bill is an experienced entrepreneur and payment industry veteran who achieved great success at iPay Technologies and Netzee Payments before taking over as CEO of Braintree in 2011. I’m looking forward to having him join my executive team.

The real winners today are consumers, who can expect to soon enjoy easier, safer, faster, and more innovative ways to pay on more of their favorite apps and at their favorite businesses. Together, I believe PayPal and Braintree will enable merchants and developers to create new mobile experiences that are magical in ways that we can’t even begin to picture today.

Bill and I share a common vision of payments built around friction-free, mobile-first experiences and disruptive businesses that surprise and delight customers at every turn. By joining forces, we expect to realize this vision at unprecedented scale and unmatchable speed.

David

title: Outside Lands and PayPal: A Cashless Adventure in Music, Art and Food
content:
Aug 12
Jeff Thomas, User Experience and Design, PayPal

Even amid all the hot new indie bands, vast array of gourmet food options and Sir Paul McCartney himself, PayPal managed to make a huge splash at this year’s Outside Lands Music and Arts Festival in Golden Gate Park.

From rentable lockers to the official PayPal tent and dozens of merchants using PayPal Here and Check-in services, our company was all over it, all weekend long. I hit the pavement along with colleague Melanie Kriese for a first-hand look at the consumer experience, including what people were saying about our integrations.

Constructed in the heart of the main concert area, our Convenience Store served as a focal point for engagement. We saw lots of people using the PayPal app to check in for 50% off essentials like sunscreen, ear plugs and blankets, as well as to participate in activities such as face painting, hair chalking, temporary tattoos of the day’s lineup, and pictures at the Instagram photo booth. All of the profits from PayPal Convenience Store sales went to support the non-profit San Francisco Rock Project, which provides a performing arts education for kids 7-18 years old.

We used the PayPal app to check in as we walked up to the store. We got to the counter, said hi, the clerk tapped our photo on his iPad, and we were done! No cash, no card, no angst. Plus, we walked away with some sweet PayPal-blue fuzzy gloves. Yes, gloves! It can get chilly in San Francisco, even in August.

One concertgoer had just installed her PayPal app that morning. A PayPal staff member at the Convenience Store showed her how to use it and then added, “Now, no wallet. No credit card.” Her response? An enthusiastic, “OMG! I LOVE that!”

The mobile phone charging stations were also a huge hit, making the Convenience Store the place to chill out and recharge between shows.

Next we were off to find San Francisco’s famous food trucks, which were well represented this year and all accepted PayPal! But what to choose? Buttermilk fried chicken? Pizza? Ribs? Spring rolls? Tacos? Finally, a grilled cheese and bacon sandwich from Bacon Bacon was the decided winner. We logged in to our PayPal app, tapped ‘Local’ and checked in before saying “I’m paying with PayPal.” And that was it – our cashier didn’t have to deal with a card or cash. More importantly, neither did we.

The experience? Super easy. The sandwich? Well, it was melted cheese, and toasted bread, and bacon. Fabulous, of course!

We also stopped in at several non-food merchants, all of which were sporting the familiar blue PayPal Here dongle on their iPads.

Finally, a quick stroll around the outside of the main festival area revealed hundreds of blue lockers powered by PayPal, which were so popular they sold out! Why not lock up your wallet if you don’t need it for anything, right?

For even the casual festivalgoer, PayPal’s presence at Outside Lands was hard to miss. And for those who chilled out, charged up, or used PayPal to pay, it appeared to be something more: a seamless, simple, delightful part of life.

title: 'Cake Boss' Buddy Valastro on How to Bake up More Profits for Your Small Business
content:

Chris Morse, Head of Merchant Communications

title: Tower Paddle Boards Rides Wave of Success, with Help from PayPal
content:
Oct 14
PayPal, an eBay company

Stephan Aarstol spends a lot of time around sharks. An avid paddle boarder, he rides waves alongside leopard sharks in the waters off La Jolla, California. And as the owner of e-commerce startup Tower Paddle Boards, he communes with another kind of shark: Mark Cuban, American business magnate and investor “shark” on the ABC television series, “Shark Tank.”

Aarstol’s deep dive into the paddle boards market was unplanned. The entrepreneur and Internet marketing expert was working to launch another startup in 2010 when a friend invited him paddle boarding. Aarstol was instantly hooked. “On my first day, I was catching waves left and right,” he says. “I couldn’t believe how easy it was. I sensed a huge market for paddle boards was ready to blow up.”

San Diego-based Tower Paddle Boards sells direct to consumers online, a new concept for the space. (Traditional retailers use tiered distribution channels, which increases product cost.) Tower Paddle Boards also introduced a new product design to the market – a paddle board that’s shorter, wider, and thicker than typical 12-foot boards.

Since Aarstol appeared on “Shark Tank” in 2012 and scored a US $150,000 investment from Cuban, Tower Paddle Boards has been on a growth track. Aarstol says offering PayPal as a payment option to customers also has contributed to the startup’s impressive growth in sales from $3,000 to nearly $3 million in less than three years. “In my opinion, PayPal is something any legitimate e-commerce company must offer,” says Aarstol.

Bill Me Later® from PayPal is popular with Aarstol’s customers. The average price of a Tower Paddle Board is $795 plus shipping costs. Comparable boards from competitors sell for $1,200 and up. But even at a lower price, a Tower Paddle Board is a big investment for many consumers. That’s why Aarstol believes Bill Me Later is a deciding factor in many Tower Paddle Board purchases. To let customers know they have more time to pay, Aarstol added Bill Me Later banners to Tower Paddle Boards’ home page and product pages. He says placing the banners and adding PayPal as a payment option took just 15 minutes.

PayPal is creating other advantages for Tower Paddle Boards. “PayPal’s rates are much lower than what we pay for credit card processing today,” says Aarstol. And since the company integrated PayPal Express Checkout with its Volusion e-commerce platform, order processing has become more efficient. “Now, every PayPal order is funded immediately,” says Aarstol.

Paddle boarding isn’t a hot trend outside the United States yet. But Aarstol is betting it will be soon. When that happens, he says PayPal can help the company win business: “Unlike most U.S. consumers, people in other countries don’t have a credit card. But anyone with a bank account can use PayPal.”

Aarstol’s next focus is building a state-of-the-art, 5,000-square-foot production facility for Tower Paddle Boards in San Diego. And by combining the company’s warehousing, shipping and production operations in one space, he is able to do so at very little cost. “Essentially, we got a factory with virtually no overhead,” Aarstol says. “By leveraging our e-commerce infrastructure, we’re able to bring manufacturing back to the United States, and PayPal has played a part in this.”

title: A Strong Foundation: The Role of Infrastructure in Building Social Relationships
content:
Oct 11
Uyen Nguyen, Brand Journalist, Sprinklr

When you think of a home, you think of time spent with loved ones and all the memories held under one roof. You rarely think about the materials that hold the house together – the foundation that makes it possible to have a home.

The same applies to social. You rarely think about the systems in place to make all those tweets, shares, and conversations possible. You overlook the role of infrastructure in building and maintaining relationships.

But the reality is: "without an infrastructure, you’re just not social," says Sonja Broze, Head of Social Relationship Infrastructure at PayPal.

Why the Emphasis on Infrastructure?

It’s clear to Sonja, and other leaders at PayPal, that social isn't just another platform to push promotional messages onto customers. Rather, it presents an opportunity to converse with them, get to know them, and nurture relationships with them.

And with 132 million active registered PayPal accounts in 193 markets, the brand has a lot of relationships to maintain. So, they’ve put in place a framework that would integrate their social channels, keep track of conversations worldwide, and provide valuable feedback.

This is especially helpful as PayPal continues to expand into international markets. Thanks to a robust infrastructure, PayPal knows when their customers need help, and how to take steps to get in touch. And they know this on a global scale.

An infrastructure empowers companies to “make business decisions by knowing – not just having -- customers,” Sonja says.

A Bold Prediction

Sonja believes enterprises will soon (if they haven’t already) put the same emphasis on building a strong social infrastructure. “Infrastructure isn’t a sexy word,” she says. “But it allows us to stay in touch with those that matter to us most – our customers.”

Take our money transfer/p2p (peer-to-peer) capabilities. This is how PayPal started and that’s all it was until PayPal found its way to eBay. This is still core of our offering – a service that is used by millions of people worldwide to send money to their friends, family and to pay for services. This need is driving incredible number of our transactions - our p2p is hugely successful.

It works like a charm – your counterpart receives the money at the second you push ‘send’ button or tap the screen on our mobile app. It’s that easy. Oh, and it’s possible to do in many countries and in multiple currencies - something that no other digital wallet can offer.

Can we make our p2p offerings better, improve our user experience and take it to the next level? Absolutely - and so we will. Truth is, we’re just getting started.

We want to serve the needs of every customer who wants to pay their brother back for Mom’s birthday gift or get their landlord paid on time – even if this means different offerings for different segments of people. So p2p will continue to be an essential part of PayPal wallet forever because it solves a real problem. And makes that problem disappear.

title: Dueling PayPal Battle Hacks in D.C and Londonv
content:
Oct 16
Jonathan LeBlanc, Global Head of Developer Evangelism, PayPal
For the first time, we hosted two PayPal Battle Hacks in two continents on the same weekend – one in Washington, D.C. and other in London. Both events attracted top talent and reconfirmed that the developer community is thriving across the globe.

I had the opportunity to be a part of the D.C. competition, while our Global Director of Developer Relations John Lunn participated in the London event. Since I was in D.C., let’s start there.

Battle Hack D.C.

D.C. was the home to our first winning team made up completely of new hackers. Attending their first hackathon, four Georgetown University students took home first place with PhilanthroFeed. PhilanthroFeed enables people to help feed the homeless. Nowadays, many people don’t carry cash around or want to ensure that the money they donate is being used for the food it was intended for. Through the app, the homeless person would create a profile via a social worker, or anyone else with Internet access. When someone wants to donate, they find the homeless person’s profile in the app, then donate to add a credit for their account. The homeless person would then go to a participating restaurant and redeem the money for a meal.

Some of the other unique applications developed at the event included BosWash and Fund B.

BosWash, an application that uses crowd funding to help improve D.C. parks or other public spaces, took second place. BosWash users place a bounty on an improvement task (i.e. clean up the trash at a local playground), and other people can take on the task and redeem the bounty through the application once it’s been completed. In third place, was Fund B, an application created as an alternative to PayDay loans, which typically have high interest rates. Fund B instead allows groups of Facebook friends to fund small loans to one another other in exchange for a small fee.

Battle Hack London

While I wasn’t in London, I heard they had a great turnout. There was some stiff competition, making our judges’ jobs a tough one. Here’s the rundown on the London winners:

The winning application was CandlePath, which uses data available on street lights to plot your safest route home at night. Taking it a step further, the subscription based service, would also alert your designated contacts if you deviate from that path.

In second place was Bigger Issue, an application allows you to buy a copy of the Big Issue Magazine using text messages and PayPal. Big Issue Magazine was launched in 1991 in response to the growing homeless population London. The Magazine works to address the problem of homelessness by offering homeless people the opportunity to earn a legitimate income as a Big Issue vendor.

Neighbour.ly, an application that allows users to define your neighborhood and then lend household items to others within your local community, came in third.

Two Continents. One Prize.

During our hackathons, the D.C. and London developers interacted with each other through a live-streamed “Smack Talk” session and during a heated re-Tweet competition for the “Best Global Idea So Far” award. While London won that round, we definitely won for the best concession speech.

Overall it was a great PayPal Battle Hack weekend, with support from awesome judges in both locations. A big thank you to all of them for their time and support.

Our D.C judges included Evan Burfield cofounder of 1776 DC (@eburfield), Sean Glass with AccelepriseVC (@Seanglass), Fosterly founder Adam Zuckerman (@AdamZ) and Konrad Waliszewski with Speek (@goKonrad).

Across the pond in London, Jamie Parkins with JustGiving (@jamieparkins), Nadeem Shaikh with Anthemis (@nrshaikh), Tak Lo at Tech Starts (@tak_lo) and James Nicholson with Hailo (@jameslnicholson).

PhilanthroFeed and CandlePath will join our other Battle Hack winners on November 16-17, at PayPal’s headquarters in Silicon Valley to compete for $100,000 in the World Finale. We look forward to seeing all of our Battle Hack winners next month! You can find the full details on the upcoming PayPal Battle Hack Finale and other winning apps at: http://battlehack.org/

title: PayPal Sets the Pace for Innovation in Payments
content:
Oct 17
Anuj Nayar, Senior Director of Global Initiatives, PayPal

“Sprinting the marathon” has never meant more to us at PayPal.

As David’s earnings post yesterday noted, it is safe to say that PayPal has its innovation mojo back . The six weeks between Labor Day and Columbus Day might have been the busiest in PayPal’s fifteen-year history. As I look back at this thrilling – and maybe a little crazy time – I’m struck by our pace of innovation. And delighted that we’re showing no signs of slowing down.

David mentioned some of these in his post yesterday but there’s so much more…

In Store

On September 5, we launched an entirely revamped consumer app for iOS and Android devices. Available across the globe, the new app boasts a tab called ‘Shop’, which reimagines the in-store shopping experience for consumers by letting them pay, order ahead, or pay their check at the table at thousands of locations in the US, UK, Australia, Japan, Hong Kong and Canada.

Just four days later we unveiled PayPal Beacon, a new merchant add on that leverages the efficiency and flexibility of Bluetooth LE technology in many mobile phones to make it easy for customers to automatically check in and pay. This technology marks our most significant contribution to retail yet, by reinventing the in-store shopping experience. We challenged ourselves by asking, “What’s easier than swiping a credit card?” and the answer simultaneously made us chuckle and gasp: doing nothing. PayPal Beacon makes it possible for there to be something easier and quicker than swiping a credit card to pay—by letting the consumer do nothing to pay. It works with any PayPal compatible merchant POS system (there are dozens already – in fact, Revel Systems announced compatibility this week) and is a rich platform for developers too.

We completed our in-store trifecta at Money2020 with the announcement of Payment Code – a simple and efficient way for merchants who still have old 2d barcode systems (or even just PIN Pads) at Point of Sale – to join the digital payments revolution. Customers can pay by scanning a QR code or using a one-time generated PIN.

Online

We announced two pilots – one for consumers and another for merchants.

1. In collaboration with eBay Enterprise, we’ve crafted a limited time offer. Anyone who uses PayPal to make a purchase online at Levi’s, Aeropostale, Sports Authority, Dockers, Dick’s Sporting Goods, Kenneth Cole, iRobot, PBS and Maurices will receive free two day shipping in the US.

2. For our online merchants, we announced PayPal Working Capital. Select PayPal small businesses have access to a business loan that allows them to get funding in minutes and repay with a share of their sales. There are no minimum payments. You make money, and we get paid back. It’s that simple.

Demand Generation

Consumers aren’t looking for just a new way to pay, they want to save time and/or money. We believe that making it easier to claim and redeem offers is one benefit of the digital wallet that will drive more consumers to start using them. Offers right now are broken. Many consumers equate offers with spam—they’re not easy to redeem; people forget to bring them along when they’re actually going to a store; or worse: they have an offer that’s only redeemable online when they want to use it at the mall. PayPal’s Closed Loop Offers changes the game. They enable merchants to put real money into a PayPal user’s account to spend at their sites and stores. Redemption can be omnichannel (e.g. both in-store and online to provide flexibility and choice to the consumer) or designed to drive sales in one particular channel.

Wow, that’s a lot. But there’s more...

We also launched PayPal in Russia, with 13 of the biggest names in Russian ecommerce. We opened up a new development center in Bangalore. Bangalore is known around the world as the center of tech innovation in India and will be the 17th eBay Inc. dev center around the world. We also held developer hackathons – battlehacks – in London, Washington DC, Moscow and Austin TX – with a chance to win a $100,000 prize at the world final next month in San Jose.

And in the midst of everything, we also announced our plans to buy Braintree for $800 million – another company that’s changing the world by innovating payments.

That was a crazy six weeks and even that is not everything. You can read about the rest by just scrolling down the PayPal Forward blog. No other company is driving innovation at the scale that PayPal is in so many different areas, and we are only at the beginning. You can read more about PayPal’s perspective on the current and future state of the industry here: The Future of POS: Point of Sale Evolution and Its Impacts

title: Third Quarter Update
content:
Oct 16
David Marcus, President, PayPal

I’ve always believed in the power of numbers to tell a business story. As we’ve been compiling our third quarter results, however, I’ve been struck by how much of the story of what’s going on at PayPal today goes beyond numbers.

It’s not that our financials are any less impressive than the results we’ve shared in previous quarters. PayPal’s results were strong in Q3. Active accounts increased by 5 million again, and now stand at 137 million. Revenue increased 20 percent* to $1.62 billion. Total payment volume reached $44 billion mark, a leap of 25 percent*. Off-eBay volume grew 30 percent, to $31 billion and PayPal penetration on eBay rose a full percentage point quarter over quarter to more than 78%, the highest ever. And we processed 729 million transactions in the quarter. To put that last number in context, it’s equivalent to every person in the United States, South America and Australia making a transaction using PayPal during the past three months.

But to really understand what’s happening, you have to look at the innovation coming from PayPal over the past three months. From this perspective, I think it’s safe to say that we’ve got our innovation mojo back.

For example, on September 5 we launched our brand new consumer mobile app with a wide range of new capabilities that make transactions simpler and a lot more fun, like the ability to skip the line if you’re getting takeout by ordering ahead from the full menu. When you dine in, you can use the app to order more food or another drink, and then pay and leave a tip without waiting for a check from your server. If you use it to check-in at your favorite store, you can receive special offers that are automatically redeemed at checkout.

In early September, we also unveiled PayPal Beacon, a new technology that reinvents in-store shopping in profound and important ways. With PayPal Beacon, paying is completely hands free: you don’t need to pull out your wallet, swipe your card, or even open up an app on your phone. It uses Bluetooth Low Energy (or BLE) technology to connect devices to each other seamlessly and at very low energy consumption levels. At stores where you choose to check in, your photo will appear on the point-of-sale system and all it takes for you to pay is a verbal confirmation.

PayPal Beacon is also designed with your privacy and security in mind. It doesn’t constantly track your location like other technologies, and if you enter a store and decline to check in, or just ignore the prompt entirely, no information is transmitted to PayPal or the merchant. When you do choose to check in with Beacon, all communications meet the high standards that you expect from PayPal for security and no financial or login data is exchanged.

In the UK, we rolled out our PayPal Here Chip & PIN card reader broadly after completing a successful exclusive launch in that market. This is an important product for markets where magnetic stripe cards aren’t the standard. In mid-September, we expanded into Russia by offering people the ability to pay with PayPal in rubles. We also announced that more than a dozen of Russia’s leading major retailers will accept payments using PayPal, and we received applications for new merchant accounts from more than 2,000 local retailers.

Each one of these announcements marks an important step forward in our continuous efforts to bring greater value and convenience to peoples’ lives by making paying and getting paid easier and safer. But the move that may have the greatest impact was our agreement to acquire Braintree.

Braintree is a phenomenal organization and a great fit for PayPal. They’ve built a powerful mobile payments platform that is enabling some of the world’s most exciting new businesses to offer game-changing experiences. Venmo, their consumer app, makes it easy and fun for people to send money to friends. I’m thrilled to have both the Braintree and Venmo teams join the PayPal family.

Together, we look forward to further accelerating the pace of innovation here at PayPal as we build a new generation of delightful breakthrough experiences that solve everyday problems and enhance people’s lives all around the world.
