title: How Should Industries Like Payments Be Regulated in the 21st Century?
content:
Oct 29
Brian Bieron, Executive Director, Global Public Policy, eBay Inc.

PayPal is at the leading edge of the global, technology-enabled payments industry, serving 137 million consumers, entrepreneurs and businesses of all sizes in 193 markets around the world. The industry has seen tremendous innovation and competition from players large and small, with rapidly evolving technologies driving change and progress towards a brighter future.

The payments industry is one that government policymakers and regulators around the world care deeply about. Yet, it’s a common refrain among technology leaders that regulatory processes are far too slow to adapt. The general sense is that government cannot keep up with the rapid pace of innovation and creativity that is at the heart of today’s successful business operations. PayPal believes that while specific regulatory processes or policies may seem frustratingly outmoded, it is critical to begin any meaningful discussion of payments regulation with a clear recognition that the core, real-world, societal goals underpinning payments industry regulation are timeless and valuable. Government goals of protecting consumers from fraud, fighting criminal abuse, protecting the stability of the financial system, and promoting commerce, economic empowerment and innovation are all important goals that PayPal supports and believes other industry leaders share.

The challenge is developing new regulatory models that better achieve societal goals and also support rapid innovation. PayPal is stepping forward to meet this challenge by beginning a collaborative discussion about how increasingly ubiquitous 21st Century technology and data-analytics techniques used by technology-enabled organizations can be used by government regulators to make better and faster decisions to help deliver better results.

This is a global challenge, and in response, PayPal is releasing reports and engaging in collaborative discussions this week in Singapore, Washington, DC and Trieste, Italy. The concept is not overly complicated. We recommend that regulators use the same data analytics techniques that have transformed the “high tech” payments sector in the same they have transformed the healthcare and getting-a-taxi industries. These techniques rely on collaboration and iteration; they use technology and data to measure performance and deliver results. We believe that implementing this new approach will enable regulators to better achieve their goals, benefit consumers, and allow for a faster pace of business innovation.

  • Rohan Mahadevan, VP, PayPal Asia Pacific releases “Payments Regulation for Asia Pacific: A Model for Innovation and Growth” at the American Chamber of commerce in Singapore. He outlines SMART and Seamless governance models and calls for an ePayments Subgroup to be established within the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) Electronic Commerce Steering Group.

  • Brian Bieron, Executive Director of Global Public Policy for eBay Inc. releases “21st Century Regulation: PUTTING INNOVATION AT THE HEART OF PAYMENTS REGULATION” in Washington, DC at a policy luncheon hosted by the Progressive Policy Institute to discuss new regulatory models.

  • Hanne Melin, Policy Strategy Counsel EMEA for eBay Inc. presenting proposals on “The Innovative Public Sector” based on ideas from “A SMART STEP: Putting Innovation at the Heart of Payments Regulation” at the 22nd Global Forum 2013, Driving the Digital Future, in Trieste, Italy.

title: Wake Up and Smell the Coffee, from Costa Rica to the Rest of the World
content:
Nov 04, 2013
Jose Fernandez da Ponte, Senior Director for Latin America Cross Border Trade, PayPal

From selling coffee to building better websites for small enterprises, online business is booming in Latin America. In fact, our recent study “La Nueva Ruta de las Especias” reveals that 40% of revenues from surveyed SMBs come from online sources. More and more, cross border commerce is leveling the playing field for Latin American merchants.

One merchant that is benefiting from this trend is Café Britt. Although Costa Rica is significantly smaller than other countries in the region, the Café Britt team has been able to share the taste of "tico" gourmet coffee to people in Brazil, England, the United States and many more.

Café Britt started with a small website in the early 90s and has since enhanced its business model with digital tools such as PayPal. Today, Café Britt sells a variety of gourmet products, operating in approximately 100 gift shops in 10 countries. They are also launching Colombian Coffee this November.

Last week, I had the opportunity to speak with Adriana Echandi, Director of Retail for Café Britt, who was happy to share their story on how they used e-commerce to better connect with their consumers.

What is Café Britt’s background story?

Café Britt was the first roaster from a coffee-producing country to export gourmet coffee, not the raw material, to consumers around the world. We identified a niche market and positioned our coffee as the natural gift that tourists could bring home with them after their vacation. Our website allowed us to strengthen our presence among international buyers. Additionally, our business shows that in Latin America there is room for local innovative companies like ours to compete on the world stage and succeed.

What digital and mobile strategies is Café Britt implementing to strengthen growth?

We want to reach customers wherever they are, and they're all spending more time online and on their phones. As a result we are always looking to improve how we use these channels to sell to and communicate with our audience. For example, along with our customer service number, we also offer live chat and e-mail assistance so users can place their orders or contact us at their convenience. And, we are working on offering location-based deals as well as providing discounted shipping rates based on user geo-location capabilities through mobile devices. We constantly look for ways to optimize cross-channel experiences for customers who switch between online and offline mediums. From a marketing perspective, we also focus on pushing consistent messaging out across channels, and we lean on content marketing and social marketing to enhance and maintain customer behavior online. Regardless of the channel, we strive to deliver targeted, relevant marketing messages to the right audience, and this is becoming easier and easier to do online. Additionally, a new Head of e-commerce has recently joined to take our vision forward.

What financial impact has cross border sales had on your company?

Cross border business is a core part of our business model, and as we've begun to reach more and more customers all over the world, our business has grown in tandem. In the last 20 years, our total revenue grew from about $1 million to $115 million, from both local and international sources. Our e-commerce sales account for 5% of our total revenue.

When and why did Café Britt integrate PayPal as a payment solution?

We incorporated PayPal into our business in 2007, and our orders have only increased since that day. PayPal allows us to provide a safe payment option to our customers in almost any country in the world. Frankly, when selling online, safety is one of our biggest priorities, and that was a big driver behind why we chose PayPal. Likewise, we believe it is necessary to provide a trusted, international payment solution to ensure a good experience for our customers around the world. This in turn supports the bottom line of our business. Just last year, the increase in revenue from PayPal compared with 2008 was 54%, and we expect orders made with PayPal to keep on growing.

What are some successful digital strategies that you would recommend to an SMB who is trying to participate in cross border commerce?

We believe that the experience of the consumer is key to making business successful. Every part of the shopping process should be easy, safe and rewarding so customers continue to come back or refer the service to others. We would recommend that businesses evaluate their resources and implement an omni-channel approach so they can benefit from both online and offline selling efforts.

title: PayPal Introduces the World to Payment Code at Money2020
content:
Oct 08
Don Kingsborough, Vice President of Retail Services, PayPal

Yesterday, we shared our new white paper outlining how we see point of sale evolving over the next few years. We’ve had a busy month innovating with new technologies including our new app and PayPal Beacon.

PayPal Beacon allows merchants to make check in seamless and automatic for consumers by letting them just pay with an image of their face that appears on a merchant's POS screen. But what if the merchant POS system doesn’t have a screen that can display images? That's why today we’re introducing Payment Code. No need to rip & replace hardware at the point of sale to take advantage of leading edge technologies to make payments easy and drive consumer engagement.

This new technology lets consumers make purchases by scanning a QR code on their mobile phone, or receive a short four-digit code on their phone to complete a purchase. Payment code is an extension of our offerings for enhancing the payments experience in-store. Our approach isn’t to push technology for technology’s sake, but to truly make the paying experience better for consumers and to give merchants more opportunity to innovate without a costly investment. Payment code is easy to use and understand and utilizes a ubiquitous technology that merchants have and are familiar with.

How does it work?

When you’re ready to pay, simply open the PayPal app (or the specific merchant’s app.) and check in. Once you’re checked-in at that location, the app prompts you with a QR code, or a four-digit short code, to authenticate your purchase.

If the merchant has a barcode or QR code scanner, the merchant scans and, just like that, you have paid. If the merchant doesn’t then a four-digit code pops up on your phone, you (or the merchant) simply punch that code into the PIN pad at checkout. Boom, done!

What is the benefit to the consumer?

As we have said many times before, the problem that needs to be solved is not paying at a POS terminal. While payment code does make the checkout process smooth, with easy access to all funding sources in one simple place (your phone), the real benefit is that it will allow consumers to automatically redeem any special offers, gift cards, merchant rewards programs or other forms of payment that might be saved in their PayPal wallet in one quick transaction.

What is the merchant benefit?

Our philosophy at PayPal is to make digital payments as easy as possible for both consumers and merchants. Many of the merchants we have talked to – and trust us we have talked to a lot – want to get the benefits of these new ways to pay but they don’t want to rip out their existing technology to do it.

Payment code lets them take advantage of mobile payments using their old technology. Utilizing the millions of 2D barcode scanners already sitting on store counters and 40+ million payment terminals available around the world, this offers an easy way to give customers the benefits without investing in new technology.

But what if the merchant already has a mobile app for their customers?

Those merchants with a mobile app and older systems can still use payment code by integrating it into their own mobile app. The PayPal QR code will then appear as within the merchant’s own app.

We expect to roll out payment code globally in the first quarter of 2014, and look forward to sharing more at that time. This is just another way that we are driving new technologies and tools to help consumers and merchants of all sizes take advantage of the rising wave of digital payments.

title: Causes We Love: Bright Pink
content:
Oct 08
Clam Lorenz, Director, Nonprofit Engagement, PayPal

Bright Pink is a national non-profit organization for the prevention and early detection of breast and ovarian cancer in young women. Recently, I sat down with Carli Feinstein, the org's Marketing and Communications Manager, to discuss these efforts, the support Bright Pink provides for high-risk individuals, and how PayPal helps along the way.

Can you share any background and/or fun facts about Bright Pink?

Bright Pink is a national organization, headquartered in Chicago. We are the only national nonprofit focused on the prevention and early detection of breast and ovarian cancer in young women, while providing support for high-risk individuals. We educate, equip, and empower young women to be proactive with their breast and ovarian health.

Bright Pink was founded in 2007 and since then we have grown tremendously to impact hundreds of thousands of young women throughout the country. Most people are surprised to learn we are a staff of only 8 full-time employees. We are a group of young, highly driven, passionate individuals, and our ambition is amplified by hundreds of wonderful volunteers nationwide. Together, and with the help of world-class brands like PayPal, Aerie, and Dirty Girl Women’s Mud Run Series, we are creating a better, brighter future – one in which every young woman understands her personal risk for breast and ovarian cancer, and is actively engaged in a risk-reduction and early detection strategy.

What makes Bright Pink unique? Why would someone support you?

While many organizations promote breast cancer awareness, we are unique for many reasons, including:

  • Bright Pink focuses on both breast and ovarian health with an innovative approach to education. We meet women where they live, work, or play, and equip them with relevant, actionable information to enact proactive health behavior change.

  • Bright Pink goes beyond creating awareness to inspire life-saving action amongst young women. We provide tangible ways for women to know their bodies, assess their risk, and develop a personalized risk-reduction and early detection strategy. We offer resources and support throughout a woman’s journey including important questions to ask your doctor,Underwire Alerts, (monthly text message reminders to check your breasts), the Assess Your Risk Tool, a digital quiz to customize your cancer risk and develop an action plan, opportunities to anonymously ask questions of a certified genetic counselor and early detection and risk reduction tools.

  • Bright Pink is not a cancer survivor/fighter advocacy group. We focus on young, women (18-45) who do not have cancer to help them understand their risk and empower them to prevent these cancers or detect them at an early, non-life-threatening stage. Bright Pink has unique support programs for young women who have not had cancer, but who are at high-risk due to a strong family history or a genetic predisposition. These programs include PinkPal®, a one-on-one peer support program, andExperiential Outreach Groups, Bright Pink’s version of support group that pairs fun activities with facilitated discussions relevant to young high-risk women. These programs are designed to help high-risk women navigate the unique challenges associated with their risk status, as well as create a community of vibrant, confident and inspiring women.

  • Bright Pink ensures medical professionals are armed with knowledge and resources to spark life-saving conversations with young women about their breast and ovarian cancer risk and early detection and risk reduction strategies.
What are some of your biggest challenges in getting support?

We are a relatively young organization with a small staff. When you start an organization from scratch, and you are trying to build an infrastructure, it can be exciting and challenging at times. We very much have a start-up organizational culture, and there are some milestones that we hit much earlier than expected, and others that take a bit longer to implement. For example, we just debuted our first annual report this year, and are now in development of our first women’s philanthropy initiative and annual giving campaign.

Bright Pink’s programs and resources are geared towards young women, who sometimes do not have the financial assets to fuel our programs. So it’s important for us continue to serve these women and simultaneously grow our relationships with major donors, family foundations, and corporate partners who have the power to support us in that capacity. We rely on a 360 degree approach, using multiple channels to maintain constant, supportive conversations will all of these various stakeholders.

How does Bright Pink currently use PayPal?

Bright Pink depends on PayPal to process our online donations made through BrightPink.org.

Why do you like using PayPal to collect donations? 

PayPal is easy, save, secure, and familiar to our online visitors. We have also worked with PayPal to facilitate donations collected at 3rd party and partner events. Our donors find using PayPal very easy, and ensuring this comfort is very important to us.

How can others get involved in Bright Pink’s cause?

There are many ways to get involved with Bright Pink. First and foremost, we want you to do something bright for yourself. Join our network here and then use our site to brush up on the breast and ovarian health basics. Download our Tools to be Proactive and complete our innovative Assess Your Risk Tool to receive a personalized breast and ovarian cancer risk assessment, in printable pdf format, to bring to your next doctor’s appointment. Finally, sign up for Underwire AlertsTM , monthly text message reminders to check your breasts, by texting PINK to 59227.

If you’re interested in supporting our cause and furthering our mission, check if there is a Bright Pink Community near you, attend one of our events, and sign up as a volunteer!

Would you recommend PayPal to another nonprofit? Why?

Of course! It’s simple to integrate into your site, trusted by donors, and the team in incredibly supportive and accommodating!

What are Bright Pink’s social media channels?

So glad you asked! Like us on Facebook.com/BrightPink and follow us on Twitter and Instagram at @BeBrightPink. Pin with us at Pinterest/BeBrightPink.

title: PayPal and the National Cyber Security Alliance Unveil Results of New Mobile Security Survey
content:
Oct 09
Andy Steingruebl, Director of Ecosystem Security, PayPal
Welcome to Cyber Security Awareness Month, the annual October program run by the National Cyber Security Alliance (NCSA) to highlight the central role that the Internet plays in our connected digital lives and provide people with resources to help protect their safety and security in the online world.

This year’s Cyber Security Awareness Month activities emphasize a different theme each week. Week two focuses on mobile security. As a leader in mobile payments, PayPal is excited to play a role in NCSA’s efforts to help people understand what they can do to stay secure when they are connected to the Internet on a mobile device. After all, mobile commerce is a vital—and fast growing—part of our business. We know that to achieve our vision of fast, friction free payments, it’s essential that consumers feel safe and secure when they use their mobile devices to shop.

As part of our support for Cyber Security Awareness Month, we have been working with NCSA to get a clearer picture of how people use are really using their mobile devices today, and to find out what they do—and don’t—know about the safety issues they might face. So, in partnership with NCSA, we commissioned a survey of 1,000 adults in the United States.

The results of that study underscore just how deeply entrenched in our daily lives mobile devices have become. For example, two-thirds of the people we contacted told us that their smartphone is never further than one room away, and one in ten said they keep their phone handy everywhere they go, with the possible exception of the bathroom. In addition, the survey highlighted the growing importance of mobile devices as a tool for shopping, with one in four respondents reporting that they complete at least one transaction per day on their smartphone, while one in six say they make at least 25 percent of all their purchases on their smartphone.

But the survey also uncovered a general sense of unease about the security of financial information on mobile devices if lost or stolen, and it made clear that many people aren’t taking the steps they need to take to use their mobile devices safely.

We discovered, for example, that nearly 70 percent of Americans believe that storing payment information on their smartphone is unsafe. At PayPal, customer’s information is securely stored in the cloud. We also found that 63 percent of the people we surveyed don’t have a clear idea about what financial information is stored on their smartphones and more than half don’t lock their mobile device with a PIN.

What this means is that people aren’t as safe as they should be, and that by following a few simple tips from PayPal and NCSA, they can achieve greater security and better peace of mind:

  • Always activate a PIN or lock function for your mobile device: A PIN is the simplest and most important thing you can do to ensure security on your mobile device especially if it is lost or stolen.
  • Automate software updates: Many software programs automatically connect and update to defend against known risks. Turn on automatic updates on your mobile device if that’s an available option.
  • Use common sense when downloading apps: Unknown or repackaged apps can contain malware designed to steal financial information from a mobile device, so always purchase or download apps from companies that you trust and check reviews. When installing new applications, review permissions and decide whether you’re comfortable granting the access that an application asks for.
  • Enable “Find My Device”: If your phone, carrier, or antivirus software supports the “find my device” feature, it’s a good idea to activate it. This functionality will help you find your device if it’s lost or stolen, and lock it or wipe it clean remotely if you need to.
  • Backup your device: It is critical to backup your device on a regular basis. Some operating systems offer this option as an automated service. If you ever need to exercise the remote wipe feature mentioned above, you will be glad you have a current backup that you can recover to a new device.
In the survey, we found that many people are open to new approaches to mobile security that would increase their safety. In particular, there are strong indications that many people are willing to take advantage of biometric technology to protect themselves against mobile security threats. Our survey found that Americans are overwhelmingly comfortable replacing passwords with newer security technologies such as fingerprint identification (53 percent) and retinal scans (45 percent).

PayPal has always been passionate about protecting customers, and we go to great lengths to do so with purchase protection, storing information securely in the cloud, and utilizing advanced technologies for fraud detection. We are also at the forefront of industry-wide efforts such as the FIDO (Fast IDentity Online) Alliance to develop new and better ways to make online authentication faster, easier, and more secure.

At the same time, we know that individuals have a vital role to play in making sure their personal and payment information is safe. Our hope is that continued innovation and education from great organizations like NCSA will help consumers understand what they can do to take advantage of a new generation of amazing mobile commerce experiences with greater confidence that their information is well-protected.

If you’re interested in learning more, please join us for a Mobile & On the Go Twitter Chat on Thursday, October 10 at 3 p.m. ET. Participants can use the hashtag #ChatSTC to join. More information is available at:www.stopthinkconnect.org/twitterchats. You can also find more “Safety & Security Tips On the Go” at: http://staysafeonline.org/ncsam/resources/.

title: Untangling Our Wired Lives with Randi Zuckerberg
content:
Nov 05, 2013
Dave Peck, Head of Social Media, PayPal

The explosion of technology and digital innovation over the last decade has meant a lot of great things for a lot of people. Today there are those of us who can grocery shop from the comfort of our own living rooms, share face time with friends and family from the road, and keep tabs on virtually every aspect of both our personal and professional lives using a device small enough to fit in our pockets.

Sometimes, however, this new space and can be as overwhelming as it is awesome, and being more connected often just ends up feeling like MORE.

And so the great challenge of our time has become developing solutions with a less-is-more approach, in hopes that by raising the bar of digital intuition, the tools we create will simplify rather than over complicate. Recent examples from our personal collection include Beacon, upgrades to our PayPal app and the increasing availability of PayPal Here, but we’re on a mission to go far beyond what we’ve got in-house.

That’s why we’re working with Randi Zuckerberg.

Dot Complicated

As a former Facebook marketing executive, Randi has been on the frontlines of the social media movement since its early days. And, like us, she’s spotted a similar gap at the intersection of technology and lifestyle.

Her recent efforts to expose and remedy the disconnect come in the form of a great book called Dot Complicated: Untangling Our Wired Lives. The text is perfect for those looking for a breakdown of today’s technology, the influence both it and social media have had on our day to day, and how to navigate through it all successfully.

You can think of it as a kind of modern day guide to life, and our new relationship with her company, Zuckerberg Media, aims to help spread these smarts to any nook and cranny that will benefit from them.

Tech-Life Balance

Randi’s endgame and ours is very similar: to promote a lifestyle in which technology enhances rather than complicates, and so we’re pretty excited to be joining forces. And bonus? She’s an avid PayPal user.

“Just the other day, I wanted to send money to my colleague Brad for a fun tech meetup he was helping me put together. I was on the road and couldn’t write him a check, but wanted him to get the money right away. I took out my phone and sent him the money through the PayPal app and he received it immediately. This is one of the ways that PayPal is making MY life easier. It’s great to be working together to promote the ways technology can make everyone’s lives simpler and provide greater tech-life balance,” she told us.

As we continue to pick up speed on the digital highway, I encourage all those who seek a smoother ride to check out what PayPal and Randi are doing to help the cause. The latest in PayPal news can always be found right here on PayPal Forward, and you can pick up a copy of Randi’s book – *wink wink* – here.

title: A Modern Dilemma: the Convenient Commerce Shift
content:
Oct 08
Adrian Christie, Head of Communications, PayPal Australia

Last week I had a rather fiery and excitable conversation with a friend over car and motorbike parts. Here’s the scenario: your car breaks down and you know why, but you don’t know how – or perhaps don’t have the time – to fix it. Is it ok to source the parts online and ask the workshop if they are ok to just charge labour for the install?

What Should we Pay for?

As a PayPal employee in the little old island of Australia driving a European 4WD, I know that I am better off buying parts online than via my mechanic. I will trust the smallest of online retailers as long as they provide PayPal as an option. This way I know that my coils, drive shaft, or braided brake lines will be covered in the event that they don’t arrive.

Online I can do more research; I scan forums, I scour reviews, and I consider price. In the end this means I am able to get exactly what I want for a price that suits my need (shipping is cheaper than air freight and often I am happy to wait).

So, again, is it ok for me to take the parts I have purchased independently to the mechanic and ask them to fit them? I think it is. As this isn’t where the mechanic adds value – it’s the skills of the trade. The mechanic didn’t spend years studying and enduring an apprenticeship to learn how to order spare parts.

An argument I raised to my unconvinced friend is that some restaurants are BYO (Bring Your Own) and this allows you to bring a nice bottle of wine without paying through the nose. If the restaurant is truly focused on their food, the money shouldn’t get in the way of a good consumer experience, right?!

The Technology and Consumer Convenience Shift

I guess my point is that technology and consumer convenience are shifting the way we do business in many ways and its effects are felt more broadly than we often think.

While the mobile phone is disrupting traditional retail and empowering the customer in ways never previously imagined, so too is traditional online commerce as consumers, just like me, use the reach of services like PayPal to buy products from around the world. So even though I work for the company, my Land Rover Defender and I would like to say a big thanks to PayPal for connecting us with great merchants around the world who are keeping us on the road.

And to close – props to my mechanic who is very supportive of my approach. He actually appreciates not having as many cars in his shop sitting around taking up space as the parts sit on order.

After consulting with PayPal, Wu chose to turn to exporting jewelry, which is high in unit price and low in shipping costs, via online transactions rather than offline.

title: How Businesses Can Encourage (Extra) Early Adoption
content:
Nov 08, 2013
Beth Ann Calhoun, Director, Global Operations OE, PayPal

As program lead for PayPal Here in North America, I’ve been consumed with this innovative new product since the beginning, and as I work from home, my family is intimate with PayPal Here as well. I’ve been particularly fascinated to see how aware my 12-year-old daughter, Sadie, has become of POS systems and PayPal Here competitors, just from her exposure to my work.

The Carolina Blue Dogs

Sadie was recently assigned a school project to create and market a Major League Baseball team for the Charlotte region (we currently only have minor league). Part of the exercise was to come up with a logo and promotional items to eventually sell. After a bit of brainstorming, the Carolina Blue Dogs were born and the logo was put onto hats and cups. But Sadie took it a step further when she decided to actually make these items sellable, and asked for a PayPal reader to use with her phone. As you can see in the photo below, she even promoted “being blue” to sell the Carolina Blue Dogs gear.

This project was presented right before I attended eBay Inc’s Women’s Initiative Network (WIN) conference – an internal program sponsored by PayPal’s CEO, John Donahoe – and one of the messages that really hit home was around the lack of women in technology. I thought of Sadie and couldn’t help but wonder, How can I take my daughter’s fascination with the PayPal Here product, her love of math, and help her become part of the conversation?

Spreading Awareness for the Greater Good

I think as leaders within the disruptive community we have an obligation to ask ourselves big questions like these, and as technology continues to influence lifestyle, an even bigger obligation to answer them.

For me, that answer currently resides in awareness. WIN has exposed me to so many helpful programs for the upcoming generation, such as Girls Who Code. The more I learn, the more I can teach and encourage my daughter, and right now the focus on the importance of diversity and inclusion, buttressed by the ongoing efforts of WIN, taps right into that channel.

We’ll need to keep the momentum going in other ways as well, but by allowing employees the opportunity to regularly be a part of such a transformative discussion, I think PayPal is moving in the right direction. When we have the means to learn, and, in effect, expose our children to the ways of technology, we encourage them to create even better ideas to connect commerce, and we effectively springboard ourselves into an even more successful future.

title: PayPal’s Top 3 Tips for Brand Success on Instagram
content:
Nov 12, 2013
Dave Peck, Head of Social Media, PayPal


PayPal has developed a really great relationship with Instagram since we launched our account in January of 2013. As PayPal’s Head of Social Media, I’ve had the privilege of seeing some wonderful and successful projects executed, including our guest Instagram initiatives, one of the first-everInstagram photo booths at Outside Lands, and most recently, the platform’s choice to include PayPal in their ads launch.

Once a sanctuary for the younger crowd, Instagram is now a popular storytelling platform for a range of age groups and demographics. Beyond that, the platform has evolved into a powerful marketing tool for business. Through Instagram, PayPal has had the opportunity to not only engage with our existing customers, but expand our social audience.

For my team and I, the golden ticket lies in Instagram’s authenticity. People love to get an inside look and feel, whether it’s behind-the-scenes at Outside Lands or a press conference we’re hosting. People like to feel like they’re a part of the action, so the more brands allow their audience members to join these experiences, the more success they will find.

That being said, I’m not recommending you should sign up for an account and start posting haphazardly. Building a brand story on any social platform takes time and thought. Whether you’re a seasoned social media professional or just starting out on Instagram, there are a few practices I’ve helped set in motion here at PayPal that every business should consider.

1. Don’t just talk about yourself. Nobody likes it when you’re too self-serving, so it’s good to mix up your content a bit. In addition to the products and services you can purchase through PayPal, we like to share photos of the various sights and treats we come across, just so people know that we too like to take breaks now and then to enjoy our surroundings. When we are sharing about products and services you can purchase via PayPal, we want our followers to feel like they are right there with us, whether it’s enjoying a cup of coffee or buying a gift for a friend.

2. Hand over your credentials. In addition to sharing content from the PayPal perspective, we often partner with Instagram photographers to document their own PayPal experience on our account. At Outside Lands, for example, British singer-songwriter Jessie Ware gave our followers a peek at her backstage life. While these photos didn’t directly exhibit the PayPal brand at an initial glance, they did show our followers our event partnership and relationships.

3. Encourage larger conversations. A conversation should be just that--a conversation. In addition to showing our followers what we’re all about, we use our Instagram account to ask them about their lives. Asking questions invites comments, which can enable you to get to know your community members as well as provide them an opportunity to get to know each other. We want to be sharing content that our community is genuinely interested in and it all starts with asking them what exactly that is.

While these specific PayPal examples may not directly apply to your business, it’s wise to start thinking of the content you share on social platforms as a way to exhibit a lifestyle rather than solely push products and brand messaging. Lending personal flair to the photo stream connects you to your community on a more personal level and lets followers get a sense of the personalities behind your brand. All in all, it’s more fun to be creative and strategic with your content rather than just posting and calling it a day.

What brands do you think are “doing it right” on Instagram? Share with me on Twitter @PAYPAL and @davepeck.

title: PayPal Awards $100,000 Battle Hack Prize to Team Moscow’s Donate Now App
content:
Nov 18, 2013
John Lunn, Global Director, PayPal Developer Network, PayPal

This weekend, the two-day Battle Hack World Finals took place at the PayPal Headquarters in San Jose and we hosted 10 teams of developers from across the globe. Each team had to win a regional PayPal Battle Hack competition to qualify for the finale. At the event, competitors were tasked with building an application that incorporated the PayPal API and benefited the community in some way.

The 24-hour competition created 10 outstanding apps, ranging from a seasonal payroll system and real-time peer loans for the under-banked to ways for food trucks to quickly expand service locations with pledges from customers. Big thanks to our PayPal Battle Hack World Finals judges for making the tough decision. Judges included: John Lunn; David Marcus, President of PayPal; Isaac Saldana, President of SendGrid; Jeff Lawson, CEO of Twilio; Aunkur Arya, Braintree General Manager of Mobile, and Sarah Austin, Stremor Chief Product Officer.

We’re thrilled to share that the $100,000 grand-prize winner of PayPal’s Battle Hack Series, a global hackathon competition, was awarded to the four members of team Moscow: Sergey Pronin, Alexander Balabna, Bayram Annakov, and Oksana Tretiakova. Team Moscow’s “Donate Now” app leverages Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) technology and PayPal to allow anyone to instantly donate to a cause right from their mobile device without filling in lengthy forms and whenever and wherever they see an opportunity for giving in their daily lives.

Here’s what the team Moscow winners had to say about the app and the competition: “People love helping others in need, but there are so many obstacles that can make it hard to donate. The commitment to great developer tools and the attention we received from PayPal’s evangelists and mentors throughout the competition gave us a unique opportunity to showcase what we do every day—build terrific applications to solve pressing problems.”

Second place went to team Tel Aviv (Dañny Leshém, Yaniv Ben Zaken, Maya Marom and Yoav Amit) for RunPal, an app that connects users with other runners around the world to encourage them to get running. Third place went to team Miami (Alexander Sjögren, Jose Pimienta and Osniel Gonzalez) for LoanPal, a peer-to-peer lending service for under-banked individuals.

The PayPal Battle Hack Series launched in May 2013 and has hosted regional hackathons in 10 cities worldwide. Prior to the finale event in San Jose, California in the United States, PayPal hosted regional competitions in Berlin, New York City, Tel Aviv, Seattle, Miami, Moscow,Austin, London, Washington, D.C., and Barcelona. PayPal awarded first place to one team in each regional Battle Hack city. Each winning team then traveled (all flight and hotel expenses paid) to San Jose to compete in PayPal’s Battle Hack World Finals. Throughout the Battle Hack Series each team was judged based the quality of the idea, execution and innovation, and the overall user experience of the app.

We truly believe that developers can help change the world. We launched the Battle Hack program to find the best and brightest developers across the globe that could do just that. The response from our inaugural Battle Hack competition has been overwhelming, and we are excited to bring it back next year. Go to battlehack.org to get updates!

title: The End of the Line – PayPal Predicts No More Shopping Lines in 5 Years
content:
Nov 21, 2013
Stacy General, PayPal Customer Experience Advocate

While we hope that the stalwarts of the holidays like chestnuts and carols are here to stay, PayPal is predicting the end of one of the most annoying and inevitable holiday experiences: the long shopping line.

We believe that, thanks to advances in technology and the prevalence of mobile devices and innovations in retail, in 5 years, we'll say goodbye to the line for good! It’s a bold prediction, but we're already experiencing ways technology reduces the pain of shopping and paying.

Today on the PayPal app, you can order lunch right from your phone while on the go and pick it up later to skip the line, or check-in at your favorite coffee shop and receive VIP treatment from the barista, all without ever having to pull out your wallet. Thousands of locations worldwide already accept PayPal and we expect consumer demand will continue to grow for experiences like these, as retailers make payments easier and shopping more delightful during the holiday season and beyond.

We’ve done some research to confirm our suspicion that waiting in lines is one of biggest hassles for shoppers during the holidays. We took a look at social chatter during the 2012 season and, not surprisingly, waiting in lines made holiday shopping an unpleasant experience for most (89%). Even more telling is that many shoppers avoided physical stores altogether, left empty handed after spotting a nasty line, or ran straight to their couch to shop online. And those good deals that people line up overnight for during Black Friday? Many said they would rather pay more for those products elsewhere than brave the crowds and stand in line.

This isn't just idle chitchat between pals on Twitter – a recent PayPal survey found that 53% of US shoppers say they'd prefer to shop online or via their mobile devices rather than deal with the lines and crowds during the holiday season.

So are we truly nearing the end of the line? Only time will tell, but we do know that this holiday season we're inching a little closer as consumers around the world look to technology like the PayPal app to save time with features like Order Ahead and Pay at Table, and money with great offers for savings at retailers and restaurants you love.

Throughout the season, we’ll share more insights around how lines are affecting consumers and their shopping behavior, as well as what we are doing to make things easier. Check back and share your experiences too.

title: Black Friday 2013: Did Consumers Go Mobile – at Home?
content:
Nov 30, 2013
Stacy General, PayPal Customer Experience Advocate

While traditionally a day for early mornings, doorbuster deals and long lines, PayPal saw an increase in shopping with mobile devices on Black Friday 2013 (compared to Black Friday 2012).

As consumers continue to look for ways to avoid waiting in lines (baby, it’s cold out there!), many are turning to their smartphones or tablets to make holiday purchases. PayPal data shows that, compared to Black Friday 2012, 99.2% more consumers shopped through PayPal on their mobile device on Black Friday 2013. Overall, global mobile TPV (total payments volume) for Black Friday 2013 increased 121% compared to Black Friday 2012.

What about early birds?

Our data shows, much of this shopping is taking place after the rush for many stores– specifically, the highest frequency of mobile shopping through PayPal in the US took place between 7pm and 8pm PT. Maybe consumers aren’t avoiding the lines at all – but extending their shopping after a long day at the mall?

Where are these savvy mobile shoppers?

This Black Friday 2013, consumers in Houston shopped through PayPal on their mobile devices more frequently than other cities around the US, followed by Chicago, Los Angeles, Miami and New York, respectively.

What was your Black Friday game plan – did you hit the in-store sales, stay home with your phone and PayPal account or a little of both? Are you gearing up for Cyber Monday?

title: Proud and Humbled: Helping Australian Small Businesses Bridge The Digital Literacy Gap
content:
Oct 18
Adrian Christie, Head of Communications, PayPal Australia

This week, PayPal launched the next phase of its Australian small business education program – Driving Business Online (DBO) – helping Australian small businesses understand technology and how they can best use it to their advantage.

So why am I proud and humbled? I am incredibly proud of our company and the way we are engaging with Australian small businesses to help them take advantage of technology platforms to drive growth. For many, services like PayPal provide a way to turn their ideas into commercial opportunities.

The Driving Business Online program is a great reminder of the role we play for thousands of businesses, and the responsibilities we carry on their behalf. This is a driving force in how we view our business processes; we’re always looking to improve to ensure we maintain the highest levels of service with minimal disruption to the people that rely on us.

Businesses from butchers to fashion merchants (and no doubt a few candlestick makers) rely on our services and we use this education program to help them make more out of the online experience. In addition, we help businesses that have yet to move online consider new technologies that will help them foster growth. Our research shows us that while we have in excess of two million small businesses trading in Australia, only 34% of them list their contact details online. For many, listing contact details is the first step in their online journey and the Driving Business Online program is there to lend a hand with helpful advice and tutorials.

It was a great honour to be joined by The Hon. Malcolm Turnbull, Federal Minister for Communications, expert commentators and leading small businesses like Black Milk Clothing at our event to discuss how we can create initiatives to improve the digital literacy of Australia’s small business community together.

Already it has been a long and enjoyable journey. We first launched the Driving Business Online program in mid-2011 on the front lawn of Parliament House in our nation’s capital. We had a big blue bus and a number of inaugural partners to help us reach the thousands of small businesses in Australia grappling with the eCommerce revolution.

In the years since, we’ve been working with thousands of businesses to provide them with tools and information to begin trading online. More than just online payment services, we’ve also helped businesses with integrated invoicing, bill payment options and in-store solutions, while also connecting them to partners within eBay Inc. to help them take advantage of everything the Internet has to offer.

One thing I love about working for eBay Inc. is that our businesses and platforms provide equal opportunity for all to prosper from technology. We do not favour big or small businesses, nor do we allow geography to stand as a barrier. This year alone, more than $5 billion dollars’ worth of retail products will be purchased from overseas customers.

As I’ve said, I am proud and humbled by this program – I can’t wait to hit the road again this year and meet with Aussie businesses exploring ways they can prosper from the growth of the digital economy. That is why the Driving Business Online program exists – to help Australian SMEs overcome the digital literacy gap to drive further growth and manage their business more efficiently.

To learn more, visit www.drivingbusinessonline.com.au.

title: Trotter Pup Supports Animal Rescue
content:
Oct 21
Clam Lorenz, Director, Nonprofit Engagement, PayPal


We’re excited to share that we’ve teamed up with Instagram’s favorite French bulldog and Instagram sensation, Trotter Pup, to visit some furry friends in need at two San Francisco animal shelters, Muttville and Northern California Family Dog Rescue. Both of these animal shelters are PayPal nonprofit partners and create better lives for animals in need through rescue, foster and donation. Follow Trotter’s adventures by visiting both shelters on our Instagram account (@PAYPAL) and donate to these organizations here.

I sat down with Marie Macaspac, Director of Marketing and Social Media at Muttville and Marisa Plaice, Fundraising and Development at Northern California Family Dog Rescue, to discuss the work they’re doing and how PayPal helps both organizations.

Can you share any background and/or fun facts about the organization?

Muttville: Muttville is about to rescue its 2000th dog. We’re about 45 dogs away! In 2010, Muttville founder Sherri Franklin attended Oprah’s final Favorite Things episode, winning many prizes later auctioned off to benefit Muttville. But we did keep one item - thanks to Oprah, Muttville has a beautiful red 2012 Muttbeetle. May 10th, 2011, was proclaimed "Muttville Senior Dog Rescue Day" in San Francisco. In 2008, Gogol Bordello drummer found us and donated $10,000 and played a 100% benefit show for Muttville at Slim's in San Francisco. Muttville has also been voted Best Animal Rescue Group in Bay Woof's The Beast of the Bay Awards for 5 years straight.

Family Dog Rescue: Northern California Family Dog Rescue is a local, grassroots-grown rescue organization founded in 2010 by a group of animal lovers and rescue experts to save family-friendly dogs from California's high-kill shelters. We pull dogs of all kinds and ages, including newborns and those with permanent disabilities, from facilities around the state so that they can be placed safely and comfortably in caring homes. In addition to providing health care (spay and neuter, vaccines, and medical attention), training, socialization, and rehabilitation services for the dogs we take in, we also advocate for greater public awareness concerning the importance of spay/neuter operations and responsible animal care. We believe that a dog is a member of the family and should be treated as such, and that means having regular access to the home (not just left in the backyard) and receiving all the love and affection that a human family member gets! Family Dog Rescue runs almost entirely by local volunteers, alums, and our communities' continued generosity. We have a five-star rating on Yelp, and are grateful to have strong community support all over the San Francisco Bay Area.

What makes the organization unique? Why would someone support you?

Muttville: Senior dogs! We are the first in the Bay Area and still one of the only rescues that focuses on dogs 7 years and older. So many people are drawn to our niche and and are opening their hearts to older dogs.

Family Dog Rescue: What sets Family Dog Rescue apart from other rescues in the Bay Area is the fact that we have our own shelter facility. Located in San Francisco’s Mission District, we rent our space from the SF SPCA and are located in their old building. Due to this we don’t have to rely solely on foster homes (although we still need those too) and thus can save even more dogs. Family Dog Rescue is also passionate about helping dogs with disabilities and educating people about the fact that disabled dogs are just as trainable and loving as "regular" dogs. We also strive to find dogs that are good with kids, because we feel it's important for children to grow up with animals.

What are some of your biggest challenges in getting support?

Muttville: In the beginning, the challenge really was about getting people to want to adopt a demographic of dogs once considered "unadoptable". I think we have overcome that stigma, and we hear people proudly say, "I've got a Muttville dog!" Now it’s about increasing the numbers. Even though we’re one of the only rescues who save senior dogs, for every dog we save, there are still at least 20 we must turn away. We need more money and more space so that we can save MORE senior dogs.

Family Dog Rescue: One of the biggest challenges in getting support is awareness. Many people, even within San Francisco, don't know about smaller independent rescues and how much we need support! We want people to know who we are and how important it is to adopt, and we want to continue to grow and save more and more dogs. We can't do that without the help and support of our community.

How does the organization currently use PayPal?

Muttville: We've been using PayPal since day one. It is our main method of direct donations, and the most reliable. PayPal is on our Give page AND how people buy tickets for our big annual fundraiser, Moolah For Mutts. We haven't changed the PayPal method since Muttville's website launched in 2007! But we want to utilize all the "bells and whistles" so we have a plan to incorporate more features in 2014.

Family Dog Rescue: Family Dog Rescue has been using PayPal since we began in order to collect donations. We have a badge on our website, and we are able to link it to specific fundraisers that we run. Verifying our PayPal account on third party sites is always quick and easy. Also it's really helpful that almost everyone has a PayPal account! We can easily collect our adoption donations online, which is great because we no longer accept checks.

Why do you like using PayPal to collect donations? Do you use it for anything else? Do your customers like using PayPal?  

Muttville: We know that everyone feels comfortable with PayPal and it is reliable. Everyone trusts PayPal. Many offers come our way, and they also come and go. We know that PayPal is here to stay.

Family Dog Rescue: As I mentioned, it's fantastic! I think adopters/donors like using PayPal because they are familiar with the site, know how to use it, and can trust that their money is going to get to where it's supposed to. All we have to do is tell them "You can donate on PayPal" and that's it - its simplicity really makes our lives easier. If it was a more complicated or longer process I think it'd make getting donations harder - they may not remember the site name, etc. Also these days people rarely have cash and checks, but have smart phones and can make the donation right then and there.

How can others get involved in your organization’s cause?

Muttville: Adopt! Donate! Volunteer! Foster! Choose what is best for you. Any amount of support is appreciated. 3 hours a week sitting in the doggy loft and giving belly rubs and TLC means the world to these dogs.

Family Dog Rescue: People can get involved in many ways! We always need shelter volunteers to walk dogs and enrich their lives - applications can be found on our website. We also encourage people to help out at weekend adoption events - the more people we have, the more dogs we can bring out to meet the public! And of course donations of any kind - leashes, towels, bedding, and monetary donations - are incredibly helpful. And of course, by adopting!

Would you recommend PayPal to another nonprofit

Muttville: We have proven success and reliability working with PayPal. PayPal is the payment method we could stand by without a doubt. Plus the support and relationship PayPal has built with us is amazing. We are always getting calls checking in and offering to help us grow or help promote our cause.

Family Dog Rescue: Definitely. It is a reputable, well-known site and its simplicity is key. Nonprofits rely on donations, so of course we want to make it as easy for our donors as possible. I really have no idea what we'd do if we couldn't utilize PayPal! In addition we can always confirm what payments have come in from what adopters, and they money is quickly deposited into our bank account.

What are your organization’s social media channels?

Muttville: We heavily use Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest and Instagram. Our hashtag is #SeniorDogsRule. Thanks to social media, we have donations and supporters around the world! Another reason we are grateful for PayPal, we know PayPal is internationally known!

Family Dog Rescue: In addition to our website, Family Dog has an active Facebook page, Twitter account and an Instagram account.

title: Getting Comfortable with Change
content:
Oct 22
Lee Brooke, Senior Director, Communications, PayPal EMEA


When I joined PayPal nearly five months ago, it represented a significant personal change for me: I was leaving Nokia where I’d been leading communications around the company’s reinvention of its smartphone strategy to lead all communications across Europe, Middle East and Africa for PayPal, which is busily reinventing itself around mobile. I also moved countries—from Helsinki where Nokia is based, to Luxembourg, where PayPal has its European headquarters. Along with this shift were subtle differences that only became apparent later: moving from a corporate headquarters to a regional headquarters requires a change in mindset; moving from a European company to a North American company brings some interesting differences in corporate personality.

One thing I’ve been adapting to since I joined PayPal is the differences in our business across the globe. While Nokia pretty much made one version of a phone (barring a few network technology variances), paying with PayPal can mean many different things in different places: authorizing in-store payments by giving the cashier a friendly smile in the UK, or scanning a QR code in a shop window in Germany to have a pair of shoes sent to your home are just a couple of examples.

Finding Constants

Communications people are generally comfortable with change - very little is predictable about our daily work schedule – and we know the easiest way to make sense of change is to find constants.

Then, last month, I found one. I was in Moscow for the launch of PayPal locally. We were standing around after the press conference when a journalist came over to chat. He’d arrived late and wanted to be briefed on what we’d announced. I began running through the 13 merchants who would start accepting PayPal payments in Russian rubles and halfway through he stopped me: ‘wait. Are you telling me I can pay for my groceries online using PayPal and I don’t have to hope that when they turn up at my house, I have the cash lying around?’ (With unreliable delivery infrastructure and a cash-on-delivery culture in Russia, you usually need to have cash to give the delivery driver, whenever he might turn up.)

“Yes.”

“That’s great news! I’ll be using PayPal for all my groceries from now on.”

It was that simple. Whatever the challenge locally, whether it’s distrust of banks in Italy or Spain, unreliable logistics in Russia or cumbersome bank transfers in Germany, PayPal’s goal is to make paying easier. That’s the constant.

The Method Behind the Madness

Change unsettles people, plain and simple. Even if people accept change as necessary, they search for reassurance in constants. It’s a pattern we see repeated all around us, like TV sitcom plotlines or the predictability of the changing seasons (unless you live in Helsinki in which case there’s only two seasons – a really long winter and a really short, but gloriously sunny summer).

Communications people help engage, explain and debate. If we do it well, we succeed in helping people find what is constant and feel comfortable with what is changing. It’s a role that offers immediate feedback: you see or hear straight away if people don’t understand or don’t feel comfortable and you try again. That’s one of the things I love about what I do – it’s a journey that never really ends.

title: Small Business Success with PayPal: Camera Paradise
content:
Oct 18
PayPal, an eBay company

Starting as an eBay trader in 2009 and developing its own website two years later, Hong Kong-based Camera Paradise was born when its creators spotted a gap in the online camera retail market. By providing tax-free delivery to Australia and the UK, plus its own warranty that supersedes those offered by manufacturers, the company has been able to capture the attention of many camera enthusiasts outside Hong Kong.

But in digging its way into overseas camera markets via the digital highway, they also encountered various obstacles, including fraudulent transactions and the frequency of shopping cart abandonment.

Enter PayPal.

“Due to PayPal’s user verification process, we found by using this platform we could substantially lower fraudulent transactions” said the company’s General Manager, Bally Butt. “Our PayPal account manager can e-mail me and alert us to any possible fraudulent transactions. In most cases, we are informed if a transaction needs further verification within 48 hours of the payment being made, and as they are reviewing the transaction. As a result we are able to hold what we are doing for that particular customer and wait for the verification from PayPal.”

As for shopping carts, Camera Paradise was pleasantly surprised when conversions starting going up after implementing PayPal. “We started using PayPal’s express checkout in mid-2012, and immediately we saw a 20-23% increase in orders,” added Bally. “I believe this is simply because it’s faster, easier and much more convenient for customers to complete their transaction.”

title: PayPal and Blackhawk Network to Bring Gift Cards to the Digital Wallet
content:
Oct 23
Patrick Gauthier, Head of Emerging Retail Services, PayPal

Consumers love giving and receiving gift cards during the holiday season. In fact, the average holiday shopper spent $155+ on gift cards last year*. However, 78% of people find themselves unable to use these thoughtful gifts because they’ve left them behind when they need them most*. PayPal and Blackhawk Network, a leading prepaid payment network that supports the distribution of gift cards issued by top brands, are now working to solve that problem and enhance the gift card experience in general by bringing gift card services to the digital wallet.

This collaboration will provide an easy way for consumers to both purchase gift cards and use them right from within the PayPal app – beginning in the first half of 2014. Consumers will also be able to reload gift cards from the app, check balances and, of course, be able to keep all of their gift cards in one handy place.

This is yet another example of PayPal working with industry leaders to help bring merchants and consumers together in a way that makes life easier for the consumer and helps to increase sales and loyalty for the merchant.

In addition to collaborating on gift cards, PayPal and Blackhawk will also work together in other areas:

  • Distribution for the PayPal reloadable debit cards across a broad network of physical retail location
  • Integration of Blackhawk Network’s ReLoadIt network with PayPal’s prepaid debit and reloadable solutions, delivering convenient cash-in and account top-up solutions to PayPal consumers at tens of thousands of Blackhawk network retailer location 
Gift and Prepaid products are going through exciting changes to give consumers and merchants more utilities. Stay tuned for more innovation from PayPal in the coming months.

*Source: BHN research

title: Three Tips for Managing International Business Communications
content:
Oct 23
Marc Jaugey, Director of Communications + Social Media, PayPal EMEA


I'm half German and half French, I lived in Africa and the Middle East for the first 12 years of my life, and today I’m the director of Communications and Social Media at PayPal EMEA, a region that covers 100+ markets from France to Israel and from Spain to Russia. I’ve spent both my personal and professional life interacting with lots of different nationalities every single day.

Today, being a Spaniard at 10 AM, a German at 11, and then switching my mind to Swedish and Russian in the afternoon is an exercise I love. (Although it often takes time to revert back to a French father and husband again every evening.) But working with different cultures can be fairly challenging for most.

Over the years I’ve learned—sometimes the hard way—how to manage international situations in a business context, and while I'm sure I’ve made some mistakes and exhibited some tactlessness along the way, there are a few major tips I would give to anyone in a similar role. They’re not rocket science; just basic practices that I feel make my interactions at PayPal more efficient.

1. Always put yourself in others’ shoes

Misinterpretation is one of the most profound causes of friction in Communications, and obvious things are sometimes the most difficult to agree on as a group. This is a natural tendency for all of us. Anthropologists call it ethnocentrism, which is defined as the way we scale and rate others with reference to our own person or group, often leading us to consider ourselves as superior.

Example: Patriotism is a very important cultural element in Japan. You owe something to your birthplace as an individual. I can also see it as a strong element in the US, where the strength of the nation is part of everyone’s sensitivity.

On the opposite end, individuals in other countries are often less incline to analyze things through this lens, but more steered by a sense of history. (like the “ancient” Europe vs. the rest of the world.)

Because of this, I never try to give my specific sense to something, but always try to put myself in others’ shoes.

I always ask my audience, "Does this make sense for you?" Or, "Are you comfortable with this idea?" Checking step by step if we are all on the same page is crucial. And if I’m not sure, I just ask! I prefer to be seen as someone who has not understood than as someone who does not care.

2. Remember: Not everyone wakes up every day with the same goals

While I myself and most of my French or German colleagues are known for taking time to analyze the present before considering the future, many of my US and Indian peers approach the future with incredible ease.

Example: After seven years at PayPal, I'm still amazed how people—especially those in Silicon Valley—wake up daily with strong desire to "CHANGE THE WORLD.”

Understanding this passion was key to understanding many of my colleagues, and I have to admit that it took me 6 to 8 months to integrate this into my thinking. For me, this daily "risk factor" is tied to the "resistance to change” but guess what: this is an amazingly important component in an industry like payments, which is changing so fast, and in a company like PayPal that is constantly innovating and developing.

At the end of the day it’s important to recognize that we don’t all have the same goals nor the same way of getting things done. Some individuals need a long and detailed report to learn all lessons from an initiative before they can jump to the next one, while others are already working on their next event before the former one has ended!

So when it comes to business collaboration, I always make sure to align vision before moving to execution.

3. Avoid politics, be cautious with humor and always be on time

In my experience I’ve found that humor and politics hold the biggest evidence of cultural differences, making them the most difficult to communicate or understand.

Example: After many years of friendship, I'm still trying to explain to my US friends what "liberal" means in France. And I'm still trying to understand a joke that made all my Dutch colleagues burst out laughing.

In business relationships, I find it best to avoid these fields—particularly in e-mail where not only can meaning be lost, but tone as well—until I know my counterpart and feel comfortable with his or her knowledge of me as well. Communications don’t have to be stiff to be effective, but when speaking across geographies it’s smart to keep them gentle.

Another thing that I’m forcing myself to do is to be always on time. Whatever the cultural background might be, believe me, nobody will ever reproach you for being on time.

In Conclusion…
Boundaries are blurring and this is not a new circumstance. Marshall McLuhan famously described the "global village" in The Medium is the Message. This is true for businesses (size has become a crucial success factor) and this is true for people (we’re often asked to work with other countries, or even report to someone from another culture.)

In this context, success depends on how companies and individuals are able to take advantage of this. What are your tips for making the most of working across geographies? Please add them in the comments below!
