title: Changing the Way Brazilians Pay
content:
Oct 24
Hill Ferguson, Chief Product Officer, PayPal
I've spent the past week in Sao Paulo getting to know its rich culture and meeting some truly inspirational entrepreneurs and business partners. While aware of Brazil's tech-forward mindset, I have been enlivened by the startup spirit that is driving business in technology here. That's why I’m really excited to share some great news with you all today: Brazilians can now check in with their PayPal consumer app to pay, marking the first time we’ve offered an in-store payment option in this region.

More specifically, we’ve partnered with Suplicy Café in Sao Paulo to help coffee lovers get their fix without having to worry about cash or cards. And while caffeine during rush hour is certainly always a plus, the aim in launching this pilot is to learn more about our customers – both merchants and consumers – and help provide an easier way to pay that is right for the local market.

Since we opened our Brazilian offices in April 2011, our services in this area have been widely received by nearly 2 million active users. This country has an extremely tech-savvy community that’s always looking for opportunities to boost security and save time. For example, last year we announced a one-of-a-kind partnership with Vivo that allowed consumers to top up their minutes straight from their mobile device without a smartphone or an Internet connection.

Moreover, the potential in the Brazilian market for shaping the future of commerce continues to grow at a rapid rate. Numerically speaking, the number of individual mobile Internet users is expected to nearly triple over the next four years (reaching approximately 96.4 million in 2016), and we’re both excited and deeply honored to be able to help lead the way along with our partners. Obrigado to Café Suplicy – looking forward to what's to come next!

title: Location, Location, Location!
content:
Oct 24
Sarah Hodkinson, Director of Marketing and Sales Strategy, PayPal Media Network

US consumers will spend $37.44 billion in 2013 on retail purchases via smartphones and tablets, and retailers are working hard via mobile advertising to grab consumers’ attention. The golden question, of course, is will people engage with your ad? With that in mind, today we are revealing PayPal Media Network’s (PPMN) Location-Based Mobile Advertising: Q3 Highlights* showing how brands are increasing user engagement and boosting average click through rates (CTR) by 12 percent.

Digging into the average CTR number, we find the top three categories that saw the greatest growth from geo-fencing are:

  • Cable, Phone and Internet Services (with an amazing 59 percent)
  • Financial Services (18 percent)
  • Big Box Retailers (12 percent)
Multiple PPMN advertisers are leveraging geo-targeting to drive purchases, including Quick-Service Restaurants (100%) and big box stores (21%). And retailers in cities across the country are saying, by all means, please “fence-me-in” with New York, Los Angeles and Portland rounding out the top.

PPMN reaches 117M mobile US consumers (source: Nielsen). Based on the data, we even got to learn some fun stats about them:

  • 68 million people on our network shopped at a big box retailer in the past 30 days
  • 113,267 people who use PPMN own a hermit crab and drive a Smart Car
  • 59 million people who use PPMN buy groceries and are the primary decision makers on what to purchase
  • 335,412 people on our network regularly practice martial arts and played Bingo within the last 30 days
  • 45.8 million people on our network made a CPG purchase in-store in the past 6 months
  • 16.5 million people shopped for event tickets online in the past 30 days
We look forward to updating you on our Q4 report, which will of course feature holiday and year-end results.



*Report is based on mobile network performance reach of 117m per Nielsen for Q3 2013 (July, August and September).

title: In 2012, the Holidays Ate Halloween
content:
Sep 30
Anuj Nayar, Senior Director of Global Initiatives, PayPal

While at my local grocery store last week, I was amazed at all the pumpkins and Halloween candy already on display. The leaves haven’t even started to change color and yet the retail industry has already moved on to October 31st.

Then I remembered an amazing statistic that came out last year. Because PayPal processes nearly one-fifth of global e-commerce, we can see trends as they appear. Traditionally, we see a rise in PayPal transaction volume for holiday shopping that kicks off before Thanksgiving and continues until the end of December. However, when we looked at the data for 2012, we saw that the US holiday shopping season started on September 30th!

In the words of Jon Stewart of The Daily Show, "Christmas is so big now, it’s eating other holidays." It’s more than just the length of the season. Consumers remain hungry to snap up the best offers available, but today they are shopping from a global marketplace—not just the stores down the street. This is part of a much bigger trend: technology is fundamentally changing the retail calendar. Holiday shopping not only starts earlier and ends later, but new services such as eBay Now allow for the online shopping season to extend to Christmas Eve and more and more of us are shopping from our mobile devices at all times of day and night.

This is an incredible opportunity for both domestic and international merchants to tap into this phenomenon early. We recently released a report on what we called the modern day spice routes, which found the global cross border shopping opportunity to be worth more than $100 billion in the top 6 markets alone. Almost 100 million consumers around the world are shopping cross border and that number is expected to explode in the next few years.

So what are you waiting for? Despite the fact that the weather report says it’s hot and sunny in San Francisco and I’m wearing shorts today, the holiday shopping season is about to start. For merchants, this is a chance to take advantage of the extended season. For consumers, if you get in early, you can get the best deals from retailers selling from around the world.

title: PayPal Supports Habitat for Humanity of the Chesapeake’s Habitown Challenge
content:
Sep 27
Gary Marino, SVP of Global Financial Services, PayPal

While global commerce is a primary focus, we at PayPal are also extremely dedicated to enabling local communities to reach their goals. That’s why we’re raising funds to help support Habitat for Humanity of the Chesapeake.

The Maryland-based organization’s mission is to bring partners together to build decent, affordable homes that change lives, empower families and strengthen communities. In addition to helping out a wonderful cause, our Bill Me Later business was also built in Maryland, so supporting Habitat for Humanity is a great way for us to give something back.

If you’re in the area and would like to be involved, Habitat for Humanity of the Chesapeake is hosting the Habitown Challenge festival September 28th from 11-5 at West Shore Park in Baltimore’s Inner Harbor. The event aims to bolster the community and encourage empowering partnerships by bringing together Baltimore businesses and nonprofits.

As part of the Habitown Challenge there will be a judged competition to build an 8x10 structure, and our PayPal team’s submission will be an eBay store designed to reduce waste by using as many recycled materials as possible.

PayPal has set a fundraising goal of $10,000 as part of the challenge, and all proceeds will go directly to Habitat for Humanity of the Chesapeake. We believe that when a community has a common goal, great things can be accomplished. If you’d like to help us reach ours, you can make a donation.

title: 3 Tips for Finding Your Leadership Swagger
content:
Sept 30
Kristen Gohr, Head of Global Employee Communications, PayPal

Over the years, the shelves in my home office have filled themselves with books on leadership – 87 to be exact. Topics range from execution and decision making to why nice girls don’t get the corner office, and I’ve read (or at least started to read) each and every single one.

I’ve spent the past twenty years reading about leadership and the last 15 practicing it, and yet the biggest a-ha moment -- the moment I genuinely believed I found my true leadership swagger -- came sometime in the past three years working at PayPal.

Making a Change for Authenticity

Anyone who has ever worked at a large corporation knows employee communications are typically dry, boring, and peppered with words that are long on syllables and short on meaning. Pop culture frequently speaks to this reality–Dilbert, The Office, Office Space, etc.—because so many of us would rather count the number of dust specks on our desk than read another “Letter from the CEO.” For years I too fell in line with these industry norms and admittedly wrote hundreds, if not thousands of “circular file” worthy communications.

But that changed when I came to PayPal. Over time the company’s culture, people, and the purpose of the work I do here served as a forcing function, propelling me towards becoming a more authentic leader. Ultimately, I had to dig deep and be more transparent and human than I’d ever been in my life.

I knew that if I was going to authentically lead and accurately represent the brand and our culture, I couldn’t accept the same old “buzz-word of the month” type of communication I’d produced for so long. So I didn’t. Instead, I started working towards a 180-degree transformation - embracing and demanding authenticity from not just myself, but also everyone on my team. Now we use communications guidelines like, “Keep it human – if you wouldn’t say it like this to your friends, don’t write or say it.” I spend less time worrying about proper punctuation, and more time trying to show our employees what we’re all about: Putting our customers first. Craftsmanship. Passion. Being a disruptive force for good.

We do this through straightforward, honest and genuine words that are sometimes funny, sometimes abrupt and a bit startling, but (hopefully) never fake. We might not always get it right – we still have moments where we overuse crunchy corporate words like “strategy” and “leverage” – but we’re heading in the right direction.

3 Tips for Finding Your Leadership Swagger

The point is that being authentic leader - whether you’re a person or a company - means facing your reality head on: the good and the bad. So here are my top three tips on how I face reality every day and am using this to become a more authentic leader:

1. Stop reading leadership books. Ok, you don’t have to stop completely, but at least stop trying to emulate every new hot leadership approach that’s out there – including the ones about authentic leadership. I try to give myself the freedom to do what I think is right for me. I learned a long time ago that if doesn’t feel natural, it probably looks even less natural to those on the receiving end. Leadership at its core is about being real and genuine, not about becoming a mold of others. Your true self can and will inspire others around you to be their best.

2. Learn about yourself. This seems obvious, but seriously, get clear on what you’re good at and make it your job (I like to use Gallup’s Strengthfinders and other tests like MBTI). I’m passionate about the work I do partially because I can be successful at doing it. It taps into the core of who I am. Knowing what you’re not so good at is equally important. I’ve had an unofficial “personal board of directors” for years. They’re people that I trust, and I seek their feedback on a regular basis. Often times they see my strengths and weaknesses more clearly than I can. I never mask my shortcoming, I embrace them and I don’t let them hold me back from being who I am. I encourage others around me to do the same, so that I can learn what makes them tick, too.

3. Give grace. Give grace to yourself and everyone around you. It’s hard to admit sometimes (because I’m a recovering perfectionist), but I’m not the perfect leader, colleague, dog mom, spouse or friend. But neither are the people I work with. What’s important on my team is that we face it together, and we help each other move past whatever is holding us back from being great. No judgments, no political maneuvering. Just straightforward, transparent and honest communication with each other.

title: Austin Showcases Top Talent in Global Battle Hack
content:

Jonathan LeBlanc, Global Head of Developer Evangelism, PayPal

Austin’s thriving developer community turned out in full force for PayPal’s latest Battle Hack, which took place at Tech Shop Austin-Round Rock this past weekend. After 24 hours of stiff competition, ten teams were ready to present their apps to the panel of judges.

It was truly an innovation showdown between the top contenders and left our judges with a tough decision. Big thanks to our judging panel including Jen Wojcik with Auspex Group Inc. (@TheJenATX), Bob Le Vitus at Houston Chronicle (@LeVitus), Manish Mehta with Mass Relevance (@mcmehta) and Joe Peck from Tech Shop (@techshop) for their time and expertise.

In the end, Jeff Linwood and his app PayPup came out ahead of the pack to win first place. PayPup is an app that helps match potential owners with dogs at Austin Pets Alive. PayPup lists all dogs available for adoption and allows you to donate directly to help pay for their various medical expenses. For example, with the app you could see that Max, a lovable two-year-old dog, is due for his next vaccinations and then be able to donate directly to help pay for them.

Rounding out the winner’s podium were Tap to Pay and Trust in Dragons.

Tap to Pay, created by Lana Jones and Alejandro Vidal took second place. Lana and Alejandro met for the first time on Saturday and worked late into the night to finish the event’s only hardware hack. Tap to Pay is an affordable 'cash register' via your mobile device, leveraging Raspberry Pi and an acrylic housing unit. Locked in at third place was Trust in Dragons, a crowd-funding platform for non-government organizations that ensures transparency and accountability with gamification features. You can check out the other innovative app ideas from Austin’s competitors here.

title: PayPal Takes Your Security Seriously
content:
Jan 29, 2014
Editor, PayPal Forward

At PayPal the security of your personal and financial information is our top priority. From our customer service department to the teams creating new products, security is always top of mind.

By now, many of you have read about the difficult situation one of our customers faced with regard to his online and social identity.

As we do with all incidents of this nature, we immediately began an investigation to understand the details of the case. While it is against our policies to discuss details related to our customers' accounts, we did want to provide at least a few facts publicly.

  • We have carefully reviewed our records and can confirm that there was a failed attempt made to gain this customer’s information by contacting PayPal.
  • PayPal did not divulge any credit card details related to this account.
  • PayPal did not divulge any personal or financial information related to this account.
  • This individual's PayPal account was not compromised.  
Our customer service agents are well trained to prevent social hacking attempts like the ones detailed in this blog post.

We are personally reaching out to the customer to see if we can assist him in any way.

We work constantly to ensure that PayPal’s validation and security processes are amongst the best in the industry and encourage our customers to be aware of the simple steps they can take to help prevent these types of crimes. You will find helpful information and tips on our Security Center.

title: Ready. Set. Code. Battle Hack Gets Underway in Tel Aviv
content:
Feb 12, 2014
John Lunn, Global Director, PayPal Developer Network, PayPal

It’s official. PayPal’s 2014 Battle Hack is underway. After a sleepless night of coding, with the support of dozens of cups of coffee, beer, pizzas and even professional on-the-house massages, the 200 developers in Tel Aviv put their coding abilities to the test. From social jogging to zombie runners, over 30 apps to help solve local and global problems were conceived in just 24 hours last weekend at Reading 3, a commercial and entertainment district in Tel Aviv.

The winner? Israeli app Socializr puts socializing back in the REAL world instead of the virtual one by keeping people away from their mobile phones with a gamification effect. That’s right. We said away.

Developed by Shai Mishali, Pavel Kaminsky and Rotem Tsabary, they pointed out that more and more people are bound to their mobile phones even when they are with their friends. So they developed the Socializr app where a user can challenge his/her friends to avoid checking their mobile phones for a given time. This social game keeps the mobile phones in the pocket and gives friends a chance to interact.

But it also gives back. All the users participating in the game use PayPal to donate any amount of money to a local charity on behalf of the winner of the game.

The second annual Tel Aviv Battle Hack 2014 was judged by GetTaxi’s CTO David Drai, Geektime CEO Moran Bar, and SpeedUp Chairman Tal Barnoach.

The runner up was the application Focus, developed by Itay Galim, Shahar Levinstein, and Alik Hochner. The app aimed to stop young people from driving under the influence; the user can test their sobriety by playing a game and sending a video to a friend. The app also proposes a cab calling service.

The Socializr developers will fly to the world finals in San Jose and battle teams from cities like San Francisco, Istanbul, London and Moscow for the grand prize of $100,000 USD. Runner-ups at the Tel Aviv event won PS4 gaming consoles and third placers won smart Fitbit wristbands. Our next battle hack is in Miami on February 22 – 23.

Happy coding!

title: Causes We Love: Movember
content:
Feb 14, 2014
Clam Lorenz, Director, Nonprofit Engagement, PayPal

Ever wonder why all those mustaches appear when November rolls around? It’s not just seasonal love for facial hair. I sat down with Mark Hedstrom, County Director, Movember U.S., to talk about what his organization stands for and how we can all start planning to help out a good cause.

Can you share any background and/or fun facts about the organization?

Movember is a global health charity that encourages men to grow and all to support a moustache for the 30 days of November. Through the power of the moustache, awareness and funds are raised for men’s health to combat prostate and testicular cancer.

Since 2003, when Movember began in Melbourne, Australia, over 4 million men and women in 21 countries have raised $550 million for men's health, funding 577 programs globally in the areas of education and awareness, living with and beyond cancer, and prostate and testicular cancer research. All through the power of the moustache!

What makes the organization unique? Why would someone support you?

Movember seeks to shake up the way prostate cancer research is approached and strives to accelerate outcomes that matter to men living with the disease.

Today we’re driving unprecedented levels of global collaboration in translational research (research that can be turned into treatments and therapies) through Movember’s Global Action Plan (GAP) initiative.

Prior to creating the GAP initiative in 2010, Movember found that prostate cancer researchers often work on similar projects, unaware of or unable to work with researchers in other countries, ultimately slowing scientific advancement. Today there are five GAP projects underway, which have brought together more than 250 of the world's top prostate and testicular cancer researchers, all of whom are committed to working together and sharing their knowledge in the area.

What are some of your biggest challenges in getting support?

As a nonprofit organization, Movember U.S. runs a lean team with 14 full-time staff members working to raise awareness and funds for critical men’s health causes in a country of over 313 million people. That is no easy task.

We are humbled and honored to have had over 219,000 men and women sign up to participate in the U.S. last year!

How does the organization currently use PayPal?

Movember currently uses PayPal to accept donations on movember.com.

Why do you like using PayPal to collect donations? Do you use it for anything else? Do your customers like using PayPal?

PayPal is a very popular form of payment, and it provides an easy way for our customers to donate to Movember and the men’s health cause. Before Movember used PayPal, the organization received requests from donors to accept donations via PayPal.

How can others get involved in your organization’s cause?

Participation is really simple. Participants start by signing up at Movember.com to grow or support a moustache. Men start November 1st, clean-shaven, and grow their moustache for 30 days, getting friends, family and colleagues to donate to their Mo-growing efforts. Everyone celebrates their journey at the end of Movember at official costumed Movember Gala Partés, or they can host their own event.

Would you recommend PayPal to another nonprofit? Why?

Yes, we would recommend PayPal to another nonprofit. It’s an extremely easy and cost effective way to accept donations!

title: App Update: Why is the PayPal App Asking for Permission to Send SMS?
content:
Feb 13, 2014
Gagan Shah, Senior Product Manager, PayPal Mobile

Since it’s your money that we help manage, we feel it is our responsibility to keep your account extra secure. That’s why we’re beefing up security in the latest version of PayPal’s Android app that went live today and in the iPhone app update that is coming soon.

In the Android app, one of things you’ll notice is that we now ask for your permission to “send SMS messages”– or what most people call text messages. For iPhone users, you’ll see a notification in your Settings tab to do a “Phone Verification” which basically gives us permission to do the same thing. By allowing your Android and iPhone apps to send a text message to PayPal, we can do a one-time confirmation that lets us know that you own a particular device. This permission helps us prevent fraudulent account takeovers. To be very clear: we only have your permission to send an SMS; we do not have access to read or receive SMS on your behalf.

It’s a really fast and easy way to help keep your account secure. A prompt will appear in your PayPal app immediately after it’s been updated. Simply click “Secure My Phone” and you’re done. (I promise, it’s that easy.)

In light of the recent security breaches in the news, it’s more important than ever to help our customers keep their accounts secure. One small step like this helps make it more difficult for fraudsters. As always, your security is our top priority.

If you have any questions about this update, don’t hesitate to drop us a comment or reach out to us on Twitter @AskPayPal.

title: Old vs. New Business Collaboration: PayPal Changes the Way Enterprise Teams are Built
content:

Nona Renfro , Director of Talent Acquisition, PayPal

As part of our never-ending quest to build the best teams, Global Talent Acquisition (GTA) leaders across PayPal, eBay and StubHub recently brought their troops together for a session of Applicant Management & Communications training. The result: the implementation of the new “ONE Applicant Experience” initiative, which utilizes a single format for hiring employees.

One Process Under eBay Inc.

Prior to this training, eBay, PayPal and StubHub’s Talent Acquisition departments were operating as individual units, meaning they were conducting similar processes to hire, but nothing was done the same.

For companies as large as ours, such an approach simply doesn’t make sense. With eBay Inc. hiring over 12,000 employees in the year 2013, it is critical for our GTA teams to follow the same steps for all eBay Inc. entities and locations. This way all of our applicants will be brought to the eBay Inc. team with the same on boarding experience no matter what entity or locations they are hired through.

We’re Going World-Class

In addition to getting all our people on the same page from the very start, the implementation of the ONE APPLICANT EXPERIENCE aims to change the future of our business. Being able to hire applicants under the same structure worldwide will provide flexibility for all Recruiters in GTA, and allows recruiters to assist other regions when high volume hiring is needed (as well as support each other when others are absent).

Our training session took a total of three days. The first two included a majority of the information using Power Points and the live systems to work through examples from the slides. It also allowed the different teams to discuss and collaborate on ideas for how to best move forward with the new systems. During the final day, GTA members were allowed to explore and work through the system on their own.

Reactions were extremely positive and everyone was excited to see the new changes and start hiring with the new system. In particular, team members were happy to know they could reach out to any GTA recruiter globally and ask questions about the system because everyone was now under the same structure.

All in all, we think this was the right step to take for our business. Implementing one process across the board addresses the need to stay aligned in the face of increasing mobility and expansion. What are some things your company is doing to synchronize teams?

title: Mobile Monday? Cyber Monday 2013 by the Numbers
content:
Dec 04, 2013
Stacy General, PayPal Customer Experience Advocate

Despite the melding of traditional shopping holidays (is it just us or does it seem more like Black Friday Week at this point?) Cyber Monday still packs a punch with retailers offering great deals online and via mobile to workers returning to the office ready for a day of work…and shopping. Traditionally, known as THE day for online sales, the increase in mobile shoppers on Thanksgiving and Black Friday has redefined this day of deals as less dependent on the desktop in your cube, and more about getting those deals wherever you might be since your smartphone rarely leaves your side.

So, how did Cyber Monday 2013 stack up? According to PayPal data, consumers continued to turn to their mobile devices to conduct their shopping, following what we saw on Thanksgiving and Black Friday 2013 as consumers expect to shop and pay at their convenience during the holiday season.

Shoppers in Houston, Chicago and Los Angeles logged on to PayPal via their mobile devices the most, followed by Miami and New York. Overall, PayPal data shows that, on Cyber Monday 2013, there was a 93.6% increase in consumers shopping through PayPal on their mobile devices and a 115.6% increase in global mobile TPV (total payment volume) compared to Cyber Monday 2012. While much has been made of people shopping while on the job, the most popular time to shop via PayPal came after the work day was over – 6:00pm to 7:00pm PT saw the highest frequency of mobile shopping via PayPal in the US.

With the holiday shopping kickoff over, do you have everyone checked off your list?

title: 2013: The Year of the Digital Donation
content:
Jan 03, 2014
Clam Lorenz, Director, Nonprofit Engagement, PayPal

Each year, the month of December brings with it many things – the holiday season, a surge in retail sales and the anticipation of a fresh start in the New Year. However, for charities, December brings with it something else entirely – the promise of critical year-end donations. In fact, according to Network for Good, 30% of all giving occurs the last month of the year, and 10% of all giving in the last three days of the year.

PayPal saw similar results. Today, we’re proud to report that total charitable giving through PayPal in the month of December 2013 reached $142.7 million dollars, a 36% increase from the month of December 2012! The last three days of December 2013 had the most dollars of charitable donations, totaling nearly $45.5 million dollars on December 29, December 30 and December 31, 2013.

At PayPal, we are committed to empowering worthy causes to receive more through technology-based solutions. We believe that online and mobile giving is on the rise, in demand, and has the power to significantly increase fundraising for nonprofits in the near future. Total charitable giving through PayPal in 2013 was $633.8 million dollars and resulted in a 34% increase from charitable giving in 2012. When looking at online and mobile donations specifically, online giving in 2013 increased 21% over 2012, for a total of $570.7 million donated; mobile giving totaled $63.1 million dollars in 2013. We believe online and mobile donations will continue to increase, but our work here is far from complete. Nonprofits still need to adopt disruptive giving solutions that are more in line with the way consumers are communicating, doing business and making transactions. And, PayPal is committed to continuing to do our part in powering mobile and online giving year-round into 2014 and beyond.

Because digital giving is easier and more efficient for donors and charities alike, we want to thank all of our users who contributed during the “Stamp Out Checks…For Good” campaign. But this year, why wait until December to check “give back more” off your list of New Year’s Resolutions? Visit your favorite organization’s website today, or visit paypal-donations.com and start making automated monthly donations with PayPal!

title: PayPal Announces Check-In Pilot in Berlin
content:

Arnulf Keese, Vice President and General Manager, PayPal DE/AT/CH
Towards the end of November, we were happy to announce the launch of our pilot Check-In program in Berlin. Now, a variety of local cafes and restaurants – and any other participating merchants – can offer their customers a walletless transaction. All that’s needed is a smartphone and the PayPal app.

With the new “Shops” tab, customers show the merchant that they are in their place of business. The merchant sees the customer’s profile image and can process the payment via the customer’s PayPal account. The customer then receives a confirmation of the amount they paid as well as a receipt.


This pilot project is another important step towards a cashless future. By this new way of paying, we not only ensure that customers can buy what they want even if they don’t have the right amount of cash on them, but also that merchants of all sizes can be an active part of the innovative future of commerce.

Personally, I think PayPal has defined a great new cashless consumer experience making use of your everyday device to make everyday purchases. Special thanks to our team that made this possible.

Currently, Berlin’s participating shops and restaurants include Du Bonheur, hosskost Berlin, MAKI, Mogg & Melzer, momos, Noodeli, ocelot, Shoenschmecker Deli, The Barn and The Barn Roastery. Where else would you like to be able to forgo your wallet? Let us know in the comments below!

title: A Collaborative Vision Unlocks Business Success
content:
Jan 07, 2014
Walter Hafner, Global Operations, PayPal EMEA


When I joined PayPal five years ago, my main rationale was to work in an international environment. At the time I didn’t put too much thought into what motivated me beyond the fact that working abroad is an invaluable experience both from a career and personal perspective.

When preparing for interviews, I read the book The Perfect Store: Inside eBayby Adam Cohen, which talks about eBay’s early days and how Pierre Omidyar engaged with the online community of his AuctionWeb platform, which he transformed into a multi-billion dollar business less than a decade later. I was impressed by Pierre’s philosophical approach to business and his objective to remove market imperfections through his platform.

But, quite frankly, PayPal in 2009 looked less philosophical. A lot of groundwork had to be done to organize better and to make life easier for customers. The problem? In the constant conflict between time to market and customer experience, people rarely lift their heads up to think about purpose. However, PayPal was committed to improving, and in my humble opinion, we’ve come a long way. Today customers are more likely to recommend us, as are our employees – and not only because we are a fast growing business which provides job opportunity. Why is that?

We defined our vision…

An enormous amount of thought has been put into our organization by our leaders. John Donahoe and David Marcus personally took the time to travel around the globe at the beginning of 2013 to talk about why great companies are built on a shared purpose and define what eBay Inc. wants to stand for in our communities.

The amount of change these presentations caused can’t be overstated. I felt valued and proud as an employee due to the fact that our leaders took the time to communicate this message to more than 10,000 employees around the globe in person. Hearing John Donahoe talk about eBay founder Pierre Omidyar’s vision for our company was inspiring. This was truly a special moment in my career and I am sure a lot of my colleagues feel the same.

…And became a team.

The reason I felt this way was because I had trust that the message delivered by John Donahoe and David Marcus was consistent with actions that can be observed. In the same way that PayPal is committed to creating a great customer experience, our leadership team is committed to creating a great employee experience far beyond competitive incentives. For example, over the last five years, I have been able to observe how much rigour has been put into team building and talent development in PayPal Global Operations, and into building not only a customer-centric, but also an employee-centric culture.

A culture that allows for work-life balance and treats remployees like grown-ups who get the job done no matter where they are. A culture that empowers employees to make the right decisions on behalf of our customers. A culture that allows people with different backgrounds to succeed in a truly global company.

A lot of companies have high aspirations regarding their culture but aren’t sure how to go about shaping it. For PayPal, it’s obvious that that first, powerful step has been building a shared purpose that translates into inspiration. Another recent example that shows PayPal’s commitment to bringing our company culture to life: every manager in Global Operations is attending two full days of diversity and inclusion training – an investment that underscores how serious our leaders take our culture.

For me, these are all small pieces of a big mosaic coming together which makes me feel I am in the right place. Different to where I was five years ago, today I know I work for PayPal not because it’s abroad, but because I have the opportunity to have an impact in a company that aligns with my values. There may still be some pieces missing, but I am excited to be part of a team that is committed to complete the work.

What has been the most inspiring moment for you at your place of business? Was it reflective of a shared purpose or something else?

title: Summit Stories Climbs Mount Kilimanjaro with PayPal in Tow
content:
Jan 10, 2014
Chelsi Nakano, Content Manager, PayPal

While many of us are still patiently waiting for technology to bring us up to speed with The Jetsons, one of the coolest turns in recent efforts has had nothing to do with flying cars and everything to do with giving back to society.

For example, Francesco Rovetta of Summit Stories decided to combine his two passions -- technology and mountaineering -- to raise twenty thousand dollars for Amani, a Tanzanian center for street children. The technology part was easy, as many technophiles were eager to join the trek in order to use their skill sets for good. The tough part? Climbing Mount Kilimanjaro.

I had the opportunity to ask Francesco a round of questions regarding the journey, how technology helped, and what’s up next for both Summit Stories and innovation.

Tell me a bit about how you got the idea to combine your Silicon Valley skill sets with your favorite hobby.

Climbing a mountain is very much like running a business: it is essential to be prepared for the possible challenges, to manage the risk of the unexpected, to have the right team in place, and push through the multiple milestones with the right combination of motivation and realistic ambition.

Having worked at PayPal and in tech for many years, my high level of sensitivity to innovation spurred the idea of leveraging technology to support a major mountaineering feat. While good legs are still necessary to chew uphill miles, mobile technologies can help monitor our progress and our fitness status, and keep us in touch with the rest of the world.

And how did Amani land on your radar?

While researching a non-profit partner for our Kilimanjaro trek, I wanted to identify an organization that was deeply involved with the local community, while developing a plan for sustainable growth. These are often the ingredients for a successful path.

Amani, which received a grant from the eBay Foundation last year, has been successfully operating for over 10 years in Tanzania and its model (to support street children with in-house programs and then fully reintegrate them into their families or communities) is being adopted by other organizations.

While relatively small, Amani is currently providing support to over 200 children every year and is planning to open a new welcome center in 2014. The Kilimanjaro trek fundraised specifically for this center.

What were the different instances in which technology helped you and your team streamline the trek?

For our fundraising efforts we used PayPal services, whether through face-to-face donations using PayPal Here, the mobile app, or the APIs leveraging a partner’s crowd-funding platform. We even accepted donations and made payments on the trek above 10,000ft.

We also used other technologies from KiliTechTrek sponsors such as GoalZero (a leading provider of portable solar panels), Eye-Fi (Maker of WiFi memory cards that automatically transfer photos to mobile device), and Runtastic (producer of mobile solutions to track fitness and sport activities).

There is no better sight than seeing a geeky group playing with and enjoying cool technologies while doing good!

How would you say mobile adoption has gone in Tanzania, and what does that say about technology overall?

Like Tanzania, most African countries have literally taken a fast track on the development cycle of the telecom and Internet infrastructure and embraced wireless as their baseline platforms from day one. This spearheaded the diffusion of both basic and advanced mobile services, as it has been the case for the world-famous mobile money transfer service M-Pesa, which allows villages from remote areas to immediately enter and participate into the wider economic cycle.

While connectivity remains far from ubiquitous, it is also allowing the emergence of new models in the field of education where, for example, new topics can be taught and knowledge can be shared across a wider network of education centers.

What were the gaps you and your group found along the way? If you could create a Jetsons-like wish list for the technological world, what would be on it?

We certainly experienced some gaps in connectivity – a very remote area especially at high elevation doesn’t necessarily see the same human traffic as in an urban setting – therefore the regular social media peeking was less at hand. We had a good support in terms of checking our health status, yet I do believe there is ample room for preventative monitoring of conditions in such an oxygen deprived and harsh environment.

We also definitely missed the comfort of our favorite food and I wonder if drones will help overcome some of this in the future.

What’s next for Summit Stories, and also, where do you see an opportunity for technology to improve an existing process? What areas of our life can technology still summit?

Summit Stories’ next expedition will be to Nepal this April: a group of technophiles will trek to Everest Base Camp to fundraise for a local non-profit while using technologies along the way. The tech angles of this trek are Wearables and Drones. We are partnering with innovative companies to adopt unique solutions and products to play with at and around 15,000ft.

These are just a couple of areas that will see a dramatic adoption in the coming years, not only to improve the lifestyle of users but also to streamline operations for enterprises (think about monitoring and delivery to and from remote regions).

title: 14 NRF 2014: The Receipt Offers Opportunity
content:
Jan 14, 2014
Carey Kolaja, Vice President, Global Product Solutions, PayPal

More than anything else, what makes this an exciting time to work in the payments industry is the chance to reexamine every aspect of how we shop and pay, and to ask fundamental questions about the value and convenience that is being created – or hindered – be each step of the process. From discovery to offers to checkout, and from loyalty programs to ordering, fulfillment, and even returns, there are incredible opportunities to eliminate unnecessary friction points and unlock information that can make shopping experiences faster, or more fun, or more personal.

The receipt is a good example. The printed paper record of past purchases seems necessary. Without it, how would you establish proof of payment for a particular item or service?

But there’s something about it that also makes it feel like an unwelcome remnant of an old way of doing things. Is there any more obvious bit of friction in the entire purchasing process than the wad of receipts stuffed in your wallet? Merchants offer them mostly in case evidence of purchase is required at some later date for anything from returns to expense reports to taxes, depending on where you are in the world. As consumers, we hold onto them because we have to, not because we want to.

Still, there are those who suggest that the receipt is a hidden vein of untapped data that can somehow be mined to influence future shopping decisions. And while receipts do contain information about where and when customers shop and how much they pay that hints at further insights about purchasing preferences and patterns, I believe its value as a predictor of future behavior is sharply limited. Rather than an indicator of what consumers are likely to do down the road, receipts are useful mostly as a way to retrace the path they followed in the past.

In this way, receipts are a little like the fossilized dinosaur tracks that paleontologists have found preserved near ancient bodies of water: while they offer tantalizing indirect evidence of past activities, they tell us only a very modest amount about the habits, personalities, or needs of the creatures that left them, and nothing about what they did in the minutes, months, or years after they left their footprints behind.

For merchants, it’s where consumers are going next – and why they’re going there – that really matters. To create the kind of complete portrait of an individual that can drive deeper engagement and more lasting loyalty, it takes more than just the location, time, and price of past purchases. Much richer indications of future intentions can be found in the clues people offer when they click on a jacket while browsing online or pick up a pair of pants off the rack at a store. New web tracking technology, new in-store beacons, new tools like something called “dwell time analytics” tie these together with the record of past purchases contained in a receipt, and you begin to get the kind of complete picture of a consumer’s needs and wants that can truly transform the relationship between a retailer and its customers.

The key here, though, is the concept of individual identity. The potential for customers and retailers to connect in more meaningful and human ways is very powerful, but whether this potential is fulfilled will ultimately depend on how much information consumers choose to share about their preferences and desires. In the end, this will be a matter of trust. Is information and financial data safe and secure? Is privacy respected? Is real value offered in return for the information that is shared? Is shopping truly made more convenient or more fun?

These are the questions that we ask every day at PayPal and the principles that we’re focused on. And while the receipt can certainly play a useful role as an artifact of past shopping activity, to create the kind of long-term relationship that people prefer and merchants seek, a much broader view of is required.

title: PayPal Looks Ahead: Six Predictions for 2014
content:
Dec 11, 2013
David Marcus, President, PayPal

Prediction lists are everywhere this time of year and they often have more to do with sounding clever than sharing insight. So I hesitated last year when a colleague encouraged me to blog about key trends to watch for in the payments industry in 2013.

In the end, though, I had a lot of fun writing Looking Ahead to 2013. It was great to go on record with my thoughts about key trends affecting payments. And the blog prompted some fascinating conversations about how technology is transforming shopping experiences.

Last year I highlighted four “thought starters”—the continuing lack of adoption of NFC technology at the cash register; the merger of payments, loyalty programs, and coupons; the rise of mobile cash registers, and the beginning of location-aware, context-relevant shopping and payment experiences. The reality of 2013 wasn’t too far off… so I decided to give it another shot this year.

My job at PayPal gives me a unique opportunity to work with peers and strategize with partners across many industries about solving real problems and delivering exciting new experiences for consumers and retailers. That leads to a pretty privileged view into what’s coming next.

So here are my predictions for 2014:

1. Traditional retail fights back

In recent years, technology innovation from companies has disrupted traditional retail by making it easy for consumers to browse in a store and then buy online at the cheapest possible price. It’s a practice called “showrooming” and in-store merchants understandably hate it. This year, retailers will start leveraging and converting their retail footprint into logistical assets to enable shoppers to buy anywhere they want: in-store, on mobile, and on the web, and get fast-delivery, or pick-up in store the same day. Local will be more important than ever – and from our perspective we couldn't be more excited about innovations like PayPal Beacon which will transform the retail environment for your local main street by bringing back opportunities for personalized service all driven by mobile.

2. Mobile will transform commerce forever

If you work for a payment technology company, this prediction won’t be a surprise. But many consumers are just beginning to experience the freedom, flexibility, and fun of mobile payments and shopping, and they’re going to want more. This will lead to a flood of new payment experiences built on technologies such as sensors, geolocation, and the cloud that will soon make standing in a long checkout line and paying with a card seem like something out of the Stone Age.

3. iOS and Android will drive a retail revolution

Last year, I predicted the beginning of the end of the fixed-location cash register in favor of mobile checkout technology. In 2014, the entire retail infrastructure will follow suit. And why not! In less than four years since the launch of the iPad, tablets have become a fixture of our everyday lives. This year, they’ll become a standard tool in retail environments too, and merchants will use them for everything from Point of Sale to inventory, fulfillment, customer relationship management, and more.

4. Bitcoin will continue to gain ground (but not as a currency)

Bitcoin will continue to attract more people as a store of value and a speculative investment asset. I predict that the value of Bitcoin still has the potential to double (as of December 11, 2013 at 8:08 AM PT: 1 BTC = 915 USD) by the same time next year. But I believe it will have a hard time becoming mainstream as a currency, due to its expected continued volatility amidst regulation authorities and governments figuring out what to make of the cryptocurrency.

5. The year of disruption . . .

I love disruption—it’s when rules get broken and new ideas are born and tested that things get interesting. This trend has been gathering momentum over the last year or so as smaller players in the payments industry power a wave of startups that use mobile payments to fuel segment-transforming new business models. (Full disclosure: PayPal recently acquired Braintree, which provides the payment technology engine behind disruptive startups like Uber, Airbnb, and OpenTable.)

In 2014, you’ll see larger payments entities scramble to accelerate the pace of their innovation to catch up to these smaller and more nimble competitors. Meanwhile, smaller players will scramble to achieve the scale and experience needed to compete in a global business. As a result, billions of dollars will be at play in the payment industry, and 2014 will be a year of game-changing disruption.

6. . . . and consolidation in the payments industry

Our industry has a lot of players. Too many. No doubt there’s a ton of great innovation out there, but a lot of it works better in combination than on its own. And some of today’s bright young firms will never achieve the scale to survive without joining forces with someone bigger. This will lead to a wave of acquisitions in 2014. Meanwhile, new alliances will create intriguing partnerships that span payments, retail, and more. It simply won’t be the same industry in 12 months that it is today.

So that’s where I see payments headed in 2014. If you think there are other trends that I missed, I’d love to hear your thoughts. And whether you agree or disagree with my thought starters, I think we can all agree that this industry is in the midst of incredible and exciting change right now. It’s going to be an amazing ride over the next 12 months.

title: NRF 2014: A New Online Checkout Experience, Payment Code is Rolling and PayPal Beacon Update
content:
Jan 12, 2014
Don Kingsborough, Vice President of Retail Services, PayPal


It’s great to be in New York for NRF 2014, this year’s edition of the National Retail Federation’s annual event commonly referred to as the Big Show, and with good reason. The overwhelming scale of this yearly gathering of the retail industry makes it an occasion that can’t be missed if you care about the fast-changing world of shopping and selling.

Last year’s Big Show marked a pivotal moment for PayPal as we showcased our move into the offline world with the announcement that consumers could pay for their purchases with PayPal at 18,000 merchant locations across the United States. We’ve enjoyed an incredibly busy and successful year since then. During 2013, thanks to our collaboration with Discover and merchant acquiring partners, and through our direct relationships with U.S. retailers, 1.9 million merchant locations in the U.S. have now committed to accept PayPal payments. We also launched our new PayPal app, announced PayPal Beacon and payment code, acquired Braintree, and much more.

Every one of these steps was designed to serve a much larger purpose. Our goal is to deliver shopping experiences that are more convenient, more personal, and more fun for consumers, and more profitable for merchants by making it easier to shop and pay from anywhere and at any time – in-store during regular shopping hours, or on a mobile device, tablet, or PC from your office, your bed, while you’re riding the bus, or any place else you can imagine.

Seamless Online Checkout

This year, we’ll accelerate the pace of innovation as we continue to lead the push to transform the shopping experience by delivering greater value to merchants and their customers. At NRF 2014 we’re showcasing advances that are already making the future of retail today’s reality for many retailers, starting with a completely redesigned online checkout experience for large merchants. Now, when customers pay with PayPal online, the entire checkout experience can happen entirely within the merchant website, in a process that takes just a few seconds and requires fewer steps than before. In addition, merchants only need to do one integration to get the same seamless checkout experience on a computer, tablet, or smartphone.

Here's a peek at how it works:

We’re currently piloting this new checkout experience with a few partners and we’ll make it more generally available to large merchants during the first half of this year. Of course we plan to roll it out to small and medium sized merchants very soon as well.

Later this year, merchants will be able to do one integration to get Log In with PayPal functionality as part of the new online checkout experience, enabling consumers to log into a merchant’s website with PayPal instead of creating another username and password. Merchants get to know their customers better and consumers get a much easier checkout experience when shopping on a merchant’s site. If you are logged in and check out, all of your shipping, preferences and payment information is automatically populated. All you need to do is click the checkout button and you're done.

Mobile Commerce Comes to the Store with Payment Code and Beacon

We’re also focused on delivering innovative ways for merchants to take full advantage of the power of mobile devices within their food service and retail locations. One example is the recent announcement of payment code, a technology that enables consumers to use a QR code or four-digit short code to pay in-store using a smartphone.

At NRF 2014, we’re also announcing that we’ve been working closely with MICROS and Discover to make payment code available to their merchants. Starting in February, many MICROS and Discover merchants will be able to upgrade software in existing terminals, via a small integration, to accept payments from customers who want to pay with PayPal using their smartphones, either by scanning a QR code or entering a four-digit short code into a PIN pad.

I am pleased to share that payment code is already available at more than 1,500 locations in the UK. Additionally, it is available as a payment method across hundreds of taxis in Canberra, Australia, with the goal to rollout to thousands more by mid 2014.

Here’s how it works:

I’m also thrilled to share a quick update on PayPal Beacon, which has been one of the industry’s hottest topics since we announced it in September. Right now, we’re testing it at a few merchant locations in the U.S. and Australia, and soon we’ll start testing with additional merchants in the U.K., Canada, France, and Germany.

We’re hard at work integrating Beacon into the PayPal app, and we expect to complete that work early in 2014, at which point we will be excited to begin making this next-generation shopping experience available to consumers. So, if you want to be among the first merchants to offer the kind of hands-free, highly personal experience that only Beacon can provide – or to help us test Beacon – please visit www.paypal.com/beacon to learn more.

Connect with PayPal at the Big Show

I’m thrilled to be in New York for NRF 2014 for another reason: it’s a great place to catch up with colleagues, partners, and friends from across the industry, and an ideal opportunity to make new connections and share ideas and hear feedback.

If you’re in New York for the Big Show, please stop by the PayPal booth (#4245) to say hello. And I encourage you to mark your calendar on January 14 at 2pm as I join a panel of industry leaders to talk about the future of retail payments.

title: Braintree Has Officially Joined PayPal
content:
Dec 19, 2013
David Marcus, President, PayPal

As of this week, we’ve officially jumped through all the hoops and completed the many steps that go into closing a major corporate acquisition. So today I’m thrilled to announce that Braintree has officially joined PayPal in our quest to transform the payment industry through groundbreaking innovation that will change the future of money.

Given what’s going on in the industry as we head into 2014, this is an ideal moment to combine the resources of our two great companies. Without question, we’re entering a period of far-reaching disruption that will revolutionize money. We believe that most of this disruption will be driven by innovative payment technologies that make shopping experiences meaningfully faster, easier, more fun, and more personal for consumers, and significantly more valuable for merchants.

Separately, PayPal and Braintree have been at the forefront of a wave of advances that have fueled big changes in how people shopped during the last 12 to 18 months. Together, we believe we offer a combination of scale, experience, business insight and technology talent that positions us to create unprecedented opportunities to accelerate innovation in the months and years ahead.

The long-term potential is endless. But our immediate focus is simple and straightforward. Now that the deal is complete, we’re focused on working together to serve our customers by supporting the great services and solutions that they rely on today while we learn from each other and gain from each other’s strengths.

This is the ideal framework for creating a combined organization that is much more than the sum of its already impressive parts. By maintaining Braintree as a separate service, PayPal will strengthen Braintree’s operations and expand its scope and scale without slowing its ongoing efforts to push the boundaries of what’s possible in mobile-first payments. Venmo, the socially-connected money sharing app, will continue to be supported by PayPal. And PayPal will look to the incredible team of engineers and innovators at Braintree to help us quicken the pace of progress and innovation in our far-ranging efforts in mobile payments.

You’ll see concrete evidence of our progress as Braintree plans to begin offering PayPal as a payment option to its merchant customers in 2014. Having access to both Braintree and PayPal tools and support will also be better and simpler for developers. Many developers are already using both Braintree and PayPal technologies in their mobile apps. For example, we recently announced that Uber is the first Braintree merchant to integrate the new PayPal Mobile SDK.

Looking back, the combination of PayPal and Braintree seems almost inevitable. From the start, it was clear that we share an identical vision for a future where commerce is powered first and foremost by friction-free mobile payment experiences. Looking ahead, we believe it’s clear that the timing that has enabled us to combine forces to make that future a reality couldn’t have been better.

This is why all of us at PayPal and Braintree are excited to roll up our sleeves and get to work together, today.

title: Tips for Tippers: Holiday Edition
content:
Dec 17, 2014
Stacy General, PayPal Customer Experience Advocate

Let's face it. Tipping can be confusing. Is the rule 15% or is it 20? How is one supposed to adjust for good or bad service? And that's just for restaurant tipping. When the holidays come around, it's hard to know who to tip and how much. Let PayPal help you out.

With PayPal, it's easier than it's ever been to tip service professionals during the holidays and any day. Using our Send Money feature, send money to those who make your life better through the year and show them how much you appreciate them and their hard work!

But wait – what are the rules? Who do we tip at the end of the year, and what's the right amount? Let us help!

Take a look at the infographic below (click to view full size) for a guide on some common holiday tip situations. For example:

  • A tip for an assistant is a good idea, but don’t think about one for your boss.
  • For some people—like teachers or mail carriers—a gift is better than money.
  • There’s no need to persist if your tip is declined.

We know a thing or two about payments, but on issues of manners we defer to the experts, so if you still find yourself in doubt, follow this advice from the Emily Post institute: “You tip the people who perform services for you year-round, who are there for you when you need them and whom you have a valuable relationship with.”

And don’t forget: you don’t need cash! It’s really easy to shoot over a quick tip on your mobile device--for free.

We should also point out that PayPal has a partnership with MoneyGram that provides yet another way for you to easily send and receive money. In fact, through the end of the year, we’re giving $10 back to anyone who completes an eligible transaction with PayPal and MoneyGram— this holiday season, if you give some, you get some.

From all of us at PayPal, have a happy, generous holiday season!

title: We’re Simplifying International Logistics for Chinese Exporters
content:
Dec 23, 2013
Wayne Wang, Head of Corporate Communications, PayPal China

We’re excited to announce that we’ve just inked a strategic deal with Beijing Post – one of China’s largest postal providers, serving customers in more than 204 cities in 143 countries worldwide. The company is also the proud owner of the largest international mail exchange office in China.

Why is this a big deal? Currently in China traditional exporters are seeing continuous decline but cross-border e-commerce is booming. As such, more and more exporting merchants have started to embrace online and ship products internationally. In 2012, China’s freight import and exports totaled USD 2.3 trillion, up 32%, surpassing the U.S. for the first time. Any successful e-commerce merchant knows the importance of getting logistics right when it comes to getting their goods into the customer’s hands. Speed of delivery, service quality and the ability to track goods are vital to any seller that wants to have a competitive edge.

For this reason we’re delighted to announce that together with Beijing Post we’ve created PayPal Package, an international logistics solution. First up, PayPal Package allows merchants to track order delivery online, which means it enables merchants to be covered by our seller protection policy. Second, merchants can benefit from an international delivery service for small parcels, which guarantees that these items will be boarding a plane for delivery on the day of order. Current estimates show that transporting parcels from China to the US and Europe takes 10 – 20 days and with this new arrangement we will improve the overall shipping experience. Working with Beijing Post, our merchants in China will benefit from its mature import-export system and, ultimately, the speed of an express delivery service for the price of surface mail.

We know that one of the reasons people prefer PayPal for international shopping is because it makes buying things simple and fast. But if it takes weeks to get your goods, or a logistical slip-up means you don’t receive them at all, customer satisfaction plummets. At PayPal we’re always looking for practical innovations which make shopping better for both merchants and consumers, and we we’re pretty confident that PayPal Package does just that.

title: The Vital Role of Trust When Shopping and Paying
content:
Dec 26, 2013
Tomer Barel, Chief Risk Officer, PayPal

Hearing about the recent data breach at one of my favorite stores was a vivid reminder of the role that trust plays in our relationships with the stores we love and the brands we interact with every day. It made me consider how sharing personal information benefits me, how I connect with others and shop at locations around the world. There's so much added convenience in paying our bills at any hour of the day/night and getting in and out of checkout lines with greater speed and ease. This all works because we trust that the privacy and secrecy of the information we provide will remain safe and secure. Unfortunately, every once in a while, this foundation of trust is shaken when we’re confronted with the fact that there are people out there who seek to exploit our private information for their illegal gain.

Trust is extremely important to keeping us connected. If we didn't have trust at PayPal, we simply wouldn’t be in business. So, with every service, product, technology, and process we create, we always place importance on one capability in particular: protecting your financial information and data.

A few ways that we do this:

  • We don’t share your financial information with merchants. All of your financial information—including your credit card numbers—is encrypted and securely stored on PayPal’s servers so that it’s less likely to be accessed by the wrong people.

  • We watch out for fraud so you don't need to. We’ve developed some of the industry’s most advanced and sophisticated proprietary fraud risk models to help detect, predict, and prevent fraudulent activities. And our fraud specialists work around the clock to spot suspicious transactions and help make sure that they don’t affect you.

  • We want you to buy with ease and know we have your back. In the event that you ever do notice an unauthorized charge on your account, as soon as you notify us, we’ll immediately secure your account and launch an investigation through our Buyer Protection service. If we discover that someone has used your PayPal account without your permission (for example, if someone stole your account password), or there was an error (if money was incorrectly taken from your account), PayPal will cover the full amount for every eligible unauthorized transaction.
What all this adds up to is this: you can continue to use your PayPal account with confidence and trust knowing that we’ll continue to maintain the high levels of vigilance that we always have. We are working hard every day to make sure that we continue to earn your trust. If you have any questions about your account and what we do to keep your information secure, please don’t hesitate to contact me at tbarel@paypal.com.

title: NRF 2014: Collaboration is Key
content:
Jan 14, 2014
Carolyn Groobey, Vice President, Global Products, PayPal

I have spent a lot of time on the road this past year talking to small and medium businesses, and one of the top questions I receive from these merchants when it comes to payments and shopping is, “How can I make an investment in a POS that fits me and my goals?” Sometimes this simply means accepting a credit card, allowing customers to shop with a mobile device, or offering customers loyalty and rewards. From our perspective, we alone cannot do all of this and we collaborate closely with like-minded companies that share our vision for making payments simple.

Small wonder, then, that small businesses are flocking to the new generation of tablet-based POS systems. Now, for less than US $1,000, you can have a sophisticated mobile point of sale system (mPOS) that includes a tablet, card reader, cash drawer, receipt printer, and advanced software for managing every aspect of a business, from inventory management to check out. Among other things, that means you can be up and running in minutes.

There are a lot of reasons why this is a particularly exciting and interesting transformation. One is that not only does it level the playing field between large enterprise retailers and small local merchants in a dramatic way, but it also creates huge opportunities for small businesses to develop disruptive new business models that can offer a significant competitive edge. Another is that it happened really fast – a year ago, it was a cool oddity to stumble into a shop that used a tablet in place of a cash register. Today it’s pretty normal.

And third, the entire mPOS setup is built on a lot of intriguing innovation that comes from a wide variety of sources – hardware manufacturers, software developers, app designers, payment networks, and more. Pulling it all together into a more-than-the-sum-of-its-parts system that’s affordable, powerful, and easy to use requires partnership and collaboration across an unusually broad array of companies.

At PayPal, we’re a key player in the ongoing process of innovation and collaboration that is powering a new generation of experiences designed to make shopping faster, easier, and more fun for consumers and more profitable for retailers. The mPOS systems transforming the retail landscape are a great example. Our PayPal Here app is a key ingredient because it enables merchants to accept any form of payment while providing other essential capabilities, like fraud protection. But we knew we couldn’t build the kind of comprehensive mPOS system that we were picturing – and that small retailers want – without the help and expertise of a host of other organizations that share our vision.

So we’ve been working with some of the world’s most interesting and innovative companies to bring everything together, including Booker,Bouncepad, ERPLY, Heckler Design, Leaf, Leapset, MagTek, MICROS, NCR Silver, Revel Systems, ShopKeep POS, Shopventory, Touch Bistro and Vend. These partners understand the issues that small businesses face and the opportunities for growth that a new generation of shopping experiences can deliver. Now any retailer can easily find a complete, affordable package that meets the specific needs of their business – everything from tablets, card readers, stands, and receipt printers to the software needed to run a retail environment, the apps to engage customers in ways that are more effective and more personal, and the network and infrastructure to accept any and all kinds of payments.

mPOS systems are just one example of what great collaboration can lead to. This week at NRF, we’ve announced that we have working with MICROS to enable their merchants to accept payments from their customers using a smartphone and either a QR code or four-digit short code. And we’re working with software developers and many of the mPOS companies we are working with to bring PayPal Beacon – our new technology that offers consumers a completely hands-free way to pay – to stores in 2014

This week’s NRF show in New York is a great place to see what can happen when innovative companies with a shared vision for how technology can transform payments and shopping work together. If you happen to be attending NRF 2014, please stop by booth #4245 to learn more about how you can collaborate with us and to see some of these great technologies in action. If you don’t make it to NRF this week and would like to learn more, please feel free to email my team at POSpartners@paypal.com.

title: The Integration of Cause-Related Work Into Business
content:
Jan 23, 2014
Oktay Dogramaci, Director, Cause Products, PayPal

It should be no surprise that eBay Inc. – with its 142 million active registered accounts and 124 million active Marketplaces users – has a wealth of data at its disposal to drive better business results for our customers and for the company. However, eBay Inc. is made up of several different business units, spanning eBay, PayPal, eBay Enterprise, StubHub, and many others. Like many organizations, we have a number of initiatives going on to share data across the company to drive better results. Some of these were on display at the National Retail Federation’s annual big show, where this year’s theme was “Elevated Insight.”

When it comes to elevated insight, our Social Innovation strategy is no exception. At eBay Inc., one of our three key areas of impact is powering charitable giving. Our approach to charitable giving is grounded in what we do best – technology-enabled commerce. We’re working to extend our business models to create a worldwide network for good that inspires everyone – whether individuals, nonprofits or global brands – to take action.

Through an increasingly global and diverse portfolio of businesses, as well as cutting-edge tools that enable anytime, anywhere transactions, our approach to powering charitable giving is three-fold:

  • Connect people with easy ways to support the causes they care about
  • Enable nonprofits to raise mission-critical funds and connect with donors in new ways
  • Offer innovative ways for retail partners and celebrities to extend their positive impact
Our long-term goal is to power the world’s largest platform for charitable giving. In 2013 we made public commitments towards that end. By 2015 we plan to double the number of customers that take action on behalf of a charity through our giving programs and platforms; to double the total value of funds raised generated for charitable organizations through our giving programs and platforms; and to double the number of charities that benefit from our giving programs and platforms.

I’ve been part of the eBay Inc. family long enough to be able to say that at least within the Social Innovation realm, it was not that long ago that our business units were working in functional data silos. I remember one case in point where two business units were not aware that each of them were simultaneously working on a cause-related initiative with the same benefiting nonprofit, missing opportunities to maximize impact and reach.

But I can also unequivocally say that these days we have broken down those silos and operate as one company. We’ve taken action to intentionally break up our Social Innovation teams and spread individuals throughout the business units in the company. And with activities ranging from yearly Social Innovation summits to share best practices, to the development of company-wide “Cause dashboards” from our enormous data warehouse that aggregate information across initiatives, to bi-weekly meetings with our global teammates to simply stay in sync, it is evident that we are doing things much better today. For example, when the eBay business unit runs an experiment to calculate the value of a donor’s location when determining a relevant charity to put in front of that person when they are checking out on our site, the PayPal team knows it and can act accordingly to determine how to adjust relevance algorithms on their side to create more relevant experiences for all of our customers and drive engagement with more charities.

By way of PayPal, eBay, StubHub and the rest of our global portfolio, we’re pioneering new, disruptive giving solutions that take advantage of each business’s unique assets to rally our customers in support of charitable causes. As we jointly work to drive the next generation of commerce, we’re committed to building a future that enables and inspires charitable giving at a scale never seen before. With hundreds of millions of users and the trust that comes with processing billions of dollars in donations for nonprofits around the world, we think we can make a pretty good start.

*This article originally appeared on Markets for Good

title: Round Two: PayPal Kicks Off Second Global Hackathon

$100,000 USD. That’s how much a team of Moscow developers won after conquering PayPal’s first-ever global Hackathon competition, Battle Hacks. At the 2013 World Finals, the team created Donate Now, an app that uses Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) technology and PayPal to allow anyone to instantly donate to a cause from their mobile devices. Instead of filling out lengthy donation forms, the app allows people to donate whenever and wherever they see an opportunity for giving in their daily lives.

title: Children's Miracle Network and PayPal Here Hit the Streets to Help Kids

“You guys are amazing,” said one donor. “I have never seen donations accepted like this. Keep up the good work!”

title: The Value of PayPal and eBay Together
content:
Jan 22, 2014
eBay, Inc.

Last week eBay Inc. CEO John Donahoe got a call from investor Carl Icahn. Mr. Icahn is a new eBay Inc. shareholder who is pretty excited about the potential of PayPal (we are, too). In fact, he thinks PayPal would be even better as a separate company.

We have tremendous respect for Mr. Icahn, so if he wants to talk with us, we’re happy to listen—just like we do with all of our shareholders. Spinning off PayPal as a separate company from eBay Inc. is not a new idea. In fact, eBay’s management team and board routinely explore all of the company’s strategic options. And based on everything the company and board see today, we continue to believe that shareholders and customers are best served by keeping PayPal and eBay together.

Why? No other payments competitor has achieved PayPal’s success – because no other competitor has a commerce platform like eBay. PayPal is successful precisely because we are part of eBay Inc., not in spite of it. eBay Inc. has helped drive our success for more than a decade, and we continue to believe we’re far more valuable together.

There are three main reasons: first, eBay accelerates PayPal’s success; second, eBay data makes PayPal smarter; and third, eBay funds PayPal’s growth. Being part of eBay Inc. gives PayPal access to an enormously valuable global customer base; it provides a source of low-cost capital that lets us aggressively fund growth and innovation in areas such as mobile and credit, as well as helping us acquire companies such as Braintree to enhance our competitive position. And being part of eBay Inc. enables us to broadly leverage the company’s technology capabilities, data, commerce platforms and relationships with retailers, brands and large merchants worldwide. We’re committed to making paying easier, and shopping more fun.

Strong synergies have always existed between PayPal and eBay. If and when these synergies run their course, the company and board will do what’s best for our business, our customers and our shareholders.

But today we strongly believe that PayPal is more competitive, more agile and more successful when combined with eBay. We are better together. Everyone at PayPal is committed to remaining focused on driving innovation and creating the future of commerce.
