title: PayPal Battle Hack Miami Winning App: Once, An App Aimed at Helping Friends and Family Build Savings Plans and Come Together
content:
Feb 26, 2014
Jonathan LeBlanc, Global Head of Developer Evangelism, PayPal

This past weekend, our 2014 Battle Hack series conquered Miami. Back in Miami for a second year, the crowd proved once again that the City is a strong, up-and-coming hub of technology and innovation, as well as the bridge between the U.S. and Latin America.

In the end, a few familiar faces took home first place with Once, an innovative app aimed at bringing families together to build out a family savings plan. Two members of Team Once were also winners of our 2013 Miami Battle Hack. Osniel Gonzalez and Jose Pimienta, and new third team member Rafael Bonnelly, are now set to join the other city champions at our Silicon Valley World Finals to compete for the $100,000 grand prize.

Incorporating a fun lottery-style component, the Once app works by having a maximum of 11 family members join together to contribute to a 12-month savings plan. Each month, one family member is picked as the “monthly winner,” and receives that month’s full contributions. Throughout the year, every contributor will win a month to get the money, but it may be at any given time.

Our second place winner was #YOLO For a Cause, created by Waldemar Figueroa, Javier Velazquez, Antonio Rodriguez and Jorge Suarez. The #Yolo app is where viral video challenges meet charitable donations. You can use the service to dare your friends to do something, like the dreaded cinnamon challenge, putting up a bet for them to take a part of. When the challenge takes place, a portion of the proceeds goes to a charity of your choosing.

Code Together took third place, developed by Gianni D'Alerta, Deborah Venuti, Dan Vera, and Joshua Martinez. Helping the local events scene, the app gives event organizers and sponsors a centralized and easy way to create events in local cities. One of the most impressive parts of the app is its l33t point integration given out through participating, allowing organizers to see how much sponsors are actually participating in events before taking them on as partners. Overall, the teams battled heavily throughout the night, with a trusty Keurig machine in heavy rotation, and brought home a tremendous array of hacks ranging from TSA mailing packages (in case you forgot that prohibited item in your carry-on), to an application that allowed you to track sign language through a Leap Motion device and translate it as needed for interaction with those with disabilities.

Miami already has a strong sense of identity in the South Florida community, and these hackers were the shining example of everything that makes Miami great.

title: Causes We Love: Valley Verde
content:
Feb 28, 2014
Clam Lorenz, Director, Nonprofit Engagement, PayPal

Recently I sat down with Raffaella Cerruti, the Operations Manager at Valley Verde, a nonprofit based in
 Santa Clara County in California. The organization provides vegetable gardens to low-income families. Raffaella and I chatted about Valley Verde’s efforts and how PayPal helps along the way.

Can you share any background and/or fun facts about the organization?

Valley Verde staff is a small but diverse group of Italian, Mexican and Vietnamese employees. We build all of the garden boxes for our participants ourselves: over 170 to date. Valley Verde was invited to exhibit a custom raised bed for the SJ Museum of Art, Round the Table exhibit.

What makes the organization unique? Why would someone support you?

We empower families in Santa Clara County (CA) to become organic gardeners, so that they can ensure their own food self-sufficiency and improve their nutrition. Our participants learn how to grow healthy produce that they are rarely able to access in their own neighborhoods. Given the debilitating impacts of the slow pace of economic recovery for Silicon Valley's lowest income families and the increasing levels of food insecurity, this is a timely opportunity to re-establish home gardens to build self-sustainment skills and alleviate hunger.

By early April 2014, Valley Verde will have supported a total of 144 families to start cultivating organic gardens at home.

What are some of your biggest challenges in getting support?

One of the largest challenges our small nonprofit faces is effectively fostering relationships with donors while also expanding our donor base.

How does the organization currently use PayPal?

Valley Verde currently uses PayPal to collect credit card donations. We also use PayPal to process the selling of our garden boxes and custom raised beds. For every garden sold, we are able to provide one low-income family with a garden and enroll them in a year-round gardening program.

Why do you like using PayPal to collect donations? Do you use it for anything else?

PayPal’s Donate button was easy to integrate into our website and donors feel secure when they check out on the PayPal site. We also like using the mobile giving application during our outreach events!

How can others get involved in your organization’s cause?

Besides donors, our organization’s best resource is our volunteers. Together with donors they can promote our cause for us. Also, we leverage our families and friend networks on our social media channels.

Would you recommend PayPal to another nonprofit? Why?

Yes, we would recommend PayPal to another nonprofit, as it is the easiest way to collect credit card donations.

What are your organization’s social media channels?

Follow along on Facebook and Twitter.

title: Causes We Love: Pets Alive
content:
March 04, 2014
Clam Lorenz, Director, Nonprofit Engagement, PayPal

Recently I had the chance to interview Dottsie Perez, Executive Director at Pets Alive and Mary Boehlke, the Assistant Development Director at Pets Alive. The organization is one of the oldest no-kill organizations in the United States. Dottsie, Mary and I discussed Pets Alive’s efforts and how PayPal helps along the way.

Can you share any background and/or fun facts about the organization?

Pets Alive is a no-kill animal sanctuary and we are proud to operate in 3 locations: Middletown, NY, Westchester, NY and Utuado, Puerto Rico. Our mission is to rescue, rehabilitate and place our animals into loving homes. We improve the lives of companion animals by any means possible including rescue, adoption, advocacy, collaboration, intervention and education. Our animals range from dogs and cats to farm animals. Many of the animals at Pets Alive are older, have special needs or require special care.

What makes the organization unique? Why would someone support you?

There are many elements that make Pets Alive a unique organization. For one, we do not euthanize animals. An animal will live its life with us should it not get adopted. During its lifetime will receive the love and care it needs. Our animals are shown love not only by staff, but by our amazing volunteers who devote their time to care for them. They not only walk them, but have them groomed, take them into their homes for sleepovers, take them on day trips like hiking or take them out for ice cream. Our barn animals are our beautiful pastures and roam free and live naturally the way a farm animal should. During the warm months, our dogs enjoy the outdoors by living in large kennel spaces with sprinkler systems, doggie pools, play yards and a large dog walk trail. During the winter season, our dogs have sufficient kennel space with kuranda beds and comforters to keep them cozy and warm. Our cats live freely in a cage free, two-story colonial home. They live their lives the same way a household cat would, therefore they have no idea they are homeless. These are just some of the things that make us stand out.

What are some of your biggest challenges in getting support?

Our biggest challenge is getting our name out in the public. We are a grassroots organization, but with the use of social media we are on our way towards making Pets Alive a household name. We participate in several community events throughout the year such as offsite adoption events and we host many of our own fundraisers which helps raise awareness.

How does the organization currently use PayPal?

PayPal is an essential tool for our organization. It gives our supporters the ability to make online donations at their convenience. We use it to accept one time donations as well as monthly sponsorships. In addition, if we are raising money for something specific that the sanctuary needs, such as renovations, needed supplies or assistance with paying medical bills or surgery we can easily set up a fundraiser. We also use it to sell any items we may have for sale, such as our annual calendar.

Why do you like using PayPal to collect donations?

It’s easy to keep track of any funding we receive, it’s easy to use and most of our supporters are familiar with PayPal-- they can send us a donation at ease.

How can others get involved in your organization’s cause?

Every Saturday at noon we hold a new volunteer orientation where volunteers will learn how to safely interact with the animals at Pets Alive. Orientation is only required one time and volunteers are free to come and volunteer as often as they can. Also, check our website for any events we have coming up as well. We also have monthly sponsorship programs for those who want to help, but aren’t able to do so physically.

Would you recommend PayPal to another nonprofit?

Yes. It’s fast, safe, easy and very user friendly with reasonable fees.

What are your organization’s social media channels?

Facebook, Twitter, and our website www.petsalive.org.

title: PayPal 101: Setting Up a PayPal Account for Your Business
content:
March 26, 2014
Chris Rising, Director Online Marketing, PayPal

One of your most important business goals, undoubtedly, is creating a great shopping experience for your customers, which means that you want solutions that are fast and easy – especially when it comes to accepting payments. That’s why we’ve made setting up a PayPal account for your business simple. In just a few steps, you can start accepting credit cards, debit cards, PayPal, Bill Me Later®, and direct debits via your online business in a matter of minutes.

So how do you get started? In this article, we break down the steps for you. And once you have your account set up, you’ll be ready to take advantage of a slew of other options, like adding a button to your website, transferring money from your PayPal account to your bank account, and much more. 

Setting Up Your Account

  1. Sign up for an account at paypal.com. First things first – go to the PayPal website and click on the Business tab at the top of the homepage. From there, click on the “Sign Up Now” button and fill out the information asked for.
  2. Confirm your email address. When you first create your account on the PayPal website and enter in your information, you should receive an email from service@paypal.com similar to the one below, asking you to confirm your email.


If you can’t find (or haven’t received) this email, you can log in to your PayPal account and request a new confirmation email here. 

3. Link and confirm your bank account. Adding and confirming your back account allows you to transfer money from your PayPal account to your bank account, and vice versa. Linking your account also helps PayPal verify your identity. Your bank account will not be visible to your customers, and you can add or change what bank accounts are associated with your PayPal account at any time. To link your bank account:

A. Log in to your PayPal account.

B. Click Profile at the top of the page.

C. Click My Money

D. Click Update next to "Bank accounts," and then click Add Bank.

E. Select what kind of account it is (Checking or Savings).

F. Enter the bank's routing number, your account number, and then click Continue. Once you get confirmation, you should be all set!

4. Confirm all your information is correct. It’s important to make sure all your information is correct so that both you and your customers can have the best experience possible. As your business grows and changes, you can easily make edits to your profile whenever needed.

A. Log in to your PayPal account.

B. Click Profile near the top of the page.

C. Click “My business info." 

D. Click “Update" beside "Business information." 

E. Click “Edit." Here you can edit things like your customer service phone number and email. Once you’ve made the necessary edits click “Save.”

5. Lift your sending and withdrawal limits. At first, your PayPal account will have limits on the amount of money that can be sent or withdrawn. Once you’ve linked your bank account, you can lift your limits with one of the following options:

  • Confirm your  social security number
  • Link and confirm your debit or credit card
 There you have it! In just a few easy steps you can set up a PayPal account for your business and start accepting payments. I’ll also mention that you should keep eye on this space for more from the PayPal 101 series, where we’ll provide you with additional tips to be successful in using PayPal as part of your business ecosystem.

title: PayPal Launches Complete Payments Solution for Australian Businesses
content:
Apri 02, 2014
Andrew Rechtman, Senior Director of SMB, Retail and Strategy, PayPal Australia

Australia is proudly made up of a diverse range of small businesses. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, nearly half of all Australian businesses fall into this category – dog groomers, hair stylists, landscapers, tourist operators and more, operating on the road, in market stalls, from beaches, homes and vehicles across the country.

With research showing that three in four Australians own a smartphone, it comes as no surprise that today’s shopfront is increasingly mobile. The reality for small businesses however, is that while technology has allowed them to break free from the confines of a physical shopfront, it is also increasing the demand for cashless payments.

In 2013, usage of all traditional forms of payments declined, with ATM use trending downwards and cash and cheques increasingly being replaced by card, mobile and online payments.

When we launched PayPal Here in 2012 we saw the opportunity to leverage smartphone technology to help businesses accept payments. In 2014 we wanted to take that concept to the next level by developing a complete payments solution that enables businesses to focus more on their passions and less on payments.

This is why we’re excited to announce the launch of the next generation PayPal Here , an app and Bluetooth device that turns a smartphone into a secure chip and PIN credit and debit card reader.

By pairing the PayPal Here device with their mobile device, hairdressers can now take credit card payments from a customer’s home, landscapers can send invoices to clients from their vehicle, and dog groomers can email receipts for debit card purchases before their furry client has had time to dry.

The device has been designed with Australian businesses in mind, using Chip and PIN technology as mandatory EMV compliance comes into effect in Australia in the next year.

With no monthly fees and only a small fee per transaction, we wanted to give small businesses greater flexibility with a less rigid payment structure.

Our vision at PayPal is to enable any business, large and small, to easily accept payments, no matter where they may operate. We want to make Australia’s shift into a cashless society as seamless as possible, allowing Australian businesses to provide the best customer service possible with the technology available to them.

Australian businesses can register their interest in PayPal Here Chip and PIN at www.paypal.com.au/here.

title: About Our Recent Privacy Policy Notice
content:
April 03, 2014
Tanya Madison Cunningham, Global Privacy Leader, PayPal

Starting in March we began contacting our customers in North America as part of our usual review and update of our policies. We send these e-mails periodically as part of our compliance with government regulations and also because we want everyone to understand our policies and the relationship they have with PayPal.

We typically receive questions after we publish a policy update. We want to take a minute to provide more detail on this update, specifically when it comes to the privacy of your personal financial information. Your trust is very important to us, so we want to share some important facts.

1. We do not sell your personal information 

We value your business and the trust you place in PayPal. We do not sell your personal information. This is not the business that we are in and it’s not new for us. This is a fundamental part of who we are and how we do business. We give our users control over when they are marketed to by third parties. This includes members of the eBay Inc. corporate family.

You trust us with your money and we take this very seriously. title: PayPal Battle “Hack” of the Bay Names Ledgr Winning App
content:

Jonathan LeBlanc, Global Head of Developer Evangelism, PayPal

Our third installation of BattleHack 2014 took place this past weekend in San Francisco at Impact Hub, and we had some really cool developers come out. The winner for the Battle of the Bay? An app called Ledgr. Randy Chan and Kevin Sutardji, the team behind Ledgr, created an app to help communities keep track of unused items they rent out to others. This puts the San Francisco team winners in the race to win the $100,000 grand prize, with other teams from around the world in San Jose this coming November.

Through the integration of Venmo payments, Ledgr aims “to create a sharing and reusing ecosystem,” according to the team. Because everyone has unused items like snowboards, games and bikes, there is a surplus of items that users are able to rent out and earn income while renters are able to use items at a lower price point than buying or renting elsewhere.

Crowdsharing became a theme at the San Francisco Battle Hack, with the second place winner focused on curing the pain of parking in large cities.  Park Scout, created by Marcus Proetti and Ryan Dignard, enables users to rent out their private parking spots when not in use.  With this app users can view nearby private parking spots, see the costs and have the ability to pay with PayPal and park – right from the app.

Third place went to Shelter Phone, developed by Chris Davies and Matthew Housden. The app lets homeless shelters set up a simple auto-attendant voice mail system, allowing their homeless population, or others without phones, to have a simple, low cost voicemail box available to them.

And of course, we could not have a 24 hour event without the assistance of local food specialties like handmade ice cream sandwiches, gourmet croissants, and gourmet pizza (on top of a heavy array of coffee and energy drinks) to keep our developers going.

In its first year in the City by the Bay, the San Francisco Battle Hack also yielded ideas and hacks ranging from helping student loan repayment to games that track recycling habits to gesture based services that enable the visually impaired to pay for goods and services.

San Francisco, long touted as a technology hub in the Silicon Valley, brought out great ideas and enthusiasm to the sold-out event. There’s no question that Battle Hack felt at home bringing a Battle of the Bay to the city.

title: OpenSSL Heartbleed Bug – PayPal Account Holders are Secure
content:
April 09, 2014
James Barrese, CTO, PayPal
There has been a lot of news in the past 24 hours about a security vulnerability in a version of OpenSSL, commonly known as the “Heartbleed Bug”. OpenSSL is a popular cryptographic software library used to help keep Internet communications private, so understandably you may have questions about how this might impact your private information.
 
We take the responsibility of keeping your personal information and financial details protected very seriously at PayPal. It is our top concern.
 
We would like to assure you that with regards to the Heartbleed bug:
 
1) Your PayPal account is secure
2) Your PayPal account details were not exposed in the past and remain secure
3) You do not need to take any additional action to safeguard your information
4) There is no need to change your password
 
While we always advise our customers to be cautious and aware of the security of their personal and financial information, in this case we want to reassure you there is no need to be unduly concerned.  When you login to PayPal using your user name and password these details were not exposed to the OpenSSL vulnerability.
 
PayPal offers a full range of services beyond the core capabilities for which we are well known. Following a comprehensive review of all our services, our security teams did identify a handful of businesses that we recommend upgrade their Payflow Gateway integrations to eliminate the risk of vulnerability. The Payflow Gateway is a payment gateway for online merchants that links your website to your processing network or merchant account.
 
We have already been in touch with the merchants who could potentially be affected and are working with them to upgrade their integrations.
 
Again, we would like to reassure all our consumers that your PayPal account details remain secure. PayPal does not share account details with businesses when our customers make a transaction. It is a fundamental way that PayPal helps to keep our customers safer and more secure.
 
If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to our customer support team.

title: Fee Transparency: A Guide to Online Payment Processor Hidden Fees
content:
April 10, 2014
Lauren Fusco, Director, SMB Services & Business to Business, PayPal

Say you’re sitting down with this month’s invoices. You decide to figure out what you’re paying to process your online payments. You’re probably getting all sorts of emails or phone solicitations. They all promise to process your charges for less money than you are paying now: what to do? It’s all very enticing to find you can pay rates that are less than your current vendor charges: but you might wonder… is this too good to be true?

Well, it might be. Due to hidden fees, you need to be very careful in assessing how much a transaction is actually going to cost your business.

  1. Some processors charge higher rates, up to 3.9%, for the premium cards that your customers prefer. Say your customer wants to use her frequent flier or corporate card; you may get hit with a different rate vs. the originally advertised 1.9%.
  2. Some processors don’t disclose what their monthly minimum process requirement or fees are. These fees can typically run $20-$35 per month with other processors if you don’t meet the minimum transaction volume. That means you’ll be penalized if you don’t meet a volume target.
  3. Some processors charge a monthly statement fee, whether or not you are mailed a paper statement.
  4. Finally, if you opt to cancel once you recover from the sticker shock of that first bill, you can be hit with a huge cancellation fee because you signed a multi-year agreement to get that “great deal.” You are already locked into payroll, rent and phone/internet packages – shouldn’t your payment processing be more flexible, able to contract and expand alongside your business?
You shouldn’t have to create complicated spreadsheets to figure out which payment processor is giving you the best rate: how about opting for transparency and going with the one who don’t have any hidden fees? After all, it may not sound like much, but multiply that by ten times a month and it really adds up.

PayPal has no hidden fees – we tell you right up front how much you will expect to see on your first bill so there’s no invoice shock. Plus, we will work with you as your business grows and be your advisor for all areas of your growing online business.

Bottom line, you made the right choice with PayPal and can relax now that you know the benefits of flat-rate, transparent pricing for your business.

title: Three Trends That Might Transform the Retail Payments Experience
content:
April 16, 2014
David Marcus, President, PayPal

At PayPal I have the opportunity to see a lot of new technologies before they're ready for prime time. Some we create, others are created by other companies in various industries. I do my best to save enough time away from the corporate side of the job to spend as much time as I can geeking out on these new technologies and charting the future with our amazing teams. Lately, I've been looking at three technologies that might truly change the retail experience as we know it. 

The Advent of Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE)

I've written about this in the past, but the proliferation of BLE chips in devices will enable the industry to create very precise, fast, and secure shopping and payment experiences that are both location and context relevant. We're big fans of BLE at PayPal – so much so that we created our own Beacon. PayPal Beacon is different from other beacons because it's connected to the Internet, enabling you to pay hands-free even when your phone data connection is poor or non-existent. I truly believe that in a lot of shopping environments, we shouldn't line up to pay at a specific location. We should be able to grab what we want and go. Beacons combined with our nearly 150 million active customers should enable that at scale as we roll this technology out.

NFC HCE

For years I've been saying NFC was a technology in search of a problem, designed and embraced by companies thinking about their own interests  rather than solving a problem for consumers. Year after year, at the Mobile World Congress, the industry has been issuing press releases about the advent of NFC the following year. And year after year, I've been very vocal about NFC not becoming mainstream. So far I've been right. Have you ever seen a consortium of mobile carriers, banks, OEMs, and associations, who each want a piece of the action delivering a good consumer product experience? Me neither. The crux of the issue of the original approach of NFC was the Secure Element. The Secure Element, as its name indicates, is meant to keep financial information secure. The problem? Everybody keeps fighting over who gets to control it, because the entity that controls it becomes the toll master for every transaction that takes place. This led to interesting battles between financial institutions, OEMs, and carriers. And this is main reason why Google Wallet on NFC only launched on the Sprint network. The other carriers wanted their own solution, ISIS, to be the only one available to their subscribers.

But something changed late last year. The Android team at Google started supporting and pushing another standard (not exclusively for payments) called NFC HCE, or Host Card Emulation. The beauty with this move is that it doesn't require the whole industry fighting over control for the Secure Element. The Android team approached us with this initiative late last year to collect our feedback on implementation. For the first time ever, I saw a glimmer of hope for NFC in some shopping configurations. Those where you need to be at a specific place in the store to pay — think multilane grocery vs. the Apple Store experience of paying wherever you are. Two more events are worth noting. One is the accelerated pace to move to EMV — chip and PIN vs. mag stripe on a card — since the major credit card breaches with large retailers, which will lead to more NFC-enabled terminals by 2016. And the second one is Visa embracing the HCE approach. It's worth noting that our approach to security is somewhat different, as we don't share your financial information when you shop.

The bottom line is that I'm moving from being a massive skeptic of NFC, to being cautiously optimistic on NFC HCE take-up in very specific shopping use cases. But I still passionately believe that paying hands-free through a BLE Beacon and notifying the merchant you're in the store through that method will enable more transformative experiences for consumers and retailers alike.

Smartwatches and Wearables

We live in a world of notifications. Apps of all kinds are fighting for our attention all day. And one of the things that struck me after playing with smartwaches quite a bit, is how it is the absolute best device for managing and responding to notifications. For example, we have a pilot running in our on-campus cafe that combines Beacon, with an app built for the Samsung Galaxy Gear 2, and Gear Fit devices. Walk into the area covered by the Beacon, your watch notifies you you've checked in, the barista greets you by name because your photo shows up on the point-of-sale system, and when she rings you up, you get another push notification. Tap on the watch to confirm the payment, and go. This is one of the most transformative payments experiences I've had. No wallet. The phone never leaves my pocket. And I'm in control.

In the next 2 years, I believe we're going to see more and better smartwatches hit the market (maybe a major new one this year?), and I'm now convinced the Swiss watch industry is going to be in trouble. And it pains me, being a lover of beautiful automatic watches. But the utility and functionality of smartwatches will be a tsunami for that industry if they don't adapt very quickly. All smartwatches will have a Bluetooth Low Energy, some may have NFC, which combined might make these devices the ultimate in-store payment instrument.

So will it be one technology winning over another? No. This is not, and has never been, about technology. It's about building amazing shopping experiences reinforcing the human connection in the retail environment. It's about combining a digital wallet in the cloud with whatever technology makes sense in the right context, and keeping customers safe at all times.

These are very, very exciting times where we get to redefine how hundreds of millions of people will move to the digital age of money. I can't wait to unleash some of these great products and innovations to our customers around the world.

title: Startups Get an Even Bigger Boost with PayPal’s Startup Blueprint Program
content:

John Lunn, Senior Director of Developer Relations, PayPal
Every year, thousands of startups are born. It’s exciting! It means people are putting their minds to work to bring our future to life. But you don’t have to be an entrepreneur to know that starting a business is hard work. Resources are limited, and every dollar counts. In some cases, the difference between a startup’s success and failure can come down to a few thousand dollars. We recognize this. That’s why we’ve worked with hundreds of thousands of developers since 2009 to help them monetize their great ideas.

Since launching the PayPal Startup Blueprint program less than six months ago, we’ve already signed up nearly 100 startups from all over the globe. Today, we’re expanding this program by adding even more benefits and bringing on fifteen new partners. You’re definitely not going to want to miss out on this.

More Startup Blueprint Benefits

Our Startup Blueprint program provides these startups with the freedom to choose the best payments experience for their business. On top of the waived PayPal processing fees on up to $1.5 million USD in payment volume, U.S. startups can also get Braintree processing fees waived on up to $100,000 USD in payment volume. That translates to more than $50,000 USD in savings. That’s a lot of money for any startup.

Our network is also your network. Building on our white glove customer service and mentorship program, Blueprint participants will now get access to our startup advisor team and Blueprint events. These are opportunities where startups can connect with the people who have been in the trenches. It’s a valuable chance to expand their network and gain make or break business insights from peers and seasoned entrepreneurs.

New Blueprint Partners

When we began the program last year, we started with a handful of top incubators and accelerators: 500Startups, Elevator Fund and SeedCamp, in EMEA and North America. But, we knew we had to quickly add more partners to reach more of today’s up-and-coming startups.

So we’ve expanded. We’ve added TechStars as well as our first VC partner, Kima Ventures. And that’s not all. We’ve added thirteen other partners, including Better Ventures, Entrepreneurs Roundtable Accelerator, Founder Institute, LeCamping, H.FARM Ventures, K5Launch, StartupBootcamp, StartupWiseGuys, SURF Incubator, TheFamily, UpWest Labs, Venture Hive, and Village Capital. With this network, we reach 5,000 startups globally. Now that’s a big number.

Our new partners are excited too. Techstars founder and CEO, David Cohen says, "We're so excited about PayPal's Startup Blueprint offering. Startups are always trying to preserve their runway -- and having no fees on up to $1.5 million USD in processing is a real game changer for Techstars companies."

We want everyone to feel this excited, so our goal is to sign up thousands of startups for the Blueprint program by the end of the year. To find out if your startup is eligible for the PayPal Startup Blueprint program, visit blueprint.paypal.com.

But our commitment to startups doesn’t stop at Blueprint. This week, we’ve taken this dedication a step further for US startups with the launch of Braintree’s Ignition program. The Ignition program gives any US startup a jump-start with their business to get them past that first $50K in revenue. Whereas the Startup Blueprint program is aimed at giving global startups that work with one of our eighteen partners access to PayPal’s network and resources to help them grow their business and succeed.

title: Update on PayPal and Crowdfunding
content:
March 13, 2014
Tomer Barel, Chief Risk Officer, PayPal


Following my post in September, I wanted to update everyone on the changes that we have put in place to address the problems around PayPal limiting the accounts of a few people who were using crowdfunding sites to support their ideas.

First, let me take a step back and explain the core of the issue. Crowdfunding is fundamentally different from regular ecommerce. There is a distinction between crowdfunding and “preselling”. In crowdfunding, the process involves speculatively supporting a new concept that may, despite the best of intentions, not make it to market. In “preselling” there is an expectation that you will get something tangible for your money…even if it takes months for delivery.

Many crowdfunding sites allow their campaign owners to pull money out before they have reached the final goal in order to begin creating and funding the concept, a process that often begins even while the crowdfunding process using PayPal is continuing. If it is not made clear that there is no guarantee of product delivery, this can cause regulatory and risk issues (and upset customers) when the final goal isn’t reached.

Here are some of the key changes we have made to help make sure this doesn’t happen:

PayPal has started to engage crowdfunding campaign owners early on to clearly understand their campaign goals and help them ensure their campaigns are compliant with our policies and government regulations.

Together with the crowdfunding sites, we identify if campaigns are strictly fundraising or preselling merchandise. We enable their campaigns without interrupting payments under the condition that the campaign owner is explicit and transparent to their contributors that there is no guarantee of delivery regarding the rewards being offered upon contribution.

You can read more about the changes here. We worked with the major crowdfunding players to put this solution in place in order to avoid unnecessary account limitations. Daryl Hatton, CEO of FundRazr, one of our largest crowdfunding partners, just posted on the FundRazr blog with his perspectives.

Over the last few months, these changes have allowed us to help thousands of campaigns build momentum and focus on their fundraising goals without interruption.

Currently, PayPal is the only payment company that has customized its policy and processes to specifically support crowdfunding and we have done it without changes to our price structure. Providing a lower price point than our competitors is also important to us because PayPal's very essence is in connecting people. The last thing we want to do is get in the way of the innovative new products coming from entrepreneurs raising money via crowdfunding.

We’ll continue to keep a close eye on these processes and work with our customers in order to improve our ability to provide a streamlined process to support crowdfunding campaigns. We will continue building strategic partnerships with crowdfunding platforms like FundRazr to make it even easier to offer flexible, safe, and secure payment options so that it is simple for people with great ideas and important causes to raise money.

As always, if you have questions or concerns about a crowdfunding campaign, please contact me directly at tbarel@paypal.com.

title: Mobile World Congress: Forget Your Passwords – Samsung Galaxy S5 Users will be the First to Use Fingerprint Authentication to Shop at Millions of PayPal Merchants
content:
Feb 24, 2014
Hill Ferguson, Chief Product Officer, PayPal

Earlier today at Samsung’s Unpacked event at Mobile World Congress, the company unveiled its new, fifth generation Samsung Galaxy S5 and PayPal will be the first global payments company to support its mobile fingerprint authentication technology. Samsung Galaxy S5 users will be the first to use their fingerprint to login to shop at any merchant that accepts PayPal on mobile and in-stores – no passwords or logins to remember. This builds on yesterday’s news that PayPal will be available on the new Samsung Gear 2 smartwatches.

Samsung is one of the world's most trusted handset makers, with a presence in more than 150 countries. By using fingerprint authentication instead of a traditional login and password on the new Samsung Galaxy S5, consumers benefit from an even more secure and seamless mobile and in-store shopping experience across the millions of merchants that accept PayPal.

We spearheaded the Fast IDentity Online (FIDO) Alliance last year and predicted that the industry would soon move beyond passwords, and this announcement brings us one step closer to that reality. By working with Samsung to leverage fingerprint authentication technology on their new Samsung Galaxy S5, we are able to demonstrate to consumers don’t need to sacrifice convenience to increase security. With a simple swipe of a finger, consumers can still securely log into their PayPal account to shop and pay with the convenience that mobile devices afford.

Security has always been and continues to be of utmost importance to PayPal. A crucial part of this commitment is leveraging technology that improves security without adding complexity and confusion.

PayPal provides a secure wallet in the cloud and doesn’t store personal information on the device. Customers can use their finger to pay with PayPal from their new Samsung Galaxy S5 because the FIDO Ready™ software on the device securely communicates between the fingerprint sensor on their device and PayPal’s service in the cloud. The only information the device shares with PayPal is a unique encrypted key that allows PayPal to verify the identity of the customer without having to store any biometric information on PayPal’s servers.

Starting in April, PayPal fingerprint authentication on the Samsung Galaxy S5 will be available in 26 markets, including Australia, Brazil, Hong Kong, Russia, United Kingdom and United States.

Stay on top of PayPal’s news at Mobile World Congress by us following us @PAYPAL. If you’re at the show, download the official GSMA app and save yourself some time by ordering food ahead of time and paying with PayPal.

title: PayPal and Interbank Bring Global eCommerce to Peru
content:
March 10, 2014
Mario Mello, VP & GM, PayPal Latin America

My team and I recently travelled to Lima, Peru for an exciting announcement. In partnership with Interbank - an innovative Peruvian financial institution that is equally committed to bringing secure and convenient payments to local businesses and consumers – we launched a service that gives merchants the opportunity to withdraw funds from their PayPal account into their local Interbank savings account in dollars or Peruvian soles.

For years, Peruvian consumers and merchants have been able to use PayPal when making online purchases or to sell abroad. So, why does this new alliance matter? First, this partnership makes it easier for Peruvian merchants to open a PayPal account and gain access to PayPal’s 143+ million global customers. Second, by being able to easily access the funds in their PayPal accounts, the service gives merchants more liquidity and flexibility.

This alliance will positively affect companies like Alpaca Expeditions, an adventure tour company in Peru whose growth relies on both local and international business. Since implementing PayPal in June of 2012, Alpaca Expeditions has grown their online sales with PayPal to over $500,000 per year. In fact, PayPal transactions now make up 95% of their online business.

Global eCommerce represents a $105 billion dollar opportunity, and Alpaca Expeditions is a testament to the fact that safe, secure payment options are integral to allowing merchants to tap into the global online marketplace. Selling to a broader consumer base and harnessing the growth of global ecommerce gives merchants a marked advantage, a fact that is supported by our own internal data and external research.

Currently 25% of PayPal’s business is cross border, meaning the buyer and seller are in different countries. And, our recent Latin American study on “La Nueva Ruta de las Especias” (Translation: “The New Spice Routes”) shows that merchants who conduct at least 25% of their online business abroad grew at an average rate of 70% between 2011 and 2012. Cross border commerce is an opportunity that PayPal wants merchants to fully take advantage of, by easily selling to other countries within Latin America, to North American neighbors or to buyers across the world in Asia or Europe.

Innovative partnerships with local banks will help us get there. The model that we’ve put in place with Interbank and with other financial institutions in the region can be replicated across Latin America and the world. We look forward to continuing our journey with Interbank and helping more companies like Alpaca Expeditions connect with the millions of global consumers who buy with PayPal.

title: SXSW 2014: We Came, We Saw, We Partied with Snoop
content:
March 12, 2014
Dave Peck, Head of Social Media, PayPal

Ah, SXSW. Once a small show and proving ground for startups, it has definitely evolved – this year’s show boasted 30,000+ attendees from 74 countries. Amidst all the craziness, there are always moments and trends that emerge.

Having a booth and handing out flyers – once a mainstay – is no longer the best way to engage with attendees. Across the board, immersive experiences ruled. This played out in a variety of ways. Social media turned from responsive engagements between brands and fans, to real time experiences. Tech aggregators provided quick snapshots of all things SXSW – the food, the panels and the pictures to unique brand engagements.

3D printing, one of the buzzwords of SXSW 2013, moved from interesting concept to a huge branding play in 2014. Brands across the show integrated 3D printing, whether through live demonstrations or showing these creations in action. Oreo interacted directly with its fans on-site, allowing them to tweet their ideal flavor combinations, which were then printed in real time. Essentially, Oreo took what was trending to create new products in real time, the new “fast” food of SXSW.

In one of the most talked about exhibits of the show, Game of Thrones fans were able to experience the show for themselves with the Oculus Rift. Virtual scenes played out on screen, coupled with temperature drops and wind while exploring the frozen tundra. These virtual experiences played out across the conference, from engaging panels to a shark punching experience at our own “Brain Blast” party.

While the show is bigger than ever, in a lot of ways, this trend towards immersion and interaction also made it feel smaller and more intimate. In speaking with attendees, whether old friends or people I met on-site, it was clear that through all of the chaos, people were seeking out these more intimate meetings and personalized experiences. Our very own PayPal Social Media Lounge played host to thousands of attendees, offering them a chance to relax, get some work done, and, of course, grab some great swag.

What did you think of SXSW 2014? Did you interact with your favorite brand or use social to interact with attendees?

title: Celebrate St. Patrick’s Day with PayPal
content:
March 14, 2014
Anuj Nayar, Senior Director of Global Initiatives

Planning to celebrate St. Patrick’s Day this year? If so, you’re not alone. According to a recent survey* conducted by Harris Poll, nearly one in three (29%) American adults are planning to do something to commemorate the St. Patrick’s Day holiday this year. With this in mind, we have some tips if you plan to celebrate.

First things first, make sure you download and pay with the PayPal app (if you haven’t already) because it could help save you from the following scenarios:

  • Approximately one fourth (24%) of those surveyed, ages 21 to 44, have accidentally left their credit card at a bar/restaurant
  • 12% of respondents have paid for their friends’ drinks without getting paid back
  • 5% of those who go out for drinks at bars/restaurants have lost their wallets
  • 21% of those ages 21 to 44 who go out for drinks at bars/restaurants would rather pay with their smartphone than having to also carry a wallet 
 
I can confirm from personal experience that nothing is worse the morning after a night out with friends than having to play detective to find a lost wallet or forgotten credit card.

It’s not just St Patrick’s Day. I was at SXSW in Austin this week and left my credit card behind twice  - the first behind the bar at the Four Seasons and the second time in the check folder at a restaurant before I got my flight back to SF. I got my card back the first time but now have had to cancel it, as it’s in Austin and I am back home now.

It’s these kinds of situations that make me glad I can use the PayPal app in so many places (although unfortunately not the ones I left my card in in Austin) – you can pay how and where you want without worrying about losing anything! You can take the hassle out of paying the check or easily pay friends back in just moments with the app. Not to mention you can find great deals at local spots – why pay full price for corned beef and cabbage when you don’t have to?

We hope you have a safe and fun St. Patrick’s Day.

*This survey was conducted online within the United States by Harris Poll on behalf of MSL Group from March 6-10, 2014 among 2,061 adults ages 18 and older (among whom 1,984 are ages 21 and older). This online survey is not based on a probability sample and therefore no estimate of theoretical sampling error can be calculated. For complete survey methodology, please email paypalhotline@mslgroup.com.

title: Thousands of Merchants Benefit from PayPal Working Capital Program, Now Extended

Darrell Esch, VP and GM, SMB Lending, PayPal

Thousands of businesses have successfully applied for PayPal Working Capital since the pilot program launched last September, including a number of repeat customers. Merchants are overwhelmingly pleased with how PayPal Working Capital allows them to repay their loan balance using a share of their sales, with no fixed payment dates to remember and no monthly minimums.   • We know that a small business’s time is precious and are pleased that 97 percent of those surveyed gave us the top rating of "very fast" on speed of application and funding.

More than half of borrowers reported using the loan to purchase inventory, including Steve Contratto, owner of CF Sales, a company that sells Logitech computer accessories. title: Introducing PassPort: A World of Global Sales Opportunity Awaits
content:
June 12, 2014
Carey Kolaja, Vice President of Global Product Solutions

In 1999, PayPal cofounder Peter Thiel laid out the company’s mission to “give citizens worldwide more direct control over their currencies than they ever had before.”

This remains our mission and it’s still our focus every day, and the worldwide element of that goal is perhaps nowhere better expressed than in our role enabling international trade for our millions of merchants. 

From small mom-and-pop shops to some of the largest enterprises in the world – and from the biggest economies on the globe to the fastest-developing newcomers – PayPal’s customers move billions of dollars in 193 countries.

Fueled by technology innovation, we have entered a period of time when the way in which people create, share, buy, sell, and trade with each other is fundamentally changing, and as a result we’re literally reinventing the world around us.

Introducing PassPort

One of the ways we’re changing the world is by making it smaller through technology. We’re connecting people from all over the planet through commerce. And today, with the launch of PassPort, we’ve made connections among countries, customers and small businesses even more simple and straightforward.

We surveyed our merchants and designed PassPort in direct response to what they want and need from a global trade partner. The result is a website designed to educate and empower small businesses with free tools to expand their global sales. PassPort provides country-specific guidance on seasonal sales peaks, including holidays and events; cultural customs, taboos and trends; shipping and distribution logistics; currency exchange and fees, and customs procedures and taxes. 

And the timing is right. According to a recent study by McKinsey & Co., international trade is increasing at an unprecedented rate, driven (again and predictably) by technology: global Internet connectivity, the pervasiveness of mobility as a mode of commerce (more than two-thirds of the world has a mobile phone, and more ways to shop than ever before).

Commerce is About People

The numbers are undeniable, but what I’m most proud to have addressed with this program is the human element. Commerce is all about people. Our role is to empower this People Economy – to make the experience of both buyers and sellers more seamless and delightful everyday. And as the person-to-person connection goes global, we help lower barriers among the world’s citizens, helping them better understand each other’s cultures, tastes and habits with tools like PassPort.

At PayPal, we see the unlimited opportunities in the People Economy and we’re excited to be part of this era in which People Rule.

title: Music & Tech: PayPal’s Going to Bonnaroo! Are You?

title: PayPal Now Available in Over 200 Markets
content:
June 16, 2014
Rupert Keeley, SVP, PayPal EMEA 

The original promise behind PayPal was to give people more direct control over their money. This wasn’t a promise we were making to a few. Our mission was to change the way the world thought about and used money. Over the years, hundreds of millions of people have come to share in that promise. This week we reached a major milestone on our global journey. Starting from today we will be rolling out PayPal to ten new markets, taking the total number of markets we serve to 203.

Over 200 markets now enjoy a safer and easier way to pay online. 

For the people of Belarus, Cameroon, Côte d’Ivoire, Macedonia, Moldova, Monaco, Montenegro, Nigeria, Paraguay, and Zimbabwe, this will not be the first time they have had access to global commerce. As technology continues to break down barriers, the world is getting smaller. We can buy the things we want from almost anywhere in the world and many people in these ten markets rely on overseas websites to get access to the goods and services they can’t find at home.

The problem is that people are understandably wary of providing credit or debit card information to a storeowner they don’t know who operates in a distant country. For the sellers too, accepting credit or debit card payments from buyers in a market they know little about can feel like a risk.

Now, by registering for a PayPal account, the people in these ten markets can shop online at millions of websites with the peace of mind that comes from knowing we don’t share their financial information with any merchant.  

And, if something does go wrong – a product doesn’t arrive or doesn’t match the seller’s description, for example – they have the added assurance that they may be reimbursed the cost of the purchase and the postage on eligible items, thanks to PayPal Buyer Protection.

Of course, this is all great news for businesses as well. Ten new markets means more opportunities for businesses to sell their goods and services backed by the reassurance of one of the world’s most trusted ways to make and receive payments.

Why these markets and why now, you might ask? It takes a lot of careful planning and preparation to enter a new market, and we take our responsibility to manage people’s money very seriously. We believe we can seamlessly integrate these markets into our platform and provide the investment and resources needed in things like customer service. More importantly, we believe there is demand. Demand for a safer way to pay and take part in the global commerce revolution.

We’re delighted that we can be there to help and to continue to deliver on our promise.

title: Business in the New Economy: Real Connection First Requires Real Listening
content:
June 19, 2014
Peter Shankman, Founder, ShankMinds Business Masterminds

I spend most of my days speaking, consulting, training, and most importantly, meeting people. I’m going to know everything about the person sitting beside to me on my next flight, because I’m the one who’s actually going to strike up a conversation, pay attention, and show interest.

Welcome to the People Economy, where it comes down to listening before anything else. In other words, let the world come to you.

A Two-Way Street

When you sit back and pay attention to what’s going on, it’s easier to read between the lines. For example, recognize the way a client is wordlessly asking to be connected to and respond accordingly. If they call you, call them back. If they email, respond by email. If they’re chatting you, be available to respond live. And don’t match them just by medium, but by the way they engage, beyond sales or official business. If they’re posting on your social chatter, engage in real conversation.

When you play by their rules, you’ll be rewarded with an authentic connection.

And when it’s personal, your customers have a part, a voice. Who is more likely to buy: the customer who doesn’t feel connected, or the one who feels like they’ve actually helped you? This may seem obvious, but so many companies haven’t gotten the hint.

One Way Traffic Can Lead to Head-On Collisions

You’ve seen it in the one-way “conversations” that turn out to be all pitch. You learn quickly that those don’t last long. The door gets slammed. So listen, pay attention then reach out – not with something to sell, but rather, when you can offer help. Today’s winners earn that title by being top of mind when people want to buy. People rule this new world.

Think back to the last amazing experience you had with a company. About the brands you really love. Be like them.

Everything now is powered by personal experiences. What kind of experience are you giving to your customers?

Peter Shankman is a customer experience evangelist, and author of the best selling “Nice Companies Finish First: Why Cutthroat Management is Over, and Collaboration is In.” His next book, Zombie Loyalists: Breeding The New Army of Customer: Comes out Fall of 2015. His life is online at www.shankman.com

title: The Store of the Future Brings Back the Personal Touch
content:
April 28, 2014
Contributing Writer

Imagine a day of shopping. You walk into your favorite store and a sales associate greets you by name. Your size and style are in the store’s system, so a dressing room is prepped with options based on your previous purchases and browsing history. Next you spot some shoes you like but they’re not in your size. A salesperson whips out a tablet, orders a pair from the location a few cities over, and schedules them to be delivered to your home that afternoon.

When it’s time to pay you realize you left your wallet in the car, but no matter. Your smartwatch – the same one that trained you on your run that same morning – takes care of the bill.

While this scenario may seem a bit far-fetched, it isn’t some sci-fi episode. This is the future of shopping: convenient, enjoyable and, most notably, extra personal.

In fact, the personal touch has always been top of mind. It used to rule retail, defining a time when shopkeepers held tabs for town residents and kept track of their growing families and changing needs. And – perhaps ironically - it’s the proliferation of new technology that will bring us back to that targeted experience in a more seamless way than ever before.

No Lines, No Worries

Already, retailers big and small are testing or deploying virtual fitting rooms, 3-D scanners, wallet-free payments systems (like PayPal’s!) and tags that provide reams of product information and technology to pitch you on the best deals. Meanwhile, sales associates armed with handheld checkout devices roam the sales floor looking to help you buy where it’s most convenient.

“That long line of cash registers in the store is going to fade away,” says Nikki Baird, analyst with Retail Systems Research. “Nobody wants to stand in line.”

And nobody will have to. Gartner retail analyst Jeffrey Roster claims the retail industry will experience more innovation in the next three years than at any other time in its history. “Stores need to be [a retailer’s] best asset. Not a liability.”

Your Preferences are in Control

One of the biggest opportunities for retail in the coming years will be the ability to recognize shoppers as they arrive. And instead of requiring a shop keep with an excellent memory, various technologies will enable the automatic authentication of visitors, opening up a whole new world of targeted experiences. Imagine receiving personalized offers based on previous purchases, or even your exact location in the store. If you’re lingering in the kitchenware section, for example, you might receive an alert for a coupon for a set of dishes.

Further, Brian Kilcourse of Retail Systems Research expects store shelves, whether in the supermarket or the shirt department, to include digital information overlays – made accessible through an app – so shoppers can get even more information that’s relevant and interesting.

A high-end boutique, for instance, may show information on how fabrics and clothes are made. Meanwhile, while buying salmon to cook for dinner, you might get a new recipe and wine tips.

The technology “plays up the information factor but also makes shopping fun,” Kilcourse says.

The Possibilities are Endless

A search for what will likely be the norm down the line turns up Seattle-based retailer, Hointer.

The retailer enables customers to scan tags on each item. The tags link to video clips or product highlights. When a customer is ready to try something on, they use the Hointer app on their phones and are directed to certain dressing rooms.

Within 30 seconds, the items appear in the dressing room via an automated system. Customers can order different sizes —or get help from a store associate—via a digital screen. Want to dump an item? Send it down a dressing room chute. No clutter.

A Better World for You, Me and We

And speaking of no clutter? Baird also expects more “showroom” stores. Instead of browsing racks of clothing, you’ll browse via touch screen. After picking items to try on, you’ll order them in the desired colors and have them shipped home. You’ll get a custom experience, and by stocking fewer items, retailers cut down on inventory costs.

Baird also sees more retailers devoting more floor space to services or events targeting their particular audience. Pet supply retailers, for instance, are already using ample retail space for grooming services or vaccination clinics. Meanwhile, outdoor gear retailer REI has event space where shoppers can listen to guest speakers.

In other words, the four walls of the store aren’t going to go away, they’re just going to look exactly like you want them to.

title: PayPal BattleHack Istanbul Names PiggyBank the Winner
content:
April 28, 2014
PayPal BattleHack Istanbul Names PiggyBank the Winner

This past weekend, BattleHack Istanbul became the largest hackathon in Turkish history, taking place at the picturesque Sait Halim Pasa Yalisi overlooking the Bospherous.

BattleHack judges awarded PiggyBank first prize. Toygar Dundaralp, Ahmet Turgut Kati, Mert Ozcan and Alan Sarpyilmaz, the team behind the hack, created the service to provide parents with a way to dole out their children’s allowances and restrict where it is spent. Through the integration of PayPal, children are able to also request money from their parents – or get it sent automatically – into their accounts. The service then  enables parents to provide input on which restaurants their children are able to spend their allowances. This way children are encouraged to eat at healthy restaurants instead of just fast food.

Second Place winner FitPal, also focused on health but combined a donations capability. The FitPal team, created the service to have a win-win outcome: Healthier people and donations to charities. Users of the app are penalized – in the form of donations to a charity of their choice – if they don’t do the quick seven-minute daily workouts.

In third place was Would Pay, an app that lets users set prices they are willing to pay for items online and get notifications when, or if, the price ever drops down to that amount.

True to BattleHack form, good food and drinks were served throughout the weekend. From speciality pastries and salads, to freshly-grilled corn and ice cream, Turkish hackers powered up and lasted through the chilly and rainy weekend. 

In its first year in Istanbul, BattleHack yielded 30 hacks and ideas from enabling homeless to obtain goods from monetary donations at specific locations to providing ways for payments via QR codes. Next up – the BattleHacks series will take on Toronto on May 31 – June 1.

title: Brand Evolution and the Role Millennials Play
content:
June 24, 2014
Christina Smedley, Vice President, Global Brand, PayPal

As I have mentioned, Cannes offers a great chance to meet with some of the industry's best and brightest to discuss topics of relevance to all of our endeavors. I was lucky enough to take part in a roundtable discussion put on by MSLGROUP and PRWeek that hit on a topic near and dear to many - millennials. Titled "Brand Purpose, Millennials and the Epic Creative that Engages Them,” the wide ranging conversation (it's amazing how much you can fit into two hours) hit on the many facets of why millennials are a force to be reckoned with.

One area that I am personally passionate about is the importance of brands to not only listen to, but engage with the people who use their products and services day in and day out. Times are changing - money is becoming mobile. Entire industries that didn't exist just a few years ago have capitalized on this, allowing for a variety of services from the swipe of your finger - personal drivers, on-demand food, you name it. Millennials (and the 21% of consumer spending they represent in the US) have embraced this change with more fervor than any other age group.

It's one thing to know who your customer is, it's another to engage with them effectively. In the case of PayPal specifically, we knew we had to do a better job of engaging with millennials. How did we do it? We went to the source. We sat back and listened - then made changes not based on what we thought would work, but what our actual users told us they needed. It wasn't just our users - this was an open conversation with our employees too. The average age of our web design team at PayPal is 26. They did an amazing job reworking PayPal.com in the past year, bringing a fresh and more engaging feel to the site. This past April, we redesigned our logo and launched a new brand identity all aligned with bringing the people behind our brand to the front, along with the people who use our products every day.

This is an ongoing conversation much bigger than one roundtable or one conference, but keep an eye on PayPal as we continue to evolve in this space. I look forward to hearing from you about where you see the biggest opportunities (and challenges) as we all learn together.

title: Believing in Yourself is “Powerful Currency”
content:
April 29, 2014
Melissa O'Malley, Director, Global Merchant and Cross Border Trade Initiatives, PayPal

British businessman, adventurer and philanthropist, Justin Packshaw, has just about done it all: he’s climbed Mount Everest, trekked to both Poles, sailed in the Whitbread Round-the-World Yacht Race, and just recently, finished a jet ski adventure along the Nigerian coast of West Africa from Cameroon to the Benin Republic.

In parallel, the father of two has built a global fashion brand with his wife, designer Tamsin De Roemer. Their luxury brand, De Roemer, features handbags, jewelry and clothing.

What’s his secret to mixing adventure and business? A healthy balance of drive and technology. Packshaw believes that having a sense of adventure is the key to being successful in both business and in life. And today’s technology affords him the chance to keep all those facets docked and connected.

“The ability to stay in touch is a fundamental shift in how we live our lives today. It’s why I’m able to tie my life to causes like charitable giving and education,” he explained. “Even in the most extreme parts of the world, I can pick up my phone and talk to my kids as they’re getting ready for bed. And whether I’m jet skiing down the African coast or riding horses across Mongolia, I can keep followers and funders abreast of progress.”

Packshaw recently took his story global with a TEDx Talk at the London School of Economics, titled “Make the Invisible Visible.” It highlighted how technology and “human endeavor” are making good things happen around the world. “Fear holds people back,” he said. “But if they can overcome fear, that self-belief is enormously powerful currency.”

Spirit Changes the World

To embody the spirit of People Power, Packshaw’s next adventure is to be part of a group that attempts a cross-country challenge. In August, they’ll run, walk, bike, swim and make it “under our own steam” from Buckingham Palace in London, across the English Channel, to the top of the Matterhorn on the border of Switzerland and Italy. The Virgin STRIVE challenge is a fundraiser started by Sir Richard Branson’s son, Sam and will benefit The Big Charitable Trust, a charity that helps young people in the United Kingdom achieve their goals.

Going the distance like Packshaw does shows people what’s possible. It’s an inspiration people need across all areas of their lives. “In business we want to inspire our employees. Recreating the old ties of loyalty, integrity, home, teamwork and esprit des corps that adventurers from the last century had will make any company or group stronger,” he said.

And because new technology lets us stay connected, and balance these work qualities with satisfying home lives, the ability to tackle what once seemed impossible is unprecedented.  

What will you overcome?

title: Technology Meet Fashion, Fashion Meet Technology
content:
April 30, 2014
Nina Garcia, Creative Director of Marie Claire Magazine and Project Runway Judge

When Google Glass first came out, someone asked me if I would ever wear it.  I said, “If Tom Ford designed one, I think I could do it.” Cut to a few months later and I was wearing it all over New York Fashion Week. No, Tom Ford did not design my pair. Yes, I may have looked like I walked off of the set of Robocop, but I wore them with such pride because it allowed me to bring the magic of New York Fashion Week to scores of people who have never experienced what it is like. I tweeted videos from the front rows of shows and I did interviews telling everyone about my experience with Glass because it truly did make the fashion week experience so much more fun for me. 

With that, my cover was blown. You see, when it comes right down to it, I’m just as big a tech nerd as I am a fashion nerd.  Always have been, always will be. I was first in line to get a Palm Pilot (remember Palm Pilots?). I was one of the first promoters of BlackBerry—I was even part of their campaign. Now, I have to have every tablet that comes out, and test almost every new phone. I am constantly on the look out for the next new gadget, but I’ll admit, until very recently, technology and fashion have not been on speaking terms. All that seems to be changing.  

In the past year, several big fashion/tech partnerships have blossomed. To name a few: Apple announced that they hired YSL’s Paul DeNeuve and Burberry’s Angela Ahrendts; Tory Burch paired with FitBit to deliver a more stylish version of the immensely popular personal fitness tracker; and Google Glass joined forces with Luxottica (the company that owns fashionable sunglass brands such as Ray Ban and Oliver Peoples) to develop a new line of Glasses that won’t stick out so much in the tents next year at fashion week. 

It’s official. Fashion and technology are getting serious about their relationship. And there is love there. So much love, in fact, that analysts at Credit Suisse estimate that wearable technology will grow to a $50 billion industry over the next 3-5 years. What excites me most is that this kind of revenue will not only be generated by big names in fashion, but entrepreneurs with good ideas and the guts to pursue them. Like the Everpurse, a line of handbags that charge your phone. The company was founded by Liz Salcedo, who raised funds on Kickstarter.  Or the MEMI, an iPhone compatible bracelet that vibrates when you have a call.  You can also set it so it only vibrates when important calls come through and you don’t have to be a slave to your phone 24/7.  It was created by two moms, not surprisingly.

Every morning, I am hoping for the next big partnership announcement from companies like Samsung, Apple, Instagram, and Microsoft. Technology is becoming more and more interwoven into the fabric of our lives; it is only a matter of time before clothing will adjust to the temperature of our bodies and we will be able to record moments with the bat of an eyelash. And, as the market becomes over-saturated with product, the need for designers and curators will become ever more apparent. I think we will see that content will take center stage, not just the gadgets themselves. 

A door has just started to open, my smart designer and techie friends. Don’t be afraid to walk through it. I know you have ideas. I see your tweets and your Instagram comments and your Pinterest posts. Tell me, what are the wearable tech products you are most excited about?  What partnerships do you dream about?  But really, tell me what are products you want to see someone design?
