title: Six Best Practices to Improve your Online Checkout
content:
May 28, 2014
Chase Jones, SMB Marketing Manager, PayPal

It’s the biggest problem of selling online: getting customers to complete the purchases they initiate. The good news is that there are several things you can do to improve your online checkout – and turn more shoppers into buyers. Below, we’ve summarized six ideas to improve your online checkout pulled from our checkout best practices white paper.

1. Put yourself in your customer’s shoes

Too often, businesses develop websites without experiencing the checkout process from the customer’s point of view. But doing so can be illuminating.

Do some user experience testing. It doesn’t have to be professional: ask friends and family—ideally people who know nothing about your website­­—to try to buy some products. Watch them as they shop and note where they hit snags. Just five or six “testers” can help uncover your biggest problem areas.

2. Streamline your checkout process

The more steps in your checkout process, the higher the likelihood for cart abandonment. It may sound harsh, but think of it like this: The more form fields (and screens) customers face, the more likely they are to abandon a purchase. To streamline your checkout, focus on removing roadblocks on the path from selection to completed purchase.

3. Keep your eyes on the prize – the sale

It can be tempting to use the checkout process to gather as much information as possible. But “can” doesn’t always equal “should.” Only ask for information required to complete the sale. Remember that a quick, successful checkout nets you that most valuable result: a happy customer who is more likely to return for future purchases.

4. Think mobile

Nearly 75% of mobile shoppers will abandon sites that aren’t mobile optimized,1 so make sure your site is mobile-friendly:

  • Accommodate small screens. Ideally, your site’s design should adapt to the device it’s viewed on, working on smaller screens as well as it does on larger ones.
  • Use larger fonts (14 pt. or higher) and bigger buttons. Place call-to-action buttons (like Add to Cart or Check Out) at the top and bottom of each page.
  • Test. There are services that show you what your site looks like across multiple operating platforms and devices. Choose ones you think are most important and make sure your website is optimized on them.
  • Use PayPal to streamline the checkout. PayPal account holders can check out using only a mobile phone number and 4-digit PIN. The experience is optimized for mobile devices—with fewer clicks and less typing. 
5. Keep customers informed

Giving customers the right information at the right time can minimize confusion and set expectations.

  • Eliminate surprises. When a shopper adds a product to the shopping cart, display the description, price, shipping cost, and tax. 
  • Provide a map. A flow diagram or numbered steps (e.g., “3 of 4”) can help situate customers, reducing anxiety and frustration.
  • Brand the checkout. Add your logo to the PayPal checkout page. It boosts confidence that customers are on the right path and can translate into a conversion lift.
6. Put PayPal to work for your business

Showing shoppers you offer PayPal can have a powerful effect. Customers who use PayPal tend to follow through: PayPal transactions have 70% higher checkout conversion than do non-PayPal transactions.4

  • Take advantage of the strongly positive association shoppers have with PayPal. Add the PayPal acceptance mark on your home page, ideally “above the fold” – so the viewer doesn’t have to scroll down to see it; Product pages, since many customers land on product or category pages via search engines, bypassing your home page; On the checkout page of your shopping cart to reinforce the PayPal association at the time of purchase. 
  • Promote Bill Me Later®. Let customers know they have access to financing3 by placing Bill Me Later banner ads on pages where customers make purchase decisions. It can help drive an 18% increase in sales.4 
  • Take the express route. The Check Out with PayPal button gives customers a shortcut, making cart abandonment less likely. Place it next to your standard checkout button on your cart/checkout page. 
PayPal Can Help

As your business partner, PayPal can help you review your checkout setup and pinpoint changes that can help lift conversion, reduce cart abandonment, and create a better shopping experience for your customers. To learn more, download the full white paper.

1 Harris Interactive survey, 2011.

2 PayPal study conducted by Nielsen Buyer Insights in Q3 2013. The study examined online conversion rates for PayPal transactions versus non-PayPal transactions across 11 categories for 34 merchants.

3 Bill Me Later is subject to consumer credit approval, as determined by the lender, Comenity Capital Bank. 

4 August 2013 commissioned study conducted by Forrester Consulting on behalf of PayPal titled “The Total Economic Impact of PayPal’s Bill Me Later Financing Banners.” Data reflects a composite organization’s online incremental sales and a 3-year, risk-adjusted return on investment, based on the organizations interviewed for the study.

title: Introducing Our New Global Brand Campaign and New Brand Identity
content:
April 30, 2014
Christina Smedley, Vice President, Global Brand, PayPal

We believe in a world that works for people. That’s why everything we do at PayPal revolves around YOU and something we call The People Economy. From its first day to today, PayPal has revolutionized the way people across the globe think about and use money. We know the world is changing, devices are getting smaller and wearables will become the norm as people adopt new connected devices. We know our customers, and those who aren’t yet, are eager to understand what this means to them every day.  And we wanted to celebrate the 148 million people who experience our company every year.

Our New Global Brand Campaign 

For the first time PayPal is unveiling a global brand platform and campaign.  Powering The People Economy is a celebration of who we are. It’s populist, inclusive, empowering – inspiring action and inviting people of all stripes to join in. It celebrates the moments that make our life just that little bit simpler and more magical. But more than that, it’s an expression of what we stand for as a brand and what we want for the world as a whole.  No matter if you are a merchant or a developer, a consumer or an employee. 

Our campaign will appear across all paid, shared, earned and owned channels -- wherever in the world people see it. The characters we feature are people just like you and me: happy, proud, busy in their lives and looking for ways to make it more frictionless. They are people with positive energy who believe in actively making the world work better for them. Our illustrative style is fresh, modern and human. Our type treatment has a hand-drawn feel that makes it friendly and populist.

We see our global brand campaign as a story. The entire story embeds us in culture, and each chapter addresses a PayPal benefit we want to educate our audience about – from our basic offers and security, to availability and merchant partnerships.

The voice of Powering The People Economy is expressed through People-isms: simple pieces of language that elevate our product features into moments of personal empowerment. People-isms capture what we do best, and how we enable folks to get what they want and demonstrate our understanding of their lives, while celebrating the human spirit. You can see a few of our favorites here:  http://bit.ly/PPEvideo

We aim to inspire people to join us and enjoy a world where no one is special – because, well, everyone is. After all, it’s not money that makes the world go round. People do.

Refreshing Our Identity

When PayPal was first founded in 1998, our image was designed for the online world…making it easier to pay and get paid online…right as consumers were considering e-commerce for the first time. Today, online is just one of the ways we show up to our consumers, merchants and developers, along with in-store, on mobile and elsewhere. To reflect the dozens of ways we make it easier and safer for you to use your money every day, we’re pleased to share our new logo, designed to exemplify that simplicity, convenience and security in this new omni-channel world.

With the help of award-winning design firm, fuseproject and feedback from people who use our products every day, our new brand identity flexes to fit all screen sizes, from wearables and mobile to the biggest, flattest high-definition TVs.  It’ll be more legible and recognizable in both type and colors and will easily extend to be usable across the look/feel of various systems, and in the 193 markets we serve worldwide. Connection is a motivating principle behind the redesign — connection to money, to people and between people. It was important to evoke connection that was human and approachable, not too technical. 

You can look for our new identity to appear throughout 2014 across the globe not only on our website, which receives 19 million unique visits daily, but also wherever else you see PayPal including checkout buttons, our diverse range of apps, PayPal Here devices, marketing materials and sales collateral. In terms of our merchant partners, you can see the new PayPal identity at Saks.com or zulily.com beginning today! 

Take a look here: 

At PayPal, we have always prided ourselves on leading a revolution as a brand. And with our environment changing so rapidly, now is a time to evolve based on the needs and changes in the marketplace. 

So, what do you think of these changes? Let us know your thoughts, because at PayPal …..People Rule.

content:
May 28, 2014
Ditch the Gym Membership - Welcome to the Fitness Tech Revolution

Depending on how you look at it, there’s never been a better time – or less opportunity to make an excuse – to get fit. 

Now more than ever before, the roadmap for healthy living is accessible and affordable. You don’t need to join an expensive gym to get fit, or take a culinary class to sharpen your cooking skills. The ability to connect to your favorite health app from any device and choose from staggering number of workouts and healthy recipe options is pretty astonishing. 

Welcome to the new world of wellness, where innovations in social and mobile technology have officially leveled the barrier to entry. Your personal trainer and chef are now one click away. 

As a fitness and nutrition specialist, corporate wellness director and contributing editor to Shape magazine, it’s been exciting to have a front-row view observing all the ways technology is completely transforming the wellness industry. Even though I’m a proud millennial and “digital native,” I even surprised myself with my initial hesitancy to welcome this new age of democratized health and fitness. My business is built on the client’s need for a capable, expert teacher – if everyone has access to a personal trainer in their pocket, why would they need my services?

I’m happy to admit, oh, how wrong I was! Embracing this notion of “fitness for the people” has only created positive changes in my business. I see every platform – apps, blogs, social media – as an opportunity to connect with new people, share my workouts, recipes and healthy living tips, and build and run my business.

For example, apps like PayPal and Venmo have made everything run much smoother for my clients and myself. As anyone who owns their own small business will tell you, we don’t have the time or energy to deal with the hassle of billing clients or cashing checks. My personal training clients can pay me on the spot for a class - it's simple and seamless, so we can worry less about the hassle of payments and instead just focus on getting fit.

Goodbye VHS, Hello App Store!

In tracking the evolution of modern, accessible fitness, let’s first give some credit Jane Fonda, who was really the first to deliver workouts to the masses. Suddenly, for millions of men and women, working out became less of a chore – they could cut the gym out of the picture and just pop in a VHS tape at home. 

Long gone are the days of leg warmers and headbands. Today, there are many affordable alternatives to the gym that all help you train harder and smarter. Apps like Fitocracy, RunkeeperandNike Training Club all essentially serve as personal trainers in the palm of your hand, offering customizable workouts for every skill level, detailed progress tracking, and social/motivational elements – for example, Nike Club users have the ability to send and receive inspirational messages to/from other Club members.

With all of these apps, the social and gamification elements are especially important – the ability to motivate and connect with other users through competitions and group challenges, support groups is what keeps us coming back for more.

But Let’s Not Forget the Human Element

While we should all celebrate the accessible fitness options that this technology boom has ushered in, I think it’s equally important that we maintain our personal connections. In some ways, these apps keep us more connected than ever before, but they can never replace person-to-person interaction – and after all, the best motivation comes from other people. This is where we really thrive and push ourselves the hardest.

One startup that has done an incredible job bringing together local, fitness-focused people together is the Fitmob app, which connects its users to fitness professionals offering gym-independent group workouts in their own neighborhood that are fun, affordable and effective. The best part? It has all the benefits of your neighborhood gym (community-based, group workouts) and none of the drawbacks (pay on the spot for what you want – no membership fees!).

A world of health and fitness is right at your fingertips – now go take advantage of it, and I don’t want to hear any excuses…or drop and give me twenty!

title: PayPal BattleHack Toronto Packs the House at MaRS Discovery District
content:
June 03, 2014
Jonathan LeBlanc, Head of Global Developer Evangelism, PayPal

This past weekend, BattleHack became the largest hackathon ever held in Toronto’s MaRS Discovery District, one of the world’s largest innovation hubs. Housed in a 1.5-million-square-foot complex located in the heart of Canada’s largest research cluster in downtown Toronto, MaRS supports and hosts some of the biggest technology events in the area.

BattleHack judges awarded first prize to Team Angry Kittens for their Security Blanket hack project. Team members Alex Christodoulou, Ernst Riemer, Maya Kenedy De Magyarpade and Christopher Larsen built the service to quickly crowdsource and find lost children and get them home safely. Through the integration of PayPal, Security Blanket users are able to donate funds to help find children and also provide sensors for those who need them. The Toronto team winners will compete to win the $100,000 grand prize with the otherworldwide teams in San Jose this coming November. 

“When we were thinking about what to build, we just wanted to address what’s important to people,” said team member Christopher Larsen. “And for people, kids are just so important.”

The team also believes that their project can be expanded to all those who need careful monitoring of their whereabouts, such as Alzheimer’s patients and pets. 

The second place winning hack, Small Change, is a micro crowdfunding mobile app game for children. The app allows kids to browse and discover local charitable causes daily and fund them via a virtual currency of balloons. Each balloon equals $1 and parents can pre-load the app with balloons from the built-in 'PayPal bank.’

BattleHack judges awarded third place to Parkle, a mobile app that allows people to pay for parking using PayPal on their mobile phone by automatically completing the transaction when they return to their car.

Throughout the event, hackers were fed Canadian treats such as a poutine bar which consisted of French fries with a choice of three types of gourmet toppings and “Beaver Tails,” a unique Canadian dessert consisting of a fried pastry topped with icing, chocolate, fruit and nuts. Of course, BattleHack mainstays of massages and a happy hour bar kept stress levels low and the environment fun and unique.

In its first year in Toronto, BattleHack yielded 35 hacks and ideas from enabling local food growers to sell or donate their crops to using PayPal to donate money to street artists to enabling the visually-impared to launch and search Kijiji, Canada’s most popular free local classified site, owned by eBay.

title: Human Tech: Speaking
content:
June 04, 2014
Sarah Austin, Internet Personality, sarahaustin.com

The Valley bubble seems obsessed with the “Internet of Things.” Things are getting smarter. Devices talk to each other and people are now starting to talk to them. Things are evolving to make decisions, gather information, and just take care of stuff for us.

For a lot of people, it sounds too crazy. But we already benefit from the start of this shift. 

Take Thai food for example. You ask your phone, and it gives you a list of options. But why doesn’t it filter out obviously bad ones? Or determine that it only need show the closest location of the restaurant chain, and that if two places have a nearly identical menu, but one is 20% more expensive and a mile further away, it shouldn't come up in your immediate results?

This is the future of tech. As humans, we want choices, but we don’t want 100 choices.

Making the AI Vision a Reality

Movies like Her and Rosie from The Jetsons help paint a picture. Siri gave the iPhone a personality, but we need to learn commands, so we're not quite at a human experience yet.​

But we’re getting there in a few ways. 

Plexi NLP has taken Natural Language Processing (NLP) to the point where computers can replace humans on mundane tasks like certain research, data entry, and data base queries that formerly required not only a human, but one with a solid technical background.

The leaves humans more time to focus on the things they are best at – and that require a human touch. The computer becomes your IT person, rather than you working for it. It flips the need to hire tech savvy young employees in place of those with more field expertise. This isn’t just a win for those who struggle to keep up with changes in software, but to everyone, because the focus and resources shift from teaching software, to teaching customer service, domain expertise, and sales techniques that ultimately positively impact people at every stage of interaction with the company.

Death to the TPS Report

The drudge work of Office Space and creating “TPS Reports” will no longer require people. Software will compile data and author reports for people to then add color, commentary and analysis. But all the heavy lifting will be done by software.

As “things” start to communicate, it means more sensors, more data and a shift of programming to a series of simple “if” and “when” statements: If it starts to rain, close the windows if they are open. When it stops raining, open them if the outside temperature is between 68 and 75.”

Schools will teach kids logic and coding in 1st grade. Not traditional coding, but procedures entered by voice. After the second grade, rote memorization will be less of a priority, because anything you would want to know is an easy ask away. 

Again, this frees up resources and focus -- in this case, for critical thinking. Information retrieval and computer programming will become the new science and social studies curricula. This may sound like something we’ve seen on Star Trek: the Next Generation, but it’s on its way.

And all it means is that tech moves more the background, so we humans can focus on what’s unique to us. Our power. Our humanity. I can’t wait to see what’s  unleashed.

title: Our Employees are the Power Behind the People Economy
content:
May 01, 2014
Kristen Gohr, Director, Global Employee Communications, PayPal

Yesterday we announced the launch of PayPal’s first global campaign: “Powering the People Economy.” This is a really exciting moment for me and many of my colleagues. We’ve waited a long time to tell the world the PayPal story, to share our passion for the work we’re doing, and to celebrate the people we are doing it for.

When I joined PayPal, I didn’t know exactly what I was signing up for. I knew it would be an adventure, and a place where I could take my passion for people (particularly employees) to the next level. Almost four years later, I see clearly our vision to reinvent money coming to life. I look around at my coworkers and I see a shared purpose and vision. Most of all, I look at our customers, and see how our work actually makes people’s lives easier.

That’s the part of the “Powering the People Economy” campaign that most people won’t see - the story of more than 14,000+ people who come to work every day to create experiences our customers love. To do the right thing. To innovate. To make life easier. And most importantly, to reinvent money for millions of people around the world. They are the heart of PayPal.

That’s why we knew our employees had to be at the center of the brand campaign launch. “Powering the People Economy” is their heart and work on display. So we selected a handful of employee ambassadors from around the globe who embody a “People Rule” spirit , and invited them to New York to star in their own commercials – with the same artwork, set, star treatment and other elements that went into the commercials we are currently running as part of our first global brand campaign.

How do these individuals ensure each day that People Rule?

By shortening the queue for much-needed morning espresso…

By telling the truth – even when it’s hard to hear, to make sure the team is working well…

By celebrating teammates’ humanity, from birthdays to babies…

And by making sure people have toast.

Curious? Find out more, beginning this Friday, May 2 and throughout the next 4 weeks, where each Friday we will feature a new employee ambassador and their commercial here on PayPal Forward.

title: Music & Tech: Experience Governors Ball with PayPal
content:
June 05, 2014
Featuring Anuj Nayar, Senior Director of Global Initiatives

Anyone who knows me knows that I love music festivals. A real expression of passion for music comes to life at them, and they’re growing at an incredible rate. Fans attended twice as many festivals in 2013 compared to the year prior.

And while the chance to see some of your favorite acts in one place over a three day period is amazing, let’s be honest: festivals can also be a huge pain in the you-know-what. ATMs are few and far between and often run out of cash. Many vendors only take cash and for those that do take credit cards, they are often sharing one clunky POS system between many sales people, causing a backlog when customers start to pay with cards. And don’t even get me started about your festival buddies who conveniently don’t have cash to pay you back after you have just bought them another round of festival beers.

With that in mind, PayPal is going to be at some of the biggest music festivals in the US this summer to help attendees deal with the pain points of the existing ways to pay when all you want to do is hear great music.

First up: Governors Ball in NYC this weekend.

PayPal + Governors Ball

At Governors Ball this year, (June 6-8 at Randall’s Island), PayPal will give New Yorkers a simple and carefree experience that will allow them to pay how and when they want. At the heart of the festival, 13 of the best food vendors (full list below) will be accepting PayPal via the PayPal App. Even better? Users will be able to automatically redeem a $5 offer at each and every one of the vendors by simply “checking-in” to pay, without ever having to take out their wallets. 

 

So, what does this mean? For one, a nice discount on some delicious Belgian fries with wasabi mayo from Pommes Frites. It also means you won’t have to worry about having enough cash, finding an ATM, carrying a big wallet or potentially losing your credit card. 

Why worry about how to pay for your favorite eats if you don’t have to? 

Music Festival Aficionados

The weekend following Governors Ball, you’ll be able to find as Bonnaroo in Tennessee, and we’ll also be at Outside Lands in San Francisco’s Golden Gate Park in August. At each of these events we’ll be helping solve the most common pain points for festival-goers – from worrying that your wallet will give you a visible wallet bulge in your carefully curated festival outfit, to whether you have enough cash with you to get you through all 3 days. For vendors, it means having the mobile technology needed to help drive more sales by moving lines faster. 

Make sure to check back into see what we’ll be up to at Bonnaroo! And if you’ll be at Governors Ball this weekend, come find us and say hi.

title: The Daily Grind: Snagajob Takes the Hourly Job Search Mobile
content:
June 06, 2014
Peter Harrison, CEO, Snagajob

My first taste of work was pounding pavement – literally – as a street sweeper in London. It taught me skills I still use each day as a CEO, and an understanding of what it means to work for an hourly wage is part of why I’m so passionate about making life simple and seamless for the seventy-five percent of American workers who fall into that category.

These are the men and women working in retail, food service, hospitality, security, childcare and dozens of other industries that help drive our country. These are the people who are at the frontline of all our days.

Accordingly, many of the moments that can make or break a mood are delivered by the millions of people in the hourly workforce: from smiles at the coffee shop to friendly cashiers when we’re buying groceries with cranky kids in tow. The impact on productivity and human interaction can be enormous, but this group is too often forgotten in our conversations about innovation and the economy. 

As a result, until very recently (and indeed still in many cases) this incredibly important foundation has also been left out of many of the advancements we’ve witnessed in cloud and mobile services for job-hunts. LinkedIn, Jobvite and other solutions aimed to ease the process are often focused on salaried workers, and the convenience and mobility they deliver leave the hourly workforce out in the cold.

At Snagajob, as a network focusing solely on hourly employment, we are mission-focused on making finding a good match much easier for both job seekers and the huge brands that rely on them. We’re particularly interested in how mobile lets us reach younger generations, busy moms and other key groups in a way that suits their lifestyles. 

Mobile: the First Screen

And these are groups for which much of the benefit of the Internet was limited by the cost of personal computers and in-home networks. Today, rather than being the ‘second screen’ that many tech industry people consider the smartphone to be, mobile is actually the first access point for huge numbers of people – in the US and beyond. It opens a new world of possibility, in job hunting, in education, and dozens of other life changing areas. 

For example, rather than walking to the local mall or cruising around downtown with their resumes, a survey we conducted found that 72 percent of 16-30 year old Americans search for jobs on their phones.

We used to hear from our job seekers on a regular basis comments like, “I don’t have a computer and rely on the library to search for jobs. I only have 30 minutes to search and apply. Help!” That conversation has shifted today to, “I don’t have a computer and rely on my phone to search for jobs, but some sites aren’t mobile friendly.” 

The Personal Mobile Connection 

The flexibility of mobility benefits everyone, unlocking the power of the people to connect directly and maintain the human touch that the PC couldn’t do. It puts more power in the hands of the people – both hiring for and seeking jobs. 

For our customers, that personal connection is key because again, the hourly workers are the frontline of their businesses and have the magic to make or break relationships. Mobile – because of its intimate, always-on connectivity – delivers the power of big data and other Internet tools while maintaining the person-to-person touch that makes our world move. 

Our experience in the job market is huge for us and for both our corporate and consumer customers. But more importantly, it’s a great example of the HUGE impact that this people-to-people connection can have to put the world in greater balance. It literally puts incredible power in the hands of more and more people around the world every day.

title: Publishing in the People Economy: Micro-Multinational from Day One
content:
May 13, 2014
Leo Prieto, Founder of Betazeta Networks, Aardvark Labs, and ImageMaker Studios

Around a decade ago, innovations in science and technology were booming in Latin America, but I found myself frustrated with the lack of media coverage of these achievements. I had just sold my first company, and decided to start a blog called FayerWayer to write about technology (in Spanish) as a personal project, with no major ambition.

In the first couple weeks of publishing, I was surprised to find that not only was the readership growing exponentially by the day, but also many of the readers lived outside of Chile. It hit me that there was an eager appetite for coverage of the tech space, not just in Chile but all over Latin America – but there was no way I could take it on alone. I needed a team to support this effort, and perspectives that extended beyond my own Chilean roots. It only made sense then that the team had to cover innovation from all corners of the continent, so I began building a staff that reflected the blog’s growing multi-national audience. In a matter of weeks, we had put together a team that spread throughout Latin America, the US and Spain. 

I quickly realized that I needed a simple, seamless way to pay my contributors. PayPal provided a frictionless, fast and efficient payment system that allowed us to work with the best people possible, no matter where they were, and helped us think as a “micro multinational” from the very beginning, collaborating across borders. 

Today at Betazeta we have writers, designers, developers, and sales teams based in many different countries who are able to keep in touch, collaborate and be paid almost instantly. Just a few years ago, it would have seemed impossible to coordinate. Now? It’s seamless and simple. 

Global and Local is the Only Way to Go

Publishing in this new people-driven economy means we have to really reflect what the people want, which requires taking the pulse of their tastes and reactions, and doing so at global scale.  

One of the keys to our success is a new editorial process where we mix an editor’s intuition with the power of big data to understand what people want to read about – and are reading about – to focus our efforts on covering what really matters. 

The depth of data and analytics we bring to bear actually makes the human decision and input much more powerful.  Now, a single person, embedded in one country/culture, can make informed decisions about a truly global audience, because they’re based on patterns and facts that drill down to each locality and also show worldwide trends.  

Then we optimize it for various social networks and ensure responsiveness to varied mobile experiences, which is especially important in the developing world, like Latin America, where people are skipping PCs and going straight to a smartphones.  Smaller displays, touch-based input, and even the bandwidth requirements are considered to ensure efficiency even on spotty wireless connections in more remote regions.

Finally, we’ve opened our communities so that all our members can contribute content, creating a more engaging and diversified experience. This is their conversation. We’re honored to facilitate it.

To think how far we’ve come in such a short time is amazing; and I’m absolutely awestruck by the community of voices we’ve created that can be at once personal and global. We’ve been able to put the power of the people to work so successfully in publishing, which is often thought of as archaic and locally driven, it’s exciting to imagine what this borderless, connected world can bring to the future of other industries.

title: Manage Your Money on Your Terms with the Improved PayPal Online Consumer Account Experience
content:
May 15, 2014
Carey Kolaja, Vice President of Global Solutions at PayPal

Behind all of our products are people. People creating them for you. People using them to make life easier. You might have seen this with the recent launch of our new logo and brand campaign. We want our products to help people use their money how, when and where they want to. We aren’t creating technology for technology’s sake. We’re building experiences based on what we hear from you is important– and our revamped PayPal online consumer account experience is no different.

Today, we’re excited to show you PayPal’s new online consumer account experience. We’ve removed the clutter so you can see the things you really care about when you log in – like your balance, where your money is going or a shortcut to send and request money. And, you can do this with any device you choose – whether it’s a laptop, mobile phone or tablet. As long as it’s connected to the web it will reflect the same PayPal account experience.

We looked at what’s worked well with our consumer app. You’ve told us sending money on the go is a favorite and you like finding offers at nearby merchants. In the U.S. you’ve even given us four stars in the iTunes app store! So we made sure your online account reflected a lot of the same easy, simplified experiences. With the new PayPal we want you to know that however you interact with us, whether via the mobile app or your online account, you'll get a consistent PayPal experience.

Your new online account experience starts by getting back to the basics. For example, many people don’t know if you link a bank account to PayPal or use your PayPal balance, you can send money to friends and family in the U.S. for free. So as soon as you log in we’ll quickly get you set up to make sure you’re getting the most out of your PayPal experience.

Once you’ve put your explorer hat on and are navigating through the new experience – whether you’re on mobile, tablets or the web – you’ll discover:
  • A new account builder tool so you can get the most out of your PayPal experience
  • A home page that lets you see what you really care about such as your balance or status of transactionsShortcuts to your favorite tasks – like quickly sending money to a friend or downloading the PayPal app (come on, it’s easy!)
  • A simple way to send & request money across the globe quickly
  • An improved digital wallet so you can manage your money, payment methods and offers how you want to
  • Sneak peak of the upcoming PayPal shop tab – find exclusive online offers and savings
We’re rolling out the new experience to you starting with select consumers in the U.S. and Germany, and over the next few weeks more and more of you will get to experience the change.   

We’re excited about all of the updates, and we look forward to hearing your feedback on the new experience. We love to hear from our customers so we can continue to make our products better. Always feel free to share your thoughts with our product managers using the feedback links throughout the new site. We can’t wait for you to try it out for yourself!

title: Business in the People Economy: Selling Takes the Backseat
content:
May 16, 2014
Jeremiah Owyang, Chief Catalyst, Founder of CrowdCompanies.com

The term consumer has traditionally implied the passive consumption of goods and services doled out by businesses. But the times have changed. People aren’t simply consuming, but are empowered as active individuals to get what they need from each other, rather than buying from corporate channels. This means that established brands are going to have to revise their business models to partner with this empowered crowd, and to really partner with, vs. simply trying to sell at the people who now rule.

Welcome to the People Economy

This is the People Economy. The Collaborative Economy. I recently co-authored Sharing is the New Buying with Vision Critical on the topic, and what we found was both confirming and surprising.

While used-good sharing marketplaces are well established, Airbnb, Uber, Lyft, Lending Club and other tech platforms that allow peer-to-peer sharing (of accommodations, transportation and crowd-funding), are still in single-digit adoption. BUT, people surveyed indicated that they intend to double their utilization of these sharing services within the next year. 100% growth in a year! Imagine what it would take for a traditional corporation:seller relationship to see that kind of growth!

This is truly the people’s movement. Sharing pre-owned goods crosses demographic lines, even far into rural areas, and while some may think that’s recession related, it’s not. People making over $100K a year were morelikely to have used shared personal services to source transportation, homes, food, and more than most other groups.

And sharing goods is just the beginning. The rapid adoption of the Maker Movement is a perfect example of this new economy. The 9 percent of people who’ve bought custom, hand-made products in the past 12 months, is also expected to double in the coming year – creating an entirely new economy for both buyers and sellers.

Simply Put: People Rule

What does this trend mean? People are using new technologies to access goods and services from each other. Directly. They’re acquiring and sharing things, including money, directly. People Rule. They’re bypassing traditional corporations. The crowd is becoming functional and self-reliant. People can self-fund, make their own goods, share what they already have and provide specialized services to each other.

The call now is for business as we knew it – the incumbents being threatened by this movement – to stop thinking of how to sell to consumers and to figure out how to grow with the crowd. For example:

  • Lincoln Motors partnered with makers from CustomMade to build matching jewelry for high-end cars.
  • GE tapped a crowd innovation community in Quirky to build next-generation electronics.
  • Walgreens partnered with TaskRabbit to deliver prescriptions to homes.
  • Home Depot delivered Christmas trees on demand using idle Uber drivers last December.
  • Kelly Services formed an alliance with oDesk to provide additional workforce resources on demand.
For more examples, there are over 80 examples on this visual timeline of large companies partnering with the crowd.

 

People like me, people like you – we’re all proving we can get what we need and share what we have. It’s time to get on board — or risk losing the crowd.Large companies working with the crowd are helping to make a world that works better for us all. Who will be next?

title: Wallet-Free Fashion: Jay Strut's Top 8 Looks
content:
My 13, 2014
Jay Strut, Fashion Blogger, JayStrut.com

Every day, I get to live out my dream – I live, breathe, sleep and even eat fashion. I’ve come a long way from my days as an 11-year-old, self-taught web designer and coder, building my own Myspace pages and understanding what it meant to be an “online personality” in the early days of the modern Internet. These days, I’m jetting around the globe, attending runway shows, red carpet events and designer parties with the likes of Chanel, Michael Kors, Versace and Roberto Cavalli. And if I’ve learned one thing along the way, it’s this: fashion is all about making a statement – statement outfits, statement trends, statement personalities.

But you don’t want to make the wrong statement by carrying around an annoying wallet that’s totally out of synch with your look. Sure, the advent of the digital wallet may seem to some as the “solution without a problem” because they don’t see why paying with a card or cash is hard, but let me tell you, there are fashion problems to be solved!

No matter the season, there’s always at least one style you just can’t rock with a wallet. Let’s be honest: nobody wants to see someone wear skin-tight leather pants with an awkward-looking square popping out of their back pocket. SO not chic. 

Thankfully, a wallet-free lifestyle isn’t too far from reality. I look forward to the day when an entire wallet’s content can be compressed into a few finger swipes and taps on our phones. 

Until then, however, there are few key looks that are most definitely anti-wallet – and frankly, anti-cash – whether they’re pocketless, defined by clean lines or tight, tight, TIGHT. Loose coins and bills are not slowing down our style! From my fashion week uniform to hippy chic festival wear to the slimmest pair of skinny pants you can shamelessly squeeze in to (admit it), here are my top hottest wallet-free looks. 

Just say NO to the wallet bulge! 

1. Leather skinny pants

You just spent a year’s salary on a pair of Balmain skinny moto pants – don’t ruin the slim-fit look with an unsightly wallet bulge. (Balmain never makes pockets big enough to hold you wallet anyways!)

2. Beach chic

Effortless boho beach styles can be dragged down by spare change. Free your light chiffon cover-up from the weight. Instead, opt to store your cash in your chic beach bag or, better yet, go mobile!

3. White out

You're strolling around New York on a hot summer day – who wants to carry anything but a phone?

4. Fashion week uniform

At Fashion Week, I’m always on the go – and that means wallet-free. Who really has time to jump in and out of a cab and pull out their pocketbook, sift through their cards & bills? I’ve got a runway show to catch, hunnie! 

5. Festival season

When you rock out at Coachella or Lollapalooza, you don’t want to worry about dragging around a wallet or getting pickpocketed. Festival wear is supposed to be about floral patterns, crop tops and fedoras. It’s all about peace, love and being free (from your wallet!). 

6. Poncho

Pocketless ponchos have no room for the bulk of a wallet. Don’t add extra weight to an already heavy ensemble. Going wallet-less will lighten your outfit and prevent the fabric from pulling.

7. Crop top/pencil skirt combo

The crop-top pencil skirt combo has been a recent celebrity favorite with Kim Kardashian, Lupita Nyongo and Miranda Kerr. These outfits are not forgiving, so unless you have a personal assistant to hold you stuff, leave the wallet at home.

8. A Donatella Versace moment

Last but not least, when doing something as crazy and thrilling such as being on set with Donatella Versace for a one-on-one interview, believe me hunnie – your wallet is the last thing on your mind. Werk it!

title: You Are Not a Robot: How to Humanize Your Job Search
content:
May 05, 2014
Sharon Feder, Chief Digital Officer, Rachael Ray/Watch Entertainment

My senior year of college, I was both thrilled and terrified to jump into the working world, prove myself and build my new grown-up life. Like anyone else, I made a few mistakes – from bad interview suits (sorry, no pics) to accepting jobs that were not the right fit for me or the career I was looking to develop. Ultimately, I found the career I wanted: building digital companies and hiring the people who make them so special. I got to do this first at Mashable and now at Rachael Ray’s parent company, Watch Entertainment, but it was definitely a process to find what I loved.

Luckily, there are now more ways to connect directly to people than ever before, and for graduates, it’s the perfect time to take a quick moment to take stock of your hopes, dreams, talents – and online profiles – because you hold the reins in a way that’s often as terrifying as it is empowering.

Be Honest About What You Want

I remember realizing that leaving the dorms meant moving back in with my parents, so I wanted a paycheck that could help me rent an apartment sooner than later (love ya, Mom and Dad!). Stressing about this, along with the amount of responsibility you’re about to take on, is easy, but it’s not worth it. Decisions made out of fear or worry don’t often pan out the way we’d hope.

Back in the day, job-seekers literally hit the pavement looking to learn about what positions might be available, but now you can move faster through efficient and effective online research. While you’re suffering senioritis, browse through the job listings and sites of companies you think match your interests and skills. Do you know people who work there? Beyond the official listings and sites, check LinkedIn, Facebook, Twitter, etc. to do a little digging to see if their marketing and your perception of the company match what it’s like to work there (wait to reach out, though – we’ll cover that later). Company culture really matters, and this “homework” can help you be more thoughtful about where you apply.

As a next step, I’d recommend visiting The Muse, a career site that offers a very visual job board, training and daily stories that can help you as you start your search.

You Can Find What's Real, and Hiring Managers Can, Too

While you might spend hours perfecting your work history and polishing your LinkedIn profile, hiring managers will look online to assess your judgment and learn whether you’d be a good fit with the team they’re trying to build. It’s sad when a candidate with an ideal resume has to be turned away after a Google search takes them out of the running.

What happens when you Google yourself? Would a hiring manager find your Instagram and Tumblr account and like what they see? This can make the difference between getting hired and not. Distinguish yourself with a consistent presence; ditch typos and any potentially inappropriate content and position yourself as impressive and worth considering for the job – without stripping out all the personality that might make you perfect for the role you seek.

Feel it out, Firsthand

Once you’ve identified your industry of interest, find organizations, industry groups and meetups where like-minded people gather. For example, Community Managers Meetup gets NYC social media people together to learn, meet each other and find jobs. Not only can you do all those things, but you can garner honest and real-time information on what its like at organizations of all types and sizes.

And as you follow up with people you’ve met live or discovered online, be thoughtful and human (read: not too formal) and try to stand out from the crowd a little (this also applies to cover letters and thank you notes). Make it hard to not write back, because you’re so engaging.

They’re more likely to hire you if they enjoy messaging, and ultimately spending time with, you. But remember: you’re also more likely to enjoy a job that encourages you to be a well-rounded person, in addition to growing your specific skillset.

Harness the Human Element

These are just a few tips. The key truth across all of them is to really harness the human element of the job search. Our jobs are where we spend the majority of our waking hours – just as you want to find a place where you can learn and grow, hiring managers want to know the person they bring into their company will enhance their culture in return.

We’re people first, and our professional roles are just a part of that. In this unprecedented era of direct human contact, let what makes you unique shine through. Finding a job that appreciates that is part of what will help guarantee a meaningful, long-term role where both you and your new employer will benefit. 

Good luck, and if you’d like to chat about your own professional pursuits, don’t hesitate to ask me @SharonFeder!

title: OAuth, OpenID Security Flaw – PayPal Customers Not Impacted
content:
May 02, 2014
James Barrese, CTO, PayPal

As always, it's important to us to keep our customers informed, connected and aware of how we're addressing any concerns you have with our products or services.

When we heard that security researchers recently discovered a vulnerability in open source login tools OAuth 2.0 and OpenID (which are widely used by many websites and web services, including some offered by PayPal) we moved quickly to determine the impact to our customers. We have carefully investigated this situation and can tell you that this vulnerability has no impact on PayPal and your PayPal accounts remain secure.

We take the responsibility of keeping your financial details protected very seriously at PayPal. When PayPal implemented OAuth2.0/OpenID, we engineered additional security measures to protect our merchants and customers.  These measures protect PayPal customers from this specific OAuth2.0/OpenID vulnerability.

We want to reassure you that if your PayPal account is accessed without your permission, PayPal will help you resolve the problem and will cover 100% of any eligible transactions to keep your money secure.

title: Spontaneity Spawns a New Industry
content:
May 05, 2014
Sam Shank, CEO, HotelTonight

One thing that mobile technology has really enhanced, and in some cases entirely enabled, is a lifestyle that encourages spontaneity. Decide to stay at the office and won’t have time to cook? Eat24 can have food at your place by the time you arrive. Or maybe it's the last day of a trip and you want to stay an extra night. Kayak can help find a new flight.

One of the last bastions of the “old way” was figuring out where to crash at the last minute – because nothing kills spontaneity like having to spend time on the phone only to find a rate so high it kills the mood, or trying to enter details into a site not optimized for a small screen and thumbs.

My frustration with that distinct buzzkill is what led to the birth of HotelTonight, which has created a unique marketplace that helps hotels and weary travelers find each other in the magic moments when life presents a reason to change plans.

The Basics

Because it is only recently that people have considered last-minute hotel bookings, most hoteliers would just set and forget a flat rate for the very few last-minute bookings they might receive.

When we first got started, my co-founder Jared would get emails from hotels with their rates and allotments for each day – definitely not as sleek and seamless a back-end process as what we were offering bookers through the app. It was still a guessing game, with hoteliers taking a stab at a rate that might attract last-minute bookers that day, and then us building it into the app to test. 

So we decided to make the process for hotels as simple as it is for our buyers, delivering visibility across the entire market and the ability to make real-time changes to rates as they see what competitors are doing. 

We basically help hotels and their potential customers communicate with transparency and clear data. As people get more comfortable booking last-minute, hotels are able to see (through our data) what drives their decisions and make their offering as attractive as possible. It’s win-win-win, and it’s wild and invigorating to see how quickly it’s all taking off. 

Less Time Paying, More Time Playing

One of the coolest outcomes we’ve seen? Because we’re a mobile-only company, we made an app that helps them manage inventory on the go. Many have joked that we’ve helped turn something as dry as “yield management” into a game by making it so easy to play with rates as they look to beat competitors by optimizing revenue and occupancy.  

The result? The average hotel now switches things up at least 4 times a day, while in competitive, high-volume markets like New York City, it’s not uncommon to see a hotel change rates 10 times per day, making adjustments late into the night. 

Anaheim’s race to capture the Disney spirit is a great example of how spontaneity benefits everyone. Experimentation showed that reducing a room rate by 15% at 9pm can capture the business of a family deciding whether or not to make a late night trip to Disneyland, so they’re the first in line the next day to enjoy the park. 

The kids from these families are growing up in a world that will celebrate this level of last-minute adventure, seeding in them new values and appreciation for what might be waiting just around a corner. It’s so exciting to imagine the way that the human spirit will be empowered and rewarded as new tech and tools continue to help us realize our dreams.   

How else does technology empower spontaneity?

title: From Pastime to Full-Time – Building a Business in the New Maker Economy
content:
May 27, 2014
Kristen James, Founder, Gilded Shadows

The time has finally come when we can retire the term “starving artist.” Today’s talented makers no longer have to depend on local farmers’ markets and craft fairs to sell or find new customers.

Modern technology has opened a new door to the small business community, enabling them to sell their handmade goods online, process payments with the click of a button, and connect with customers all over the world. 

Online marketplaces like eBay and Etsy have transformed the way artists connect with buyers and sell their work. Social networking sites such as Facebook and Twitter can also make it easy to promote yourself, upload and share your designs, and stay in contact with your fans and customers. Having all of these platforms at our fingertips makes it possible for artists to turn their passions into profit, and sometimes, full-time jobs.   

Gilded Shadows

Turning that passion into a full-time job is exactly what I wanted to do. In the spring of 2011, a friend asked me to help her choose accessories for her upcoming wedding. I had always been interested in design and fashion – I love to sew and had dabbled in jewelry design, so I was more than happy to help her. After doing plenty of research online, I took a chance and made a headpiece myself. The experience of making the accessory satisfied my creative itch and she loved what I had developed for her. As a result, I offered to make headpieces for the rest of her bridal party as a gift. After the wedding, my husband and friends kept encouraging me to open an Etsy shop to sell bridal accessories. I’m an architect working a full time job in Los Angeles so opening an online business and adding to my already full workload made me a little hesitant. However, their reassuring gestures and that little voice in my head that kept saying “what if?” just wouldn’t go away.

So I listened to them and later that summer, I launched Gilded Shadows, an Etsy shop specializing in bridal headpieces, veils, and other accessories. In just three years, I have been able to turn my hobby into a successful online business. I still pinch myself over the fact that a hobby I love so much keeps me so busy with ongoing work!

On a daily basis, I get to interact with brides from all over the world and design unique handmade items that they get to wear on their special day. I also get to do business with other Etsy store owners who sell me lace, buttons, vintage fabrics, and millinery supplies.  I recently received an email from a bride that had photos of her in the veil from the wedding and a note that said, “Thank you for the veil. It was the talk of the wedding!” I take great pride when the brides can have that kind of experience from something that I created. I feel so honored to have been part of such a memorable day for them. This is why I love what I do.

Full-time Passion

I have many friends, vendors, customers and other supporters to credit my success to, but it’s also quite remarkable how big of a role Etsy and PayPal have played in making it all a reality.

In fact – it’s all so real that I’m actually planning the big next step of turning my architecture day job into a hobby and pursuing my Gilded Shadows business full time. I’ll be moving to Austin, Texas with my husband and two rescue dogs to embark on the next chapter of our lives – where I’m hoping to take Gilded Shadows to new heights – always aiming to make a bride-to-be’s day a little better, one handmade wedding accessory at a time.

title: eBay To Ask Users to Change Their Passwords, No Evidence PayPal Customer Information Accessed or Compromised
content:
May 21, 2104
eBay Inc. and PayPal

Later today, eBay Inc. will be asking all eBay users to change their passwords due to a cyber attack that compromised an eBay database containing encrypted eBay passwords and other non-financial information. eBay will notify its user base directly within the next 24 hours with more details. 

Extensive forensic research has shown no evidence of unauthorized access or compromise to personal or financial information for PayPal customers.  PayPal customer and financial data is encrypted and stored separately, and PayPal never shares financial information with merchants, including eBay.

In addition to asking users to reset passwords, eBay Inc. said it will also encourage any eBay user who used the same password on other sites to change those, too.

We will update the PayPal Forward blog and eBay Inc blog with more details later today.

title: When Time is Money, Mobile Moments Become Essential
content:
May 06, 2014
Brian Wong, Founder & CEO, Kiip

Mobile commerce is all about time. Saving time, the timing of when offers reach shoppers, the time it takes to transact, the velocity of the moment when the thought to shop strikes, the times and ways people use smartphones vs. computers, and the list goes on. 

It was based upon this “time = money” premise (not exactly a new concept!) that I founded Kiip in 2010. We’re always working to better understand how to become a part of people’s lives at the right moment, and for the right reason, tailoring rewards specific to their preferences and environment. For example, surprise you with promo for Sephora when you’re in a beauty app, or for fitness gear when you’re logging your progress in a workout app. It’s a win-win for shoppers and brands alike, because it’s a much more effective (and welcome) way to get their attention rather than just serving up another ad. 

When you really think about it, it’s hard to believe how quickly mobile has adapted to our lifestyle and habits. I’m particularly excited about a few key trends I’m observing that are really accelerating how often and how broadly we use our phones – and it’s no coincidence that it all has to do with saving us time.
Technology for the Speed of Life

Hipmunk does a fantastic job considering how and why people toggle between mobile and desktop when booking travel. They know price discovery and comparison is an easy task to accomplish when taking a bus or watching TV, but when it’s time to actually throw down a couple grand for a trip, many people are more willing to do that from their computer. So Hipmunk makes that SUPER easy, delivering a 5-letter code to copy from mobile into the website, so people can pickup where they left off and buy.
Companies like Postmates and Uber Rush are delivering on the promise of instant gratification from same-day (or even same-hour). And a huge number of exclusively mobile commerce sites have emerged – like Uber, Lyft, etc. – that exist specifically (and entirely) for the mobile moments of life. 

Why are these companies so successful? They remove friction from the process, and increase productivity, and that’s what mobile is all about – technology that moves at the speed of life, and not the other way around.
 
Instantly Moving Money

The ability to track purchase details by device, vs. by retail account is also a huge timesaver. Having your credit card information and shipping preferences stored by a third party like PayPal makes the mobile experience seamless and quick. It doesn’t require clunky, repetitive thumb-entry; it makes conversion from discovery to purchase almost instant; it doesn’t follow with a huge number of sales emails like you get from dozens of retail accounts; and your details and identity are protected at the device level, in some cases, with the added level of biometric security. 

We’ve come so far in 5 years, and I expect more change in the next 5 that will further enhance the simplicity and ease of buying. The death of the physical credit card is inevitable; the magnetic stripe and punched numbers will be a non-entity, because they’re only meant to verify identity and we’re advancing WAY beyond that in sophistication and unique personal identifiers: Your iris. Your fingerprint. Even your heartbeat, with Nymi – it's the first wearable to use biometrics to authenticate identity, and one of its first applications is set to be in payment and identification. 

What does this all mean for YOU? Well, most importantly, you’re getting more of your time back. You’re wasting less of it on crawling the Internet for airfare deals, waiting for taxis or picking up your dinner takeout. You don’t have to spend time to spend money. It has always been true that the most successful businesses are those that put people first, and the digital age is empowering and accelerating this in ways we couldn’t have predicted just a few years ago.

The potential is undeniable, and the future is now. It’s going to be fun – just imagine the possibilities.

title: Engage Kicks Off in New York - Small Businesses in the Big Apple!
content:
May 07, 2014
Dan Leberman, Vice President, GM of North America SMB Core/Online Business, PayPal   

Small businesses are the heart and soul of American business. We all support small businesses every day, from the deli around the corner we frequent because of their unbeatable turkey avocado ciabatta sandwich, to the online jewelry boutique whose help we enlist to avoid anniversary nightmares by ordering uniquely crafted gifts for our loved ones. Moreover, small businesses are the most critical driver of our nation’s economic health, creating more new jobs than large businesses every year. Given their importance, we all must find ways to more deeply support and help small businesses in their pursuit of growth.

PayPal is proud of its history of helping small businesses grow, but we are now doing more than ever. In that vein, I’m pleased to share that PayPal is a sponsor of National Small Business Week! title: PayPal BattleHack Berlin Winning App: Berserkers
content:
June 24, 2014
John Lunn, Senior Global Director of the Developer Network, PayPal and Braintree

This past weekend, PayPal’s BattleHack came back for a second time to the city known as the  ‘European Silicon Valley.’ The sixth installment of the series of hackathons worldwide yielded 28 hacks ideas ranging from organizing team sports and crowd-funding to elder care assistance to instant home delivery for people with disabilities.

At the sold-out event, BattleHack Berlin judges Sascha Karstädt, Yan Minagawa, Sabine Geithner, Nadahl Shocair and Chris Ibañez awarded the coveted first-place prize to the team, “Berserkers for Charity.” Team members Ulysses Hsiúng-Luó, Hoa Huynh and Andreas Osowski created a peer-to-peer local donation exchange allows you to donate to charities worldwide while still benefitting from the local rates and tax status. The application integrated both SendGrid and Twilio platforms to provide instant feedback to its users.

The Berlin team winners will compete to win the $100,000 grand prize with the other worldwide teams in San Jose this coming November.

BattleHack Berlin’s second-place winning hack, Ofertify, was created by Marek Kotewicz, Krzysztof Kaczor, Michal Hernas and Bartosz Hernas, and is a mobile application for posting local offers for time, service and goods. The team managed to impress judges by utilizing both Android plus iOS as target platforms and went even further by  demoing a companion application for the smartwatch Pebble.

In third place came AirPay, developed by team members Christoph Zamaitat, Christian Kroter, Jens Ravens, and Cedric May. The mobile application is a device-to-device payment system. Utilizing cutting-edge technology like Bluetooth Low Energy, the team managed to create an offline payment system for Apple’s iOS.

BattleHack continued its tradition of providing top-notch catering for attending hackers -- from speciality German pastries, salads and tacos to Bao Burgers, summer rolls and Guiness pie. BattleHack mainstays of massages and a happy hour bar kept stress levels low and the environment fun and unique.

title: Working with the Security Community
content:
June 25, 2014
Anuj Nayar, Senior Director of Global Initiatives, PayPal

Through the PayPal Bug Bounty Programwe were recently made aware of a potential way to bypass our two-factor authentication (2FA) log in process for a small number of our mobile products. As this researcher has chosen to share issue publicly and because your security is important to us, we wanted to share a bit more information with you.

First, we want to emphasize that all PayPal accounts remain secure. The workaround identified by the researcher is related to an extra layer of security (2FA) some customers have chosen to add to their PayPal account. Customers who do not use the PayPal security key (physical card or SMS codes) as an additional step to log into their accounts are not impacted in any way.

If you have chosen to add 2FA to your PayPal account, your account also remains secure and 2FA will continue to operate as usual on the vast majority of PayPal product experiences. Even though 2FA is an additional layer of authentication, PayPal does not depend on 2FA to keep accounts secure. We have extensive fraud and risk detection models and dedicated security teams that work to help keep our customers’ accounts secure from fraudulent transactions, everyday.

As a precaution we have disabled the ability for customers who have selected 2FA to log in to their PayPal account on the PayPal mobile app and on certain other mobile apps. These customers will still be able to log in to their PayPal account on a mobile device by visiting the PayPal mobile web site.

We know that our customers enjoy paying on mobile with PayPal and we do regret any inconvenience this may cause. Your security is our top concern and we will work as quickly as possible to resolve this issue for you.

title: Wallets on Wearables: Introducing the PayPal App for Android Wear™
content:
June 25, 2014
Richard Mercille, Senior Software Engineer, PayPal

At PayPal, we see wearables as a huge opportunity to create seamless, context driven payment experiences that truly change the way people interact with their devices. In fact, earlier this year we were proud to deliver the first payment experience on the Samsung wearable devices—with the Gear 2 and Gear Fit.

From a development perspective, this means creating a user experience that is designed specifically for wearables. The tiny device screens alone require developers to rethink the user interface (UI). A truly wearable optimized application has to be a completely fluid, streamlined and contextual experience. However, with new devices from multiple manufactures rapidly coming to market, without using a somewhat device-agnostic development approach, keeping pace presents a challenge.

With Google’s introduction of its Android Wear™ OS, developers are now better positioned to really drive innovation and take full advantage of the potential wearable devices present. As developer advocate Timothy Jordan explains it, Android Wear is “designed to be simple, glanceable and built on micro-interactions.”  For us at PayPal, this allows us to further accelerate our pace of innovation, we can design once and quickly tailor to support new wearable devices as they come to market. With Android Wear, we’re able to add just a few lines of code to leverage stacks, pages and simple notification replies. From there, with the full SDK, we can create totally unique Android Wear experiences. 

With the official release of the Android Wear SDK at Google I/O, we are excited to share what we’ve been working on. Starting this week, by leveraging the Android Wear OS and new SDK, we’ll begin to release the PayPal App on Android Wear to our Beta Community. And in the coming weeks, the PayPal App will be available on the latest Android Wear devices—including the recently announced Motorola Moto360 and LG’s G Watch. Once available, the PayPal app will allow Android Wear device owners, to check-in to pay at local stores, redeem offers, and receive payment notifications while on the go (and in some cases with just the command of your voice).

As new wearable devices come to market, I personally look forward to seeing where developers are going to take us. And as we continue with our ‘Wallet on Wearables’ innovation path, I look forward to quickly delivering the PayPal mobile experience to future Android Wear devices.

title: PayPal Brings Fingerprint Authentication to the Samsung Galaxy Tab S
content:
June 27, 2014
Matt Gromada, Director, Global Product Launch, PayPal

It’s been quite a year for biometric technology. Developers and leading manufacturers have been exploring how they can use biometric technology to simplify how people go about their daily lives in more secure and convenient ways. Using biometrics to revolutionize how people shop and pay has been top of mind for us at PayPal.

Our collaboration with Samsung means you can get convenience without sacrificing security across multiple devices, whether they are using a Samsung Galaxy S5 Smartphone or a Galaxy Tab S tablet.

PayPal fingerprint authentication on the Samsung Galaxy Tab S is rolling out across 27 markets globally. United States and Canada will start today and additional markets – including Australia, Brazil, Hong Kong, and United Kingdom – will follow this summer.

Maybe you’re finally making the move to a new tablet. Or maybe you’re joining the 42% of U.S. adults who own a tablet by purchasing one. title: PayPal Makes Next-Day Settlement a Reality
content:
July 07, 2014
By Steven Chien, Lead Product Manager for Money Management, PayPal

As PayPal has transformed over the last 18 months, we’ve focused on becoming a better partner to the millions of businesses we work with– online and in-store. Last fall, we introduced PayPal Working Capital, which is issued by the lender, WebBank, to help small businesses fund their growing companies. Last month, we unveiled the latest version of the online business account experience to help make it easier for businesses to manage their money.

We’ve also been listening to what our customers and business partners want so that we can address real issues head on. And, our business partners have been telling us that they want more control over their money. So, we’ve heard you.

Starting this month, we introduced Next-Day Settlement (NDS) for eligible businesses in the United States through a pilot program. 

With Next-Day Settlement, eligible businesses transferring money from their PayPal account to their bank account now have the ability to receive their money within 24 business hours instead of the three to four business days it used to take. And, as long as you make your transfer by 5 pm local U.S. time, you’ll have access to your money quicker than ever before. Again, we’ve heard your concerns so we’ve been working with our banking partners to optimize processes on both their end and ours so that we can make the 24-hour transfer a reality. Now that makes a difference. 

Businesses eligible for Next-Day Settlement have received notifications informing them that they can opt in to the program. But stay on the lookout because we want to help our business partners succeed, and we have more to come to help make this a reality.

title: Team DWAI Wins PayPal BattleHack Chicago
content:
July 01, 2014
John Lunn, Senior Global Director, Developer Network, PayPal & Braintree

This past weekend, BattleHack blew into the windy city, and Braintree’s hometown, for the first time. It was held at 1871, an awesome, collaborative space where Chicago’s digital designers, engineers and entrepreneurs join forces. The event showcased a total of 21 hacks that integrated PayPal APIs as well as Braintree and Venmo SDKs.

With alcoholic slushies, hand-brewed coffee, Korean chicken wings and relaxing massages on their side, the hackers braved through 24 hours to bring their code to life and impress our panel of judges.

BattleHack judges awarded the RePOTr app, from Team DWAI (Don’t Worry About It) the first prize. Team members Stefan Aleksic, Eson Musabelliu, Nishanth Samala and Ray Perry created the app using existing mobile technology to locate potholes in Chicago, compile data and find solutions to fill these potholes. The application uses an accelerometer in smartphones to detect potholes when driving and informs the city department of their location throughout Chicago. Moreover, with crowd funding, through the integration of PayPal and Braintree, users can allocate funds towards specific projects that can then be used to fund private contractors and fill the potholes.

Second place winner PayBack created a mobile app that makes it easier for friends to split bills. PayBack uses facial recognition technology and Venmo, to let you divide bills amongst your friends by just taking their photo. In third place was Almost Home, developed by John Geletka, Tyler Travitz and Len Kendall. Almost Home, connects you with people who live nearby and pay them to receive packages for you, when you’re not available.

Team DWAI will now represent Chicago and compete for the $100,000 grand prize in San Jose at the BattleHack World Finals this coming November. To find out more about BattleHack visit: https://2014.battlehack.org/

title: Low-Cost Tech Revives the Mom and Pop Shop
content:
May 06, 2014
Jason Richelson, Founder & CEO, ShopKeep POS

If you’ve got a killer small business idea but you’re not sure when to take the plunge, I have an answer: the time is now. And not just because great entrepreneurs tend towards a ‘jump first, ask questions later’ attitude, but also because today it’s actually affordable.

For the longest time, large big-box corporations were able to dominate Main Street by providing a consistency of customer experience; by constantly optimizing prices; by maintaining a ruthless control on their operating costs. The problem for smaller businesses was, of course, that the tools required to accomplish this feat cost a small fortune.

I spent many years starting and running retail stores before I founded ShopKeep POS, and my first point of sale systems cost well over $10,000 – just for hardware. Add software, security patches, limited access, total reliance on customer care to make it work, and it was impossible to imagine how any small guys could get started.

The Good News? The Times They Are a-Changed

The advent of cloud-based technology has dramatically lowered hardware and software costs and made data more available than ever before. Now it seems like a new startup pops up every day, with offers targeted specifically at small business owners. Innovation has been ceaseless, competition has grown, and the price point has been driven downwards.

On Day 1 of their business, an entrepreneur can now access a whole range of services and tools that would have previously cost tens of thousands of dollars. Services like point-of-sale systems, scheduling and payroll, gift cards and loyalty services, accounting and bookkeeping, billing and invoicing, etc. are now available for monthly subscriptions that add up to less than the price of a good meal.  

Unlock New Livelihood

The technology that big business has had at its disposal for thirty years is now in the hands of the guy running your local bodega, the shop behind your neighborhood wine store, and the young entrepreneur starting a new food truck. It’s at your fingertips too; your craft can be a side business, or even a new career. Your hobby could be your key to a more fulfilling livelihood.

For those of us who love diversity and originality – and who recognize the value of local entrepreneurship to the economy (54% of US annual sales and 8 Million new jobs contributed since 1990) – this unprecedented access to efficiency and advanced analytics for the small business community is a huge opportunity. If you’re an aspiring local entrepreneur, there has never been a better time to get started, and the ShopKeep team has your back.

My team and I have put together a Small Business 101 guide to help you get off the ground and a guide to the best SMB technologies to help you stay efficient. Good Luck!

title: Empowering People Starts with Knowing Them
content:
July 07, 2014
Christina Smedley, Vice President, Global Brand and Communications, PayPal

There are age-old adages about time, money and technology that seem to have been accepted as universal truth: time equals money; money doesn’t grow on trees; need is the mother of invention…to name just a select few.

And at PayPal, we’re hoping to create new ones that will be part of our children’s or grandchildren’s vernacular as the innovation and product solutions we deliver around the world fundamentally change the ways people think about and experience money, which ultimately changes their day-to-day lives. We want to make them simpler, more secure, more enjoyable.

But to assume we, sitting in San Jose, know what that means everywhere in the world ignores the incredibly rich diversity across the 203 markets we serve around the globe. Even with our on the ground teams in these markets, deep customer driven insights and other ways we keep tabs on existing and future customers, we don’t know enough.

So we decided that to really empower the people in the rapidly changing, global marketplace we serve, we should go out and ask a broad sample directly about how they feel about various topics related to money, time, technology and other elements of the People Powered Economy.

The results are in, and we’re excited to share.

The main takeaway is that we seem to be on the right track: the vast majority of the world agrees that technology should make things simpler, connected and faster, delivering more choices and opportunities. 

The obstacles in the way, how to spend found time, and daily grievances vary significantly among countries, but it seems the world is ready for the People Economy we’re working so hard each day to power. For cash to disappear and mobile payments to get easier. For online transactions to simply and safely open access to the rest of the world’s goods. For an easier way to experience life’s moments and to express spontaneous generosity.

Knowing that what we deliver helps improve the quality of people’s lives helps keep us true to the mission that has driven PayPal from the very beginning, as delivered by cofounder Peter Thiel: to “give citizens worldwide more direct control over their currencies than they ever had before.”

We’ve come so far already, and can’t wait to reveal what the future holds. What do you hope to see?
For more stories on how both PayPal and individuals just like yourself are powering the People Economy, visit peoplerule.com
